Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by H. Robinson after a drawing by W. Etty of a character from Scott's novel The Bride of Lammermoor
Description#1: Three-quarter portrait of Lucy Ashton, as described in The Bride of Lammermoor, ch. 3. Illustrates the text: 'Lucy Ashton's exquisitely beautiful, yet somewhat girlish features, were formed to express peace of mind, serenity, and indifference to the tinsel of worldly pleasure. Her locks, which were of shadowy gold, divided on a brow of exquisite whiteness, like a gleam of broken and pallid sunshine upon a hill of snow.' (Bride of Lammermoor, ch. 3)
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt, 1834 (p. 11)
Subject#1: Scotland - History - 18th century - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Behind him, with his hands crossed on the cane upon which he rested, stood Dominie Sampson, whom Mannering recognised at once. Description#1: Depicts Julia Mannering, Charles Hazelwood, Lucy Bertram, and a servant chancing upon Vanbeest Brown in a fir plantation (Guy Mannering, ch. 31).

Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by W. H. Mote after a drawing by C. R. Leslie of a character from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
Description#1: Depicts Jeanie Deans in a tartan head-dress as she is presented to the Duke of Argyle (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 34). Illustrates the text: 'She wore the tartan plaid of her country, adjusted so as partly to cover her head, and partly to fall back over her shoulders. A quantity of fair hair, disposed with great simplicity and neatness, appeared in front of her round and good-humoured face, to which the solemnity of her errand gave an appearance of deep awe.'
Source#1: Portraits of the Principle Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt, 1834 (p. 10)
Subject#1: Scotland - History - 18th century - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by T. Johannot of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
Description#1: Depicts Meg Murdockson and Madge Wildfire apprehending Jeanie Deans on the road to London (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 29). From Trente vignettes pour les oeuvres de Walter Scott d'aprÌ¬s les tableaux de MM. Alfred et Tony Johannot. Paris: Furne, 1832? The Heart of Mid-Lothian was translated into French as La Prison d'Edimbourg (The Prison of Edinburgh).
Subject#1: Scotland - History - 18th century - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by Charles Rolls after a drawing by H. Richter of a scene from Leitch Ritchie's story The Outlaw's Bride
Description#1: Depicts a sleeping Jeanie Deans with Meg Murdockson and, in the background, Madge Wildfire (Heart of Mid-Lothian, ch. 31). The print, originally designed to illustrate The Heart of Mid-Lothian is here employed to illustrate a short tale, 'The Outlaw's Bride', by Leitch Ritchie. In its new context it depicts Jeanie Lindsay in Ronald Cameron's hut (The Outlaw's Bride, ch. 3).
Source#1: The Keepsake for MDCCCXXXIII. London: Longman & Co., 1832 (facing p. 283)
Subject#1: Scotland - History - 18th century - Fiction Ritchie, Leitch, 1800?-1865 - Characters - Heroines

Alternate Title#1: Steel vignette engraving by G. Adcock from a drawing by A. Chisholm of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
Description#1: Portrait of Effie Deans, known for her beauty as the 'Lily of St. Leonards', as described in The Heart of Midlothian, ch. 9. Illustrates the text: 'Effie Deans had now shot up into a beautiful and blooming girl. Her Grecian-shaped head was profusely rich in waving ringlets of brown hair, which, confined by a black hood of silk, and shading a laughing Hebe countenance, seemed the picture of health, pleasure, and contentment.'
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt, 1834 (p. 9)
Subject#1: Scotland - History - 18th century - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by J. Mitchell after a painting by C. R. Leslie of a scene from Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Mistrel
Description#1: Depicts a child playing at soldiers and an armoured guard. John Banim (1798-1842) and his brother Michael Banim (1796-1874) wrote national tales and novels, using the pseudonyms Barnes and Abel O'Hara, with the aim of doing for Ireland what Scott had done for Scotland. This engraving may originally have been intended as an illustration for Scott's The Lay of the Last Minstrel, possibly portraying Lady Branksome's infant son.
Source#1: The Keepsake for MDCCCXXX, ed. Frederic Mansel Reynolds. London: Hurst, Chance & Co., 1829
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Influence - Ireland
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by E. Scriven after a drawing by H. Howard of a character from Scott's novel The Monastery
Description#1: Frontal portrait of the White Lady, supernatural protectress of the House of Avenel in Scott's novel The Monastery. Inspired by the lines: '"Noon gleams on the Lake | Noon glows on the Fell | Wake thee, O wake, | White Maid of Avenel!" These lines were hardly uttered, when there stood the figure of a female clothed in white, within three steps of Halbert Glendinning.' (The Monastery, ch. 11)
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels: With Illustrative Letter-Press. London: Chapman & Hall, 1833-
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by G. H. Adcock from a drawing by E. Prentis of a character from Scott's novel The Monastery
Description#1: Three quarter portrait of Mysie Happer, the miller's daughter in Scott's novel The Monastery. Inspired by the lines: 'The countenance itself was exceedingly comely--the eyes black, large, and roguishly good-humoured--the mouth was small--the lips well formed, though somewhat full--the teeth were pearly white--and the chin had a very seducing dimple in it.' (The Monastery, ch. 13)
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels: With Illustrative Letter-Press. London: Chapman & Hall, 1833-
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by H. Cook after a drawing by R. B. Faulkner of a character from Scott's novel The Monastery
Description#1: Portrait of Mary Avenel, heroine of Scott's novel The Monastery. Inspired by the lines: 'Mary Avenel had been taught by the peculiarity of her situation, to regard herself as the Child of Destiny; and the melancholy and reflecting turn of her disposition gave to her sorrows a depth and breadth peculiar to her character.' (The Monastery, ch. 30)
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels: With Illustrative Letter-Press. London: Chapman & Hall, 1833-
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by A. Caron after a drawing by A. Johannot of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
Description#1: Depicts Sir Piercie Shafton attempting to revive Mary Avenel. Behind him, Edward Glendinning is being prevented from drawing his sword to avenge his brother Halbert whom he wrongly believes Shafton has killed (Monastery, ch. 26). From Trente vignettes pour les oeuvres de Walter Scott d'aprÌ¬s les tableaux de MM. Alfred et Tony Johannot (Paris: Furne, 1832)?

Title#1: Abbot Boniface & Father Philip = L'abbÌ© Boniface & le pÌ¬re Philippe
Alternate Title#1: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
Description#1: Shows Abbot Boniface confronting a drenched Father Philip after the White Lady has pitched him into the mill-stream (Monastery, ch. 7).
Source#1: Landscape-Historical Illustrations of Scotland and the Waverley Novels, vol. I. London: Fisher, Son & Co., 1836-38 (facing p. 48)

Title#1: Melrose Cross: The Earl of Murray & Abbot of St. Mary's = Croix de Melrose: Le comte de Murray & l'abbÌ© de Ste. Marie
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by R. Staines after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
Description#1: Depicts the Earl of Murray and Abbot of Kennaquhair meeting beneath Melrose Cross, Melrose, Scottish Borders. The Earl is demanding that the Abbot hand over Sir Piercie Shafton (Monastery, ch. 37). As Scott himself acknowledged in the 'Magnum Opus' edition of The Monastery (1830), the fictional town and abbey of Kennaquhair in the novel were based on the Scottish Border town of Melrose.
Source#1: Landscape-Historical Illustrations of Scotland and the Waverley Novels, vol. I. London: Fisher, Son & Co., 1836-38 (facing p. 47)
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction Melrose (Scotland)

Title#1: Sir Piercie Shafton & Halbert Glendinning = Le chevalier Piercie Shafton & Halbert Glendinning
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by W. Floyd after a drawing by G. Arnald of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
Description#1: Depicts the duel between Sir Piercie Shafton and Halbert Glendinning (Monastery, ch. 21).

Title#1: Tower of Glendearg = Tour de Glendearg
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by G. Presbury after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
Description#1: Depicts the Abbot of Kennaqhair with his attendants, accompanied by Sir Piercie Shafton, approaching Glendearg Tower (Monastery, ch. 15). Glendearg Tower is reputedly based on Hillslap Tower, near Galashiels, which is now sometimes known as Glendearg Tower in homage to Scott.
Source#1: Landscape-Historical Illustrations of Scotland and the Waverley Novels, vol. I. London: Fisher, Son & Co., 1836-38 (facing p. 44)
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction Hillslap Tower (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by R. Staines after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
Description#1: Depicts Father Eustace approaching the Abbey of Kennaquhair which Scott based on Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders (Monastery, ch. 9).
Source#1: Landscape-Historical Illustrations of Scotland and the Waverley Novels, vol. I. London: Fisher, Son & Co., 1836-38 (facing p. 43)
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction Melrose Abbey

Title#1: Monastery: Abbey of St. Mary Kirkaldy
Alternate Title#1: Steel vignette engraving by Edward Finden of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Monastery
Description#1: Depicts the Abbey of Kennaquhair (based on Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders) with the gates thrown open in preparation for a procession (Monastery, ch. 37). Despite the caption, the engraving is an artist's impression of Melrose Abbey prior to its ruin. It was presumably engraved by Finden after his own design.
Source#1: The Waverley Album. London: Charles Heath, 1832 (facing p. 30)
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction Melrose Abbey

Title#1: [Steel vignette engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by Richard Westall of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery]

Title#1: [Steel engraving by C. Rolls after a drawing by Henry James Richter of a scene from Scott's novel Old Mortality]

Harrison's Christmas Tales (1833).

Title#1: [Steel engraving by W. H. Lizars after a drawing by William Allan of a scene from Scott's novel Old Mortality]

(Old Mortality, ch. 1)

Source#1: Ritchie, L. Scott and Scotland. London: Longman & Co., 1835 (facing p. 254)

Title#1: [Steel engraving by E. Radclyffe after a drawing by A. Soloman of a scene from Scott's novel Saint Ronan's Well]
Description#1: Shows Francis Tyrrel saving Clara Mowbray from the attentions of a drunken countryman (St. Ronan's Well, ch. 25). Illustrates the text: 'They had accomplished their purpose greatly to their satisfaction, and were hying home after sunset, when they were encountered by a country fellow [...] who [...] saw not the nobility of blood through her disguise, and accosted the daughter of a hundred sires as he would have done a ewe-milker. Miss Mowbray remonstrated--her companion screamed--up came cousin Francis with a fowling-piece on his shoulder, and soon put the sylvan to flight.'
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels. Library Edition, vol. 17, Edinburgh: Adam & Charles Black, 1877

Title#1: George Hamilton-Gordon, Earl of Aberdeen, K. T.-F. A. S. &c &c.
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of George Hamilton Gordon, Earl of Aberdeen, by T. Woolnoth after a painting by A. Wivell
Description#1: Portrait of the British statesman George Hamilton Gordon, Earl of Aberdeen (1784-1860). The Conservative diplomat and statesman George Hamilton-Gordon, 4th Earl of Aberdeen, served successively as British Ambassador to Austria (1813-14), Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster (1828), Foreign Secretary (1828-30 and 1841-46), Secretary of State for War and the Colonies (1834-35), and Prime Minister (1852-55). Scott first met him as a guest of Lord Abercorn in 1807, judging him 'a very accomplishd young man who promises to make a figure' (letter to Lady Scott, 30 March 1807). Lord Aberdeen subsequently secured a diplomatic position for Scott's son Charles (1830) and furnished his son Walter with a letter of introduction to the British Ambassador to France. The original portrait by Wivell was painted in the mid-1820s.
Source#1: The National Portrait Gallery of Illustrations and Eminent Personages. London: Fisher, Son & Co., 1846
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Aberdeen, George Hamilton Gordon, Earl of, 1784-1860 - Portraits
Subject Person#1$1: Gordon, George Hamilton, Earl of Aberdeen

Title#1: Addison: From a Picture Copied by J. Thurston in the Possession of the Publisher
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Joseph Addison by J. Thomson after J. Thurston after G. Kneller.
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the English essayist and poet Joseph Addison (1672-1719). In June 1819, the actor Daniel Terry acquired for Scott a collection of antiquarian material for Abbotsford, including a pair of velvet slippers and a wig-case belonging to the English essayist and poet Joseph Addison. Scott replied: 'If Addison's slippers and wig-box will serve you in your professional dress, pray accept them from me, for my curiosity leads chiefly to articles of armour; and Addison, I know not why, is personally no such favourite of mine as Sir Roger de Coverley should make him' (letter of 15 June 1819). (Sir Roger de Coverley was a caricatural old country gentlemen created by Addison in The Spectator.) Despite his expressed distaste for Addison, Scott frequently quoted his works, particularly the tragedy Cato which he saw performed in Edinburgh in 1812, greatly admiring J. P. Kemble in the title role. The original portrait was painted by Sir Godfrey Kneller (1646-1723) between 1703 and 1712. The engraving was taken from a copy by John Thurston (1744-1822) made ca. 1820.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Authors, English - Portraits Addison, Joseph, 1672-1719 - Portraits

Description#1: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott engraved by John Horsburgh after a portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn painted in 1808. Scott sat for the original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn in spring 1808. Commissioned by Archibald Constable, it was completed in the same year. It is now in the possession of the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry at Bowhill. The engraving by Horsburgh was published in the 2nd edition of J. G. Lockhart's Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. (1839) but previously issued separately in 1837.

Title#1: Sir Walter Scott in his Study (Castle Street, Edinburgh)
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by Robert Charles Bell after a painting by J. Watson Gordon
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott seated at his desk at 39 North Castle Street, Edinburgh, with his cat Hinse of Hinsefeldt and dog Maida. The original portrait of Sir Walter Scott by John Watson Gordon is a posthumous likeness dating from the 1840s or 1850s. There are numerous inaccuracies and anachronisms. Scott's study at 39 North Castle Street (his Edinburgh home from 1801 to 1826) was lined with bookshelves and featured a portrait of John Graham of Claverhouse where Gordon has placed his own portrait of Scott's mother. The painting now belongs to the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. This engraving by Robert Charles Bell was published as the frontispiece to Portrait of Sir Walter Scott and Five Engravings in Illustration of The Pirate (Edinburgh: [Royal Association for the Promotion of the Fine Arts in Scotland, 1871]).
Source#1: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott and Five Engravings in Illustration of The Pirate. Edinburgh: [RAPFAS], 1871
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Oil painting of Melrose Abbey after D. Roberts]
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders. The description of a moonlit Melrose Abbey in Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (canto II, stanza 1), and its further depiction in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820), led to it becoming a popular destination for sightseers. The original painting by Roberts was exhibited at the Society of British Artists in 1824. Cf. Guiterman, H. and Llewellyn, B. (eds). David Roberts (Oxford: Phaidon Press, 1986).
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose Abbey

Title#1: His Majesty King George the IV, Born August 12 1762
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of a portrait of King George IV after Thomas Phillips
Description#1: Engraved portrait of George IV, King of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland from 1820 to 1830. George IV, both as Prince Regent and King, bestowed a number of favours upon Sir Walter Scott. In 1813 he offered Scott the post of Poet Laureate (which Scott refused in favour of Robert Southey). In 1815 he twice invited Scott to dine with him and granted him free access to the Regent's Library, where Scott consulted papers on the Jacobite Rebellions of 1715 and 1745-46. In 1818 Scott became the first man to be knighted under George IV and the first ever to be knighted in recognition of literary merit. When the new king commissioned Sir Thomas Lawrence to paint the most distinguished men of the age for the great gallery at Windsor Castle, he desired that Scott be foremost amongst the men of science and letters. For his part, Scott played a leading role in organizing the visit of King George IV to Edinburgh in 1822, the first visit of a Hanoverian monarch to Scotland. The 'Magnum Opus' edition of the Waverley Novels is dedicated to the King. This uncredited print is made from a portrait by Thomas Phillips and closely resembles an engraving by Luigi Schiavonetti in the National Portrait Gallery.
Subject#1: Great Britain - Kings and rulers - Portraits George IV, King of Great Britain, 1762-1830 - Portraits
Subject Person#1$1: George IV, King of Great Britain

Alternate Title#1: Coloured photograph of a watercolour by W. Allan of the dining room at Abbotsford
Description#1: Depicts the dining room of Sir Walter Scott's home of Abbotsford, Scottish Borders, on the day of the writer's death, 21 September 1832. Sir William Allan had been invited by Scott's son-in-law and future biographer J. G. Lockhart to make images of the interior apartments of Abbotsford as occupied by Scott.

Description#1: This sketch of Hermitage Castle, Scottish Borders, was copied from an original pencil drawing by Sir Walter Scott. The sixteenth-century castle of Hermitage was a favourite of Scott's and is described in his Essay on Border Antiquities (1814). While gathering ballads in Liddesdale Scott, carried out excavations at the Hermitage and made a sketch of the castle. A print derived from Scott's sketch was published in Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1804), and the backdrop of Sir Henry Raeburn's 1808 portrait of Scott is also based on it.
Subject#1: Hermitage Castle (Scotland)

Title#1: Sir Walter Scott and his Literary Friends at Abbotsford

Description#1: Depicts the dining room at Scott's home of Abbotsford, Scottish Borders, where the writer, surrounded by friends, is reading from a manuscript. The original painting by Thomas Faed was exhibited in 1850 and enjoyed great success when engraved by his brother James Faed. Portrayed from left to right are: Seated: Thomas Thomson, James Ballantyne, Archibald Constable, Thomas Campbell, Tom Moore, Sir Adam Fergusson, Francis Jeffrey, William Wordsworth, John Gibson Lockhart, George Crabbe, Henry Mackenzie, Scott, and (on footstool) James Hogg. Standing: Sir Humphrey Davy, Sir David Wilkie, Sir William Allan, Prof. John Wilson.

Title#1: Abbotsford. Scale Four Chains to an Inch
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of plan of Abbotsford and adjacent land
Description#1: Facsimile of the original 1811 plan for the Abbotsford estate, Scottish Borders, with annotations in Scott's own hand. When Scott bought the 110-acre Cartley Hole Farm in 1811 he renamed it Abbotsford. He bought up neighbouring properties until in 1825 the estate had expanded to ten times its original size. By 1821, the residence that he had built between 1812 and 1818 had become too small for the estate and for the constant stream of visitors that he received. A two-storey manor house (portrayed here) was built in its stead. Scott continued to live in Abbotsford following the financial disaster of 1825-26 as the estate had been settled upon his newly married son Walter. Abbotsford proved immensely influential on nineteenth-century building styles, sparking the Victorian revival of Scots-Baronial architecture. The architects were William Atkinson and Edward Blore, with assistance from Scott himself.
Source#1: Scott, W. Familiar Letters of Sir Walter Scott, vol. I. Edinburgh: David Douglas, 1894 (at end of volume)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Abbotsford (Scotland) - Designs and plans

Alternate Title#1: Cover illustration for a quadrille inspired by Scott's novel Old Mortality
Description#1: Front cover of a book of sheet music, depicting John Graham of Claverhouse, Viscount Dundee ('Bonnie Dundee') on horseback saluting a cheering crowd. The campaign against the Covenanters, conducted by Graham of Claverhouse, is the subject of Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816). In a footnote to the Magnum Opus edition of the novel (1830), Scott writes: 'This remarkable person united the seemingly inconsistent qualities of courage and cruelty, a disinterested and devoted loyalty to his prince, with a disregard of the rights of his fellow-subjects. He was the unscrupulous agent of the Scottish Privy Council in executing the merciless severities of the government in Scotland during the reigns of Charles II. and James II.; but he redeemed his character by the zeal with which he asserted the cause of the latter monarch after the Revolution, the military skill with which he supported it at the battle of Killiecrankie, and by his own death in the arms of victory.' Scott was fascinated by the figure of Claverhouse, whom he believed had been traduced by Presbyterian historians, and displayed a portrait of him in his study at Castle Street, Edinburgh. Claverhouse is also portrayed in 'Wandering Willie's Tale' (1824) and in the song 'Bonnie Dundee' in Scott's play The Doom of Devorgoil (1830).
Source#1: Albert, C. L. N. d'. Bonnie Dundee: Quadrille. London: Chappell & Co., [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Musical settings Graham, John, Viscount Dundee, 1648-1689

Title#1: [Title page of James Hogg's The Brownie of Bodsbeck; and Other Tales]
Description#1: James Hogg's novel The Brownie of Bodsbeck is a fictional account of the 17th-century Covenanting movement, written in response to Scott's Old Mortality, and offering a more sympathetic portrayal of the Covenanters. Scott met the poet and novelist James Hogg while researching material for Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-03). Scott remained his lifelong friend and patron. Following Scott's death, Hogg published The Domestic Manners and Private Life of Sir Walter Scott (1834).
Source#1: Hogg, J. The Brownie of Bodsbeck. Edinburgh: William Blackwood, 1818
Subject#1: Scotland - History - 1660-1688 - Fiction Covenanters - Fiction

Alternate Title#1: Frontispiece engraving by W. Greatbatch after a drawing by W. Boxall of a scene from Scott's novel Count Robert of Paris
Description#1: Depicts Count Robert seated on the throne of Emperor Alexius during the oath-taking ceremony on the eve of the Crusade (Count Robert of Paris, ch. 9). Illustrates the lines: 'Without a moment's hesitation the Frank seated himself in the vacant throne of the Emperor, and extending his half-armed and robust figure on the golden cushions which were destined for Alexius, he indolently began to caress a large wolf-hound.' This engraving was originally made for the Magnum Opus edition of Count Robert of Paris, published by Robert Cadell, Edinburgh, in 1833. The engraver's name is variously spelt 'Greatbatch' or 'Greatbach'. Most reference sources favour the latter spelling.

Title#1: The Regalia of Scotland, Edinburgh Castle
Alternate Title#1: Albumen print by Alexander Inglis of the Scottish crown jewels
Description#1: Albumen print depicting the Regalia of Scotland or Scottish crown jewels. Following the Act of Union between England and Scotland in 1707, the ancient Regalia (or 'Honours') of Scotland were deposited in a locked oak chest in the Crown Room of Edinburgh Castle. Over the following decades, their whereabouts was forgotten, and it was rumoured that, counter to the terms of the Union, they had been carried away to England. Prompted by Sir Walter Scott, the Prince Regent set up a commission to search the Crown Room for the Regalia. On 4 February 1818, the Commissioners, including Scott, discovered the chest and found, wrapped in linen, the fourteenth-century Scottish Crown, the Sceptre of James V, and the Sword of State, a gift from Pope Julius II to James V. The Regalia were subsequently placed on permanent display in the Crown Room. Scott described the discovery in his Description of the Regalia of Scotland (1819).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Regalia of Scotland. Edinburgh: published at the Crown Room, 189-
Subject#1: Regalia (Insignia) - Scotland Crown jewels - Scotland
Related Work Title#1: Description of the Regalia of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Title page and frontispiece of a dramatization of Scott's novel Rob Roy by I. Pocock
Description#1: Frontispiece illustration depicting the singer Catherine Stephens in the role of Diana Vernon in Isaac Pocock's musical drama Rob Roy Macgregor, or, Auld Lang Syne. Also title-page of libretto to the opera. Rob Roy Macgregor, or, Auld Lang Syne was adapted from Scott's novel Rob Roy by Isaac Pocock, with music by Sir Henry Bishop (1786-1855) and John Davy (1763-1824). It was first performed at Covent Garden, London, on 12 March 1818 and went on to become one of the most popular and frequently revived dramas of the nineteenth century.
Source#1: Pocock, Isaac. Rob Roy MacGregor, or, Auld lang syne: An opera. London: W. Simpkin & R. Marshall, 1821
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Musical settings Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Description#1: Black and white postcard showing Sir Walter Scott's study at Abbotsford House, Scottish Borders. When Scott bought the 110-acre Cartley Hole Farm in 1811 he renamed it Abbotsford. He bought up neighbouring properties until in 1825 the estate had expanded to ten times its original size. By 1821, the residence that he had built between 1812 and 1818 had become too small for the estate and for the constant stream of visitors that he received. A two-storey manor house (portrayed here) was built in its stead. Scott continued to live in Abbotsford following the financial disaster of 1825-26 as the estate had been settled upon his newly married son Walter. Abbotsford proved immensely influential on nineteenth-century building styles, sparking the Victorian revival of Scots-Baronial architecture. The architects were William Atkinson and Edward Blore, with assistance from Scott himself.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Abbotsford (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Frontispiece illustration by A.H. Payne of a German translation of Scott's novel Ivanhoe
Description#1: Portrait of Rebecca, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's novel Ivanhoe. This portrait was engraved by the German-based English artist Albert Henry Payne (presumably from his own design) for a German translation of Ivanhoe. It depicts Rebecca as described in chapter 7 of the novel: 'Her form was exquisitely symmetrical, and was shown to advantage by a sort of Eastern dress, which she wore according to the fashion of the females of her nation. Her turban of yellow silk suited well with the darkness of her complexion. The brilliancy of her eyes, the superb arch of her eyebrows, her well-formed aquiline nose, her teeth as white as pearl, and the profusion of her sable tresses, which, each arranged in its own little spiral of twisted curls, fell down upon as much of a lovely neck and bosom as a simarre of the richest Persian silk, exhibiting flowers in their natural colours embossed upon a purple ground, permitted to be visible--all these constituted a combination of loveliness, which yielded not to the most beautiful of the maidens who surrounded her. It is true, that of the golden and pearl-studded clasps, which closed her vest from the throat to the waist, the three uppermost were left unfastened on account of the heat, which something enlarged the prospect to which we allude. A diamond necklace, with pendants of inestimable value, were by this means also made more conspicuous. The feather of an ostrich, fastened in her turban by an agraffe set with brilliants, was another distinction of the beautiful Jewess, scoffed and sneered at by the proud dames who sat above her, but secretly envied by those who affected to deride them.'
Source#1: Scott, W. Ivanhoe (tr. Ernst Susemihl). Stuttgart: Hoffmann'sche Verlagsbuchhandlung, 1851
Subject#1: Great Britain - History - Richard I, 1189-1199 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Title#1: Goetz of Berlichingen, with the Iron Hand: A Tragedy
Alternate Title#1: Title page of Scott's translation of Goethe's drama Goetz of Berlichingen
Description#1: Title page of Sir Walter Scott's translation of Goethe's tragedy Goetz of Berlichingen erroneously giving Scott's name as William Scott. Scott began his literary career with a series of translations from contemporary German literature. Of Goethe, the European writer whom Scott most admired, he translated Goetz of Berlichingen (1799), 'The Erl-King' (1799), 'Frederick and Alice' (1800), and 'Lamentation of the Faithful Wife of Asan Aga' (1806). Scott described Goethe as 'a wonderful fellow, the Ariosto at once, and almost the Voltaire of Germany' (Journal, 15 February 1827) and acclaimed him as 'an author born to arouse the slumbering fame of his country' (Introduction to 'Magnum' edition of Anne of Geierstein, 1831). Scott was bitterly disappointed that Goethe's death on 22 March 1832 thwarted a long-cherished plan to visit him at Weimar. Goethe, in his turn, was a great admirer of the Waverley Novels, praising Scott in a letter of 12 January 1827 for his 'wonderful pictures of human life'. Deeply flattered, Scott sent Goethe a copy of his Life of Napoleon Buonaparte and hailed him as 'the father of the German literature' (letter of 9 July 1827).
Source#1: Goethe, J.W. Goetz of Berlichingen, with the iron Hand: a Tragedy (tr. Walter Scott). London: J. Bell, 1799
Subject#1: German drama (Tragedy) - Translations into English

Alternate Title#1: Engraving by C. Rolls of a painting by J.-B. Isabey depicting Napoleon Bonaparte
Description#1: Portrays Napoleon Bonaparte in the grounds of the ChÌ¢teau de Malmaison, the country house bought by his wife JosÌ©phine de Beauharnais, which was from 1800 to 1802 seat of the French government. This is the frontispiece to the 1834 edition of Scott's Life of Napoleon Bonaparte, which was first published in nine volumes in 1827. In a letter to Lady Abercorn (April 21, 1824), Scott described Napoleon as 'a strange mingled phantom of grandeur and terror and a little meanness withal as ever bestrode the destinies of the world'. The original portrait by Isabey was considered to be one of the closest likenesses of Napoleon.
Source#1: Scott, W. Life of Napoleon Buonaparte. Edinburgh: Robert Cadell, 1834 (frontispiece)
