Title#1: John Flaxman: From the Original Picture by John Jackson in the Possession of the Right Hon. Lord Dover
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of John Flaxman by R. Woodman after a painting by John Jackson
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the English sculptor and designer John Flaxman (1755-1826). Sir Walter Scott's friend George Ellis suggested that he invite Flaxman to illustrate The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805). Scott feared, however, that Flaxman's style was 'too classical to stoop to body forth my Gothic Borderers' and that there would be 'some risk of their resembling the antique of Homer's heroes, rather than the iron race of Salvator' (letter of 21 August 1804). Scott had, in fact, already arranged to have the volume illustrated by engravings from paintings by John James Masquerier. Flaxman himself was no admirer of Scott. According to Crabb Robinson's diary, he remarked to Samuel Rogers that 'his works have in no respect tended to improve the moral condition of mankind'. The original portrait by John Jackson was painted in the mid-1820s.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Sculptors - England - Portraits Flaxman, John, 1755-1826 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Title#1: The Right Hon.ble Chas. James Fox: Principal Secretary of State for the Foreign Department &c&c&c
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait by James Ogbourne
Description#1: Engraved vignette portrait of the British statesman Charles James Fox (1749-1806). When, in 1806, Scott's political patron Henry Dundas, 1st Viscount Melville, was acquitted of misappropriation of public funds, Sir Walter Scott composed a celebratory song which mocked Melville's Whig opponents Samuel Whitbread and Charles James Fox: 'But the Brewer we'll hoax, | Tallyho to the Fox, | And drink MELVILLE for ever, as long as we live!' ('Health to Lord Melville', lines 82-84). These lines, composed when Fox was gravely ill, gave serious offence to his supporters and cost Scott the friendship of Dugald Stewart and the Countess of Rosslyn. Scott made partial amends by praising Fox's patriotism in the Introduction to Canto I of Marmion (1808): 'When Europe crouch'd to France's yoke, | And Austria bent, and Prussia broke, | And the firm Russian's purpose brave, | Was barter'd by a timorous slave, | Even then dishonour's peace he spurn'd, | The sullied olive-branch return'd, | Stood for his country's glory fast, | And nail'd her colours to the mast!' (lines 154-161). In the Introduction to the 1830 edition of Marmion, Scott recalls his reluctance to appeal to Fox to sort out a clerical error jeopardizing his appointment as Principal Clerk to the Court of Session. He feared that it might appear an expression of 'political opinions different from those which I have always professed', although 'in his private capacity, there is no man to whom I would have been more proud to owe an obligation'. Scott was also told that Fox admired his Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), and wrote: 'Although my Tory principles prevent my coinciding with his political opinions, I am very proud of his approbation in a literary sense' (letter to George Ellis, 26 May 1805). The engraving may derive from a painting by John Raphael Smith.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Fox, Charles James, 1749-1806 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Title#1: Charles James Fox: From a Picture by Sir Joshua Reynolds in the Possession of Lord Holland
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Charles James Fox by J. W. Cook after a painting by Sir Joshua Reynolds
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the British statesman Charles James Fox (1749-1806). When, in 1806, Scott's political patron Henry Dundas, 1st Viscount Melville, was acquitted of misappropriation of public funds, Sir Walter Scott composed a celebratory song which mocked Melville's Whig opponents Samuel Whitbread and Charles James Fox: 'But the Brewer we'll hoax, | Tallyho to the Fox, | And drink MELVILLE for ever, as long as we live!' ('Health to Lord Melville', lines 82-84). These lines, composed when Fox was gravely ill, gave serious offence to his supporters and cost Scott the friendship of Dugald Stewart and the Countess of Rosslyn. Scott made partial amends by praising Fox's patriotism in the Introduction to Canto I of Marmion (1808): 'When Europe crouch'd to France's yoke, | And Austria bent, and Prussia broke, | And the firm Russian's purpose brave, | Was barter'd by a timorous slave, | Even then dishonour's peace he spurn'd, | The sullied olive-branch return'd, | Stood for his country's glory fast, | And nail'd her colours to the mast!' (lines 154-161). In the Introduction to the 1830 edition of Marmion, Scott recalls his reluctance to appeal to Fox to sort out a clerical error jeopardizing his appointment as Principal Clerk to the Court of Session. He feared that it might appear an expression of 'political opinions different from those which I have always professed', although 'in his private capacity, there is no man to whom I would have been more proud to owe an obligation'. Scott was also told that Fox admired his Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), and wrote: 'Although my Tory principles prevent my coinciding with his political opinions, I am very proud of his approbation in a literary sense' (letter to George Ellis, 26 May 1805). The original portrait was painted by Reynolds in 1782-83.

Title#1: Franklin: From an Original picture by J. A. [sic] Duplessis in the Possession of Mr. Barnet Consul General for the United States of America at Paris
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Benjamin Franklin by J. Thomson after a painting by J. A. Duplessis
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Benjamin Franklin (1706-1790), American author, publisher, scientist, inventor, and diplomat. Walter Scott quotes from the maxims of Benjamin Franklin in letters to Alexander Ballantyne (24 April 1817) and Daniel Terry (18 February 1824). The original portrait by Duplessis was painted in 1778.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Books and reading Franklin, Benjamin, 1706-1790 - Portraits

Title#1: Frederick II: From the original by Carlo Vanloo in the private collection of the King of the French
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Frederick II of Prussia by E. Scriven from a picture by Carlo Vanloo
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Frederick II ('the Great'), King of Prussia (1712-1786). In Munich in May 1832, Sir Walter Scott admired the coat, pistols, saddle and bridle of Frederick the Great. He had earlier advised his soldier son Walter to read Frederick's instructions to light troops as 'he was the first who reduced that important part of an army to system and principle' (letter of 27 June 1820). In his Life of Napoleon Buonaparte (1827-28), Scott describes the King of Prussia and Tsar of Russia swearing to liberate Germany on Frederick the Great's tomb. In Paul's Letters to His Kinsfolk (1815), he unfavourably compares Napoleon who plundered the artistic treasures of Dresden with Frederick who was content to admire them.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Prussia - Kings and rulers - Portraits Frederick II, King of Prussia, 1712-1786 - Portraits

Title#1: Galileo: From a picture by Ramsay in Trinity College, Cambridge
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Galileo by R. Hart after a painting by Ramsay
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei (1564-1642). In May 1832 Sir Walter Scott visited the Basilica di Santa Croce in Florence where he would have seen Galileo's tomb. The painting by Ramsay is copied from an original portrait by Justus Sustermans in the Palazzo Pitti, Florence.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Astronomers - Italy - Portraits Galilei, Galileo, 1564-1642 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of George II by S. F. Ravenet probably after T. Worlidge
Description#1: Engraved profile portrait of George II, King of Great Britain (1683-1760). Sir Walter Scott's first novel Waverley (1814) is set during the Jacobite Rebellion of 1745-46 which sought to place Charles Edward Stewart on the British throne in place of the Hanoverian George II. The hero, Edward Waverley, is arrested on a charge of 'levying war against the king, the highest delinquency of which a subject can be guilty' (ch. 31). A further fictional rebellion against George II is described in Redgauntlet (1824). Here the ultimate failure of the Jacobite cause is proved by the reading of George II's personal orders to let the conspirators return in peace to the Continent (ch. 23). The Jacobite Rebellions are also described in Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1829), where Scott terms Georges I and II 'men of honour, courage, and good sense; but, being born and educated foreigners [...] strangers to the peculiar character, no less than to the very complicated form of government, of the country over which they were called by Providence to reign'. Despite Scott's insistence on George II's 'good sense', there are references in The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818) to his notorious temper. Miss Damahoy has heard 'that King George flang his periwig in the fire when he heard o' the Porteous mob', kicked Sir Robert Walpole, and, according to Bartholomew Saddletree 'was for kicking the Duke of Argylle too'. Miss Damahoy concludes that 'he might keep mair wit in his anger' (ch. 23). In the same novel Jeanie Deans successfully pleads with Queen Caroline to intercede with George II to pardon her sister Effie. The engraving by Ravenet is probably derived from a 1753 painting by Thomas Worlidge.
Subject#1: Great Britain - Kings and rulers - Portraits George II, King of Great Britain, 1683-1760 - Portraits
Subject Person#1$1: George II, King of Great Britain

Title#1: His Majesty King George the IV: Born August 12 1762
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of George IV
Description#1: Engraved vignette portrait of George IV, King of Great Britain (1762-1830) with geometrical surround design. George IV, both as Prince Regent and King, bestowed a number of favours upon Sir Walter Scott. In 1813 he offered Scott the post of Poet Laureate (which Scott refused in favour of Robert Southey). In 1815 he twice invited Scott to dine with him and granted him free access to the Regent's Library, where Scott consulted papers on the Jacobite Rebellions of 1715 and 1745-46. In 1818 Scott became the first man to be knighted under George IV and the first ever to be knighted in recognition of literary merit. When the new king commissioned Sir Thomas Lawrence to paint the most distinguished men of the age for the great gallery at Windsor Castle, he desired that Scott be foremost amongst the men of science and letters. For his part, Scott played a leading role in organizing the visit of King George IV to Edinburgh in 1822, the first visit of a Hanoverian monarch to Scotland. The 'Magnum Opus' edition of the Waverley Novels is dedicated to the King. The uncredited engraving is based on a painting by Thomas Phillips and closely resembles an engraving by Luigi Schiavonetti in the National Portrait Gallery.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries George IV, King of Great Britain, 1762-1830 - Portraits
Subject Person#1$1: George IV, King of Great Britain

Title#1: Gibbon: From a Print by Jas. Hall after a Picture by Sir Joshua Reynolds
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving of Edward Gibbon by W. Holl after a painting by J. Reynolds
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the English historian Edward Gibbon (1737-1794). Edward Gibbon, best known for his History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire (1776-88), was a constant source and model for Sir Walter Scott, particularly in Count Robert of Paris (1831), which drew extensively on Gibbon's account of the Byzantine Empire under the Komnenian Restoration. The Introduction to the novel quotes extensively from Gibbon's judgment of the princess and historian Anna Komnene or Comnena. The original portrait by Sir Joshua Reynolds was painted ca. 1779. The engraving by Holl is based on an earlier engraving by John (not James) Hall published in 1780.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Books and reading Gibbon, Edward, 1737-1794 - Portraits

Title#1: Goethe: From a Picture by George Dawe. Esqr. RA in the Possession of Henry Dawe Esq
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Goethe by J. Posselwhite after a painting by George Dawe
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the German author Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749-1832). Sir Walter Scott began his literary career with a series of translations from contemporary German literature. Of Goethe, the European writer whom Scott most admired, he translated Goetz of Berlichingen (1799), 'The Erl-King' (1799), 'Frederick and Alice' (1800), and 'Lamentation of the Faithful Wife of Asan Aga' (1806). Scott described Goethe as 'a wonderful fellow, the Ariosto at once, and almost the Voltaire of Germany' (Journal, 15 February 1827) and acclaimed him as 'an author born to arouse the slumbering fame of his country' (Introduction to 'Magnum' edition of Anne of Geierstein, 1831). Scott was bitterly disappointed that Goethe's death on 22 March 1832 thwarted a long-cherished plan to visit him at Weimar. Goethe, in his turn, was a great admirer of the Waverley Novels, praising Scott in a letter of 12 January 1827 for his 'wonderful pictures of human life'. Deeply flattered, Scott sent Goethe a copy of his Life of Napoleon Buonaparte and hailed him as 'the father of the German literature' (letter of 9 July 1827). The original portrait by George Dawe was painted in 1819.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Books and reading Goethe, Johann Wolfgang von, 1749-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Rev. James Grahame, Author of "The Sabbath." &C
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Rev. James Grahame by S. Freeman
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the Scottish poet the Rev. James Grahame (1765-1811). Sir Walter Scott was a great admirer of James Grahame's The Sabbath (1804), 'a very pretty poem' which he recommended to James Currie and Anna Seward in letters of 25 February and 21 March 1805. John Ballantyne and Co., in which Scott held a half-share, published his British Georgics (1809). Grahame was a fellow Advocate who abandoned the Bar to take orders as an Anglican clergyman. Scott sought unsuccessfully to use his influence to have Grahame elected to the Lectureship of St George's Chapel, Edinburgh, in October 1808. On his death in 1811, Scott lamented him as 'one good man lost to the best of possible worlds' who 'had conscience and modesty enough for a whole General Assembly or Convocation' (letter to Charles Kirkpatrick Sharpe, 4 December 1811). He regretted however that his 'principles and prejudices and feelings made an odd jumble', hampering both his legal and ecclesiastical careers. He was a Jacobite yet a Whig, an Anglican yet an apologist for the Covenanters. Scott recalled teasing him for his detestation of his own kinsman John Graham of Claverhouse. Grahame is also mentioned in Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft as sharing the family superstition that the colour green is fatal to the Grahame clan, and having his library table covered in blue or black cloth.
Source#1: Wilson, James Grant. The Poets and Poetry of Scotland. London: Blackie & Son, 1876-77
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Grahame, James, 1765-1811 - Portraits

Title#1: Grotius: From an Original Picture by M.J. Mirevelt in the Possession of the Publisher
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Grotius by J. Posselwhite after a painting by M. J. van Miereveld
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the Dutch jurist and scholar Hugo Grotius (1583-1645). In chapter 1 of A Legend of Montrose (1819), Sir Walter Scott quotes Grotius's condemnation of mercenaries: 'Nullum vitae genus est improbius, quam eorum, qui sine causae respectu mercede conducti, militant' ('There is no more immoral way of life than that of these men who, regardless of the cause, fight for money'). Equally, when in Old Mortality (1816), James Graham of Claverhouse laments the Covenanters' contempt for the 'laws of war', he is referring to Grotius's De jure belli ac pacis libri (1625). In a letter to his son Captain Walter Scott of 25 December 1827, Scott hopes that his younger son Charles is busy studying 'Grotius, Puffendorf and others of that class of jurists' in order to obtain a post at the Foreign Office. The original portrait by Miereveld was painted in 1614.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Books and reading Grotius, Hugo, 1583-1645 - Portraits

Title#1: Gustavus Adolphus: From a Print by Paul Pontius after a Picture by Van Dyck
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Gustavus Adolphus by J. Posselwhite after a painting by Van Dyck
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Gustavus Adolphus, King of Sweden (1594-1632). Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden achieved renown as a military commander during the Thirty Years War (1618-48) with the aid of a brigade of Scottish mercenaries. In Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819), the soldier of fortune Captain Dalgetty refers constantly to his service under 'that invincible monarch, the bulwark of the Protestant faith, the Lion of the North, the terror of Austria, Gustavus the Victorious' (ch. 2). Captain Dalgetty's horse Gustavus is named in honour of his former commander. In Old Mortality (1816), Henry Morton considers taking up arms abroad: 'Perhaps some lucky chance may raise me to a rank with our Ruthvens, our Lesleys, our Monroes, the chosen leaders of the famous Protestant champion, Gustavus Adolphus' (ch. 6). Gustavus Adolphus's Scottish brigade is also discussed in Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829).
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Sweden - Kings and rulers - Portraits Gustaf II, Adolf, King of Sweden, 1594-1632 - Portraits
Subject Person#1$1: Gustaf II Adolf, King of Sweden

Title#1: Hale: From an Original Picture in the Library of Lincolns Inn
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Sir Matthew Hale by J. W. Cook after a painting by John Michael Wright
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the English jurist Sir Matthew Hale (1609-1676). In Letter VIII of Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft (1830), Sir Walter Scott regrets to quote 'the venerable and devout Sir Matthew Hales [sic]', as presiding at a trial in 1644 which saw two women Amy Dunny and Rose Callender hanged as witches on the flimsiest evidence. 'But no man', adds Scott, 'unless very peculiarly circumstanced, can extricate himself from the prejudices of his nation and age.' Scott had previously published the final recommendations of the Hale Committee (1652) on law reform in the Somers Tracts, vol. VI (1811). He quoted from this document in his own 'Essay on Juridical Reform' (1810). The original portrait was painted ca. 1670.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Lawyers - England - Portraits Hale, Matthew, 1609-1676 - Portraits

Description#1: Engraved portrait of the English astronomer Edmond Halley (1656-1742). The original portrait was painted in 1736.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Astronomers - England - Portraits Halley, Edmond, 1656-1742 - Portraits

Title#1: Hampden: From a Print by J. Houbraken 1740
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of John Hampden by J. Posselwhite after a print by J. Houbraken
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the English parliamentarian John Hampden (1594-1643). Hampden was staunchly opposed to autocratic rule of Charles I, particularly the King's attempts to levy the 'ship money' tax. There are several references to Hampden in Scott's novels of 17th-century England and Scotland. In Old Mortality (1816), the putative narrator Peter Pattieson writes that many Covenanters 'united the independent sentiments of a Hampden with the suffering zeal of a Hooper or Latimer' (ch. 1). In Woodstock (1826), the hostility of the wolfhound Bevis to the fugitive Charles II leads the King to believe that 'the spirit of Pym or Hampden has transmigrated into the rogue and continues to demonstrate his hatred against royalty and all its adherents' (ch. 24). In an Appendix to the Introduction to the 'Magnum Opus' edition of Peveril of the Peak (1831), Scott writes that 'the adventures ascribed to "historical characters" would, however, fail in their moral aim, if fiction were placed at variance with truth; if Hampden or Sydney, for example, were painted as swindlers'. Finally, a note to the 'Magnum' edition of Ivanhoe (1830) reveals that Scott borrowed his hero's name 'from a manor forfeited by the ancestor of the celebrated Hampden, for striking the Black Prince a blow with his racket, when they quarrelled at tennis'.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Statesmen - Great Britain - Portraits Hampden, John, 1594-1643 - Portraits

Title#1: Handel: From a Picture in the Collection of His Majesty at Windsor
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of Handel by J. Thomson after a painting by T. Hudson
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the German-British composer Georg Friedrich Handel (1685-1759). Sir Walter Scott was, by his own admission, no connoisseur of music. When his wife Charlotte attended the Edinburgh Music Festival in 1815, the highlight of which was a performance of Handel's Messiah, Scott preferred to stay at Abbotsford. He wrote that he was 'delighted with your having found the gaieties of the time acceptable' but that he would not 'give one "wheeble of a whaup" from the moss at Keaside for all the fine music you have heard' (letter of 11 November 1805). Scott nonetheless named Handel as pre-eminent in the art of music in his Life of Dryden (1808), where Handel's setting of Dryden's 'Alexander's Feast' is discussed. Handel is also quoted as identifying the morris dance as the quintessential English dance in a note to the Magnum Opus edition of The Fair Maid of Perth (1832). This engraving is based on a 1756 portrait of Handel by Thomas Hudson, now in the National Portrait Gallery.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Composers - Germany - Portraits Handel, George Frideric, 1685-1759 - Portraits

Title#1: John Harrison: From an Engraving by Tassaert, Published in 1768, after a Painting by King
Alternate Title#1: Steel engraved portrait of John Harrison by W. Holl after a painting by T. King
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the English horologist John Harrison. The English horologist John Harrison is best known for inventing the first practical marine chronometer, enabling navigators to compute accurately their longitude at sea. This engraving by William Holl is based on a previous engraving by Philippe Joseph Tassaert. The original portrait by Thomas King was painted in 1767.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Clock and watch makers - England Harrison, John, 1693-1776

Illustrates part III, stanza 38, lines 3-4: 'And there, before Lord Douglas' face, | With them he cross'd the flood.' This modern continuation of the ancient ballad Thomas the Rhymer was first published in The Minstrelsy of the Scottish Borders, vol. II (1802).
Source#1: Scott, W. Glenfinlas, and Other Ballads, etc.: Illustrated with Engravings from the Designs of Richd. Westall. London: J. Sharpe, 1812 (facing p. 130)
Subject#1: Thomas, the Rhymer, 1220?-1297? - Poetry

Alternate Title#1: Engraving by F. Engleheart from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Helvellyn
Description#1: Depicts Charles Gough's dog guarding his master's corpse from predators on the slopes of Helvellyn, Lake District(Helvellyn, stanza 2). Illustrates stanza 2, lines 7-8: 'The much-loved remains of her master defended, | And chased the hill-fox and the raven away.' This poem was inspired by the death by exposure of Charles Gough on Helvellyn in the Lake District, April 1805. It was first published in A Collection of Scottish Airs (Edinburgh: William Whyte, 1806).
Source#1: Scott, W. Glenfinlas, and Other Ballads, etc.: Illustrated with Engravings from the Designs of Richd. Westall. London: J. Sharpe, 1812 (facing p. 180)
Subject#1: Helvellyn (England) - Poetry Gough, Charles, d. 1805 - Poetry

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Williamina, Lady Forbes by C.H. Jeens
Description#1: Portrait of Williamina Belsches (1776-1810), later Lady Forbes of Pitsligo, Walter Scott's first love.
Source#1: Sharp, J.C, P.G. Tait and A. Adams-Reilly. Life and Letters of James David Forbes. London: Macmillan, 1873 (facing p. 4)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Forbes, Williamina, 1776-1810 - Portraits

Title#1: Anne Scott, Second Daughter of Sir Walter Scott
Alternate Title#1: Portrait of Anne Scott engraved by G.B. Shaw after W. Nicholson
Description#1: Portrait of Walter Scott's younger daughter Anne Scott (1803-1833) at the age of fifteen. The original portrait by William Nicholson was painted in 1818.
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart., vol. 7. Edinburgh: Cadell, 1848
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Family Scott, Anne, 1803-1833 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Title#1: Anne Rutherford, Mother of Sir Walter Scott
Alternate Title#1: Portrait of Anne Rutherford Scott engraved by G.B. Shaw after J.W. Gordon
Description#1: Portrait of Walter Scott's mother, Anne Rutherford Scott (d. 1819).
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. Edinburgh: A. & C. Black, 1871 (facing p. 30)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Family Scott, Anne Rutherford, d. 1819 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Title#1: Mrs J.G. Lockhart, Elder Daughter of Sir Walter Scott
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Charlotte Sophia Scott after W. Nicholson
Description#1: Portrait of Walter Scott's older daughter Charlotte Sophia (1799-1837) at the age of nineteen in Norwegian peasant dress. Charlotte Sophia Scott married Scott's future biographer John Gibson Lockhart on 29 April 1820. The original portrait by William Nicholson was painted in 1818.
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. Edinburgh: A. & C. Black, 1871 (facing p. 428)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Family Lockhart, Charlotte Sophia Scott, 1799-1837 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Alternate Title#1: Portrait of Charlotte, Lady Scott, engraved by G.B. Shaw after J. Saxon
Description#1: Three-quarter portrait of Walter Scott's wife, Charlotte, nee Carpenter (or Charpentier) (1770-1826) at the age of forty. The original portrait by James Saxon was painted in 1810 and is on display at Abbotsford House.
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. Edinburgh: A. & C. Black, 1871 (facing p. 79)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Family Scott, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, Lady, 1772 or 3-1826 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Title#1: Walter Scott. Surnamed "Beardie", Great-Grandfather of Sir Walter Scott
Alternate Title#1: Portrait of Walter Scott of Raeburn engraved by G.B. Shaw
Description#1: Three-quarter portrait of Walter Scott's great-grandfather, Walter Scott, 1st Laird of Raeburn (1653-1729). Walter Scott of Raeburn was known as 'Beardie' having sworn not to shave until the Stuarts were restored to the crown of Scotland. His property was confiscated following his participation in the Jacobite Rebellion of 1715. The painter of the original portrait is unknown.
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. Edinburgh: A. & C. Black, 1871 (facing p. 20)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Family Scott, Walter, c.1653-1729 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Title#1: Walter Scott, Writer to the Signet, Father of Sir Walter Scott
Alternate Title#1: Portrait of Walter Scott, W.S., engraved by G.B. Shaw
Description#1: Three-quarter portrait of Sir Walter Scott's father, Walter Scott, W.S. (1729-1799), in his late twenties. The original portrait was painted c. 1758 by an unknown artist.
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. Edinburgh: A. & C. Black, 1871 (facing p. 22)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Family Scott, Walter, 1729-1799 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of J.G. Lockhart by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Sketch of Sir Walter Scott's son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart. The writer and editor John Gibson Lockhart was Scott's son-in-law and biographer. He married Scott's daughter Sophia in 1820 and in 1837-38 published the monumental Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart., regarded by many as the greatest Romantic biography and still a standard reference work for scholars of Scott. Lockhart edited the influential Tory periodical, the Quarterly Review, from 1826 to 1853. This is a facsimile reproduction, on a slightly reduced scale, of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-38, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of "Illustrious Literary Characters", ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 7)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Family Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson), 1794-1854 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Alternate Title#1: Portrait of J.G. Lockhart engraved by G.B. Shaw after W. Allan
Description#1: Three-quarter portrait of Sir Walter Scott's son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart. The writer and editor John Gibson Lockhart was Scott's son-in-law and biographer. He married Scott's daughter Sophia in 1820 and in 1837-38 published the monumental Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart., regarded by many as the greatest Romantic biography and still a standard reference work for scholars of Scott. The original portrait by Allan has not been identified. The engraving may derive from the depiction of Lockhart in Allan's group-portrait 'Celebration of James Hogg, the Ettrick Shepherd's Birth Day (1819).
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. Edinburgh: A. & C. Black, 1871 (frontispiece)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Family Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson), 1794-1854 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Alternate Title#1: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott engraved by H.T. Ryall after J.P. Knight
Description#1: Half-length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-four. Scott sat for the original portrait by John Prescott Knight in January 1826. It was destroyed by fire in 1832. The engraving by Ryall was first published on June 1, 1833 by Harding & Lepard of London. It was subsequently reprinted in numerous publications. It is not known from which this engraving was extracted.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Steel engraving by G.B. Shaw of a statue of Sir Walter Scott by J. Greenshields
Description#1: Engraving of a statue of Sir Walter Scott (aged around sixty) with 'Sic Sedebat' inscribed on the pedestal. The original statue by John Greenshields was commenced in 1831 and completed in 1835. It is now displayed in Parliament House, Edinburgh. The engraving was first published in vol. II of J.G. Lockhart's Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. (Edinburgh: Cadell, 1837).
Source#1: Scott, Sir Walter. Waverley Novels, vol. XXV. Edinburgh: R. Cadell, 1843 (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott as a child by J. Horsburgh from a copy of the original miniature
Description#1: Profile portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of four or five. The original 'Bath miniature' was painted by an anonymous artist during the young Scott's visit to Bath in 1775/76. Although the dates for this visit are uncertain, it is likely that Lockhart's dating (1777) is wrong, and that Scott was at most five years old at the time of the sitting. The miniature has been attributed to Abraham Daniel of Bath (d. 1806) by Sir John Pope-Hennessy (Francis Russell, Portraits of Sir Walter Scott, p. 36). The engraving is made from a copy of the miniature at Abbotsford which Lockhart erroneously believed to be the original. The original is held by the Society of Antiquaries.
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. Edinburgh: Robert Cadell. 1839 (frontispiece)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: The Author of Waverley in his Study
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott in his study by E. Goodall after W. Allan
Description#1: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott, aged around fifty-six, sitting at his desk in his study at Abbotsford. The original portrait by William Allan was painted from sketches of Sir Walter Scott's study at Abbotsford, possibly made when Allan was working on his oil sketch A FÌ»te ChampÌ»tre at Abbotsford in August 1827. The editor of The Anniversary notes that some minor changes to the arrangement took place after these sketches were taken. Francis Russell suggests that the painting may have been made specifically in order to be engraved (Portraits of Sir Walter Scott, p. 25).
Source#1: Cunningham, A. (ed). The Anniversary, or Poetry and Prose for MDCCCXXIX. London: John Sharpe, 1828. (facing p. 98)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Engraved portrait by G.B. Shaw from a bust of Sir Walter Scott by Sir F. L. Chantrey]
Description#1: Engraving of a bust of Sir Walter Scott aged around fifty. Scott first sat for the original plaster bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. This engraving is from the marble replica (known as the 'Abbotsford Bust') that Chantrey made for Scott in 1821. It was first published in 1839 in vol. VII of J.G. Lockhart's Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart., 2nd edn (Edinburgh: Cadell, 1839).
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. The Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.: Abridged from the Larger Work. Edinburgh: Adam & Charles Black, 1871
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by Thomson from a bust by F. Chantrey
Description#1: Engraving of a bust of Sir Walter Scott aged around fifty with facsimile of signature. Scott first sat for the original plaster bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. This engraving is from the marble replica (known as the 'Abbotsford Bust') that Chantrey made for Scott in 1821. It was first published in the New Monthly Magazine, January 1, 1831, then reprinted as a supplement with the Court Journal of October 6, 1832. This copy is probably one of the 1832 prints. The engraver is probably James Thomson (occasionally spelt Thompson).
Source#1: Court Journal, October 6, 1832
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Engraved profile portrait of Sir Walter Scott by A. Collas derived from a bust by F. Chantrey]
Description#1: Profile portrait of Sir Walter Scott aged around fifty with facsimile of signature. Scott first sat for the original plaster bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. This engraving is from the marble replica (known as the 'Abbotsford Bust') that Chantrey made for Scott in 1821.This print was engraved by Achille Collas from a medallion by Henry Weekes derived from Chantrey's statue. It was first published in 1838 in The Authors of England (London: Charles Tilt).
Source#1: The Complete Works of Robert Burns and the Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott. Vol. II. Glasgow: William Collins. 1867 (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by T. Woolnoth after J. Graham-Gilbert
Description#1: Three-quarter length portrait of a seated Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-seven. Scott sat for the original portrait by John Graham (later Graham-Gilbert) between January and June 1829. It was commissioned by the Royal Society of Edinburgh which still owns the portrait. Scott is depicted wearing the gold chain of the President of the Society. Woolnoth's engraving was first published in 1832 in the National Portrait Gallery of Illustrious and Eminent Personages of the Nineteenth Century (London: Fisher, 1831-32) and in the Imperial Magazine, 2nd ser., vol. II (November 1832).
Source#1: National Portrait Gallery of Illustrious and Eminent Personages of the Nineteenth Century, vol. III. London: Fisher, 1832
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Reproduction of a photograph of a portion of mural featuring notable Scotsmen, including Sir Walter Scott, by W.B. Hole]
Description#1: A frieze of notable Scotsmen including Sir Walter Scott (seventh from the left). The original mural was commissioned for the Central Hall of the Scottish National Portrait Gallery and completed in 1898.
Source#1: Brown, P. H. History of Scotland to the Present Time. Vol. II. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1911
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by H.W. Smith after Sir T. Lawrence]
Description#1: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-five including a facsimile signature. Scott first sat for the original portrait by Sir Thomas Lawrence in March 1821 (not 1820). Further sittings followed in November 1826, but the painting was not ready for delivery until November 1828. Commissioned by George IV, it is part of the collection at Windsor Castle. A version of this engraving by Hezekiah Wright Smith was published in James F. Hunnewell's The Lands of Scott (Edinburgh: A. & C. Black; Boston: James R. Osgood, 1871).
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott from an engraving by W. Humphrys after Sir T. Lawrence
Description#1: Three-quarter length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-five. Scott first sat for the original portrait by Sir Thomas Lawrence in March 1821 (not 1820). Further sittings followed in November 1826, but the painting was not ready for delivery until November 1828. Commissioned by George IV, it is part of the collection at Windsor Castle. The engraving by William Humphrys (not Humphrey) was first published by Graves & Co. in 1844. This is a fascimile of a drawing made from the engraving by an unknown artist.
Source#1: Scott, W. Ivanhoe. London: Daily Express Publications, 1933 (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Photograph of a lithograph of Sir Walter Scott from a pencil drawing by Elliot Aitchison]
Description#1: Three-quarter portrait of Sir Walter Scott. Elliot Aitchison (1797-1858) was the nephew of Robert Shortreed, Sheriff-substitute for Roxburghshire and close friend of Sir Walter Scott. The original lithograph is held by Hawick Museum.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: 'We're proud to see ye, Shirra. Would ye honour us by comin' ben?'
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a drawing depicting a meeting between Sir Walter Scott and Tom Purdie
Description#1: Depicts Tom Purdie inviting Scott, whom he addresses as Sheriff Deputy of Selkirkshire, into his home. 'A Friend in Need' by Halbert Johnston Boyd is a fictionalized account of the first meeting between Scott and his retainer Tom Purdie ca. 1804 following a poaching incident.
Source#1: The Romance of Scott: His Home, His Work, His Country; Sir Walter Scott Centenary, 1832-1932. Edinburgh: Travel Press and Publicity Co., 1932 (p. 53)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Photograph of R. Dease's designs for stamps of John Keats, Thomas Gray and Sir Walter Scott
Description#1: Design for stamps with profile portraits of John Keats (3p), Thomas Gray (5p) and Sir Walter Scott (7 1/2p) The three stamps were designed by Rosalind Dease to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the death of John Keats, the 200th anniversary of the death of Thomas Gray and the 200th anniversary of the birth of Sir Walter Scott. The stamps were first issued on July 28, 1971. Dease's design is freely inspired by the bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved profile portrait by E. Lacey from a medal of Sir Walter Scott by A. J. Stothard
Description#1: Depicts a medallion with a profile portrait of Sir Walter Scott (aged around fifty) and a border decorated with military and Scottish motifs. The portrait is engraved by Edward Lacey from a medal cast by A. J. Stothard in 1827. The ornament is by Samuel Mitan after Henry Corbould. Stothard's medal is derived from the bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey.
Source#1: The Waverley Album: Containing Fifty-one Line Engravings to Illustrate the Novels and Tales of Sir Walter Scott. London: Charles Heath. 1832 (frontis)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a drawing of Sir Walter Scott by B. Driscoll after a bust by F. Chantrey
Description#1: Drawing from a bust of Sir Walter Scott aged around fifty. Scott first sat for the original bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. Further sittings took place in February-July 1821 and the bust was completed in that year. It is now on display at Abbotsford. This drawing by Driscoll was made to commemorate the bicentenary of Sir Walter Scott's birth in 1971. It was published by Noel Tatt of Hythe, Kent.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by M.I. Danforth after C.R. Leslie
Description#1: Three-quarter length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-three, seated with his coat of arms and motto ('Watch weel') in the background. Scott sat for the original portrait by Charles Robert Leslie in September 1824. Commissioned by the American man of letters George Ticknor, the painting was completed in 1824 and is now held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Leslie made a copy of his portrait for Archibald Constable, from which this engraving is probably derived. Danforth's engraving was published in the Literary Souvenir in 1829.
Source#1: Literary Souvenir for 1829. London: Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown & Green, 1829
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by W. Read after C.R. Leslie
Description#1: Half-length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-three, seated, with landscape in background. Scott sat for the original portrait by Charles Robert Leslie in September 1824. Commissioned by the American man of letters George Ticknor, the original painting was completed in 1824 and is now held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Leslie made a copy of his portrait for Archibald Constable, from which this engraving is probably derived. The engraving by William Read was first published in 1832 as the frontispiece to part 1 of The Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart., begun by William Weir and completed by George Allan.
Source#1: Weir, W. and G. Allan. Life of Sir Walter Scott, Baronet. Part I. Edinburgh: Thomas Ireland Junior, 1832 (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a sketch by D. Maclise of Sir Walter Scott and two dogs
Description#1: Full-length portrait of Sir Walter Scott aged fifty-four standing in left profile accompanied by two dogs. Below the portrait there is a facsimile of his signature. The original sketch by Daniel Maclise was made on 9 August 1825. It later formed one of a series of portraits published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-38, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Borland, W.P. (ed). The Scott Book: Scenes From the Novels of Sir Walter Scott. London: Bell, 1924 (p.viii)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Walter Scott's Introduction to Percy's Reliques
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a portrait of Sir Walter Scott as a child reading in a garden by W. Matthews
Description#1: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott as an eleven-year-old child, reading under a tree in a walled garden. The original portrait was painted in 1914. It depicts Scott in his Aunt Jenny's garden in Kelso, Scottish Borders, in the spring or summer of 1783. The artist is probably Winifred Matthews (born 1886).
Source#1: Cruse, A. Sir Walter Scott. London: George G. Harrap & Co, 1915 (facing p.32)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by Roffe after H. Raeburn
Description#1: Head and shoulders portrait, facing right, of Sir Walter Scott at the age of thirty-six. Scott sat for the original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn in spring 1808. Commissioned by Archibald Constable, it was completed in the same year. It is now in the possession of the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry at Bowhill. This engraving was originally published in The Mirror of Literature, 1826. The engraver was probably John Roffe (1769-1850). It is likely, however, that part of Roffe's work has been confused with that of an identically named engraver, possibly a son, active between 1820 and 1861. Roffe's engraving is itself based on an 1810 mezzotint by Charles Turner and an 1821 engraving by J. R. West.
Source#1: Tillotson, J. Lives of Eminent Men, or Biographical Treasury. London: Thomas Holmes, [185-?] (facing p.173)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by C. Heath after H. Raeburn
Description#1: Half-length portrait facing left of Sir Walter Scott at the age of thirty-six. Scott sat for the original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn in spring 1808. Commissioned by Archibald Constable, it was completed in the same year. It is now in the possession of the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry at Bowhill. Charles Heath's engraving, first published by Constable, Edinburgh, in 1820, is itself derived from an earlier engraving, made by Henry Meyer and published in the New Monthly Magazine, 1818 (see record 1039).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Poetical Works of Walter Scott, Esq. (Edinburgh: Constable, 1820), vol. I (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by J. Horsburgh after H. Raeburn
Description#1: Full-length portrait facing left of Sir Walter Scott at the age of thirty-six, seated with Camp at his feet and Hermitage Castle, Liddesdale, Scottish Borders, in the background. Scott sat for the original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn in spring 1808. Commissioned by Archibald Constable, it was completed in the same year. It is now in the possession of the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry at Bowhill. The engraving by Horsburgh was originally made for the 2nd edition of J.G. Lockhart's Life of Scott in 1839.
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley: or 'Tis Sixty Years Since. Centenary Edition. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1886. (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by W. H. Lizars after H. Raeburn
Description#1: Three-quarter length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of thirty-six. In his Portraits of Sir Walter Scott (1987), Frances Russell treats this engraving as a derivation of the portrait painted by Raeburn for Archibald Constable in spring 1808 (p. 74). In unpublished research James C. Corson argues that it was more probably derived from a second portrait by Raeburn, painted in 1809. and now on display at Abbotsford. The portrait was copied by J. G. Lockhart. The initials P.M. on the plate stand for Peter Morris, the pseudonym that Lockhart adopted when writing Peter's Letters to His Kinsfolk (1819), the publication for which this engraving was made. The engraver was William Home Lizars, son of Daniel Lizars. Although Daniel Lizars died in 1812, the family occasionally continued to use W. & D. Lizars as a collective signature.
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Peter's Letters to his Kinsfolk. Second Edition. Vol. II. Edinburgh: William Blackwood, 1819 (facing p.351)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Etching of Sir Walter Scott by R.S. Forrest after H. Raeburn]
Description#1: Shoulder-length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-one. In 1823 Raeburn worked simultaneously on two portraits of Scott, one for Lord Montagu of Boughton and one for Raeburn's private gallery. This etching probably derives from the latter which is now held by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. Robert Smith Forrest (1871-1943) was active as an etcher from 1908 onwards.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by J. Horsburgh after J.W. Gordon
Description#1: Three-quarter length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-eight. Scott is accompanied by his dog Maida. Scott sat for the original portrait by Sir John Watson Gordon in March 1830. Painted for Scott's publisher Robert Cadell, it is now in the possession of the Viscount Cowdray at Dunecht House. The engraving by Horsburgh was first published in 1831 as one of A New Series of Original Illustrations to All Editions of the Waverley Novels (London: Moon, Boys, and Graves).
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. New Edition, Complete in One Volume. Edinburgh: Robert Cadell, 1845 (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Altrieve Cottage: The Residence of the Ettrick Shepherd
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Altrive Cottage by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Altrieve Cottage, near Ettrick, Selkirkshire, and the attached hill-farm. Altrieve Cottage was the home of poet and novelist James Hogg, known as the 'Ettrick Shepherd'. Sir Walter Scott met Hogg while researching material for Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border and became his lifelong friend and patron.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Vol. II. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1837 (front.)
Subject#1: Hogg, James, 1770-1835 - Homes and haunts Altrieve Farm (Scotland)

Title#1: Altrive: The Residence of the Ettrick Shepherd
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Altrive by W. Richardson after D.O. Hill
Description#1: Depicts Altrieve Cottage, near Ettrick, Selkirkshire, with James Hogg and family in the foreground. Altrieve Cottage was the home of poet and novelist James Hogg, known as the 'Ettrick Shepherd'. Sir Walter Scott met Hogg while researching material for Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border and became his lifelong friend and patron.
Source#1: Hogg, J. Tales and Sketches by the Ettrick Shepherd. Vol. V. Glasgow: Blackie & son, 1837 (t.p.)
Subject#1: Hogg, James, 1770-1835 - Homes and haunts Altrieve Farm (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Barnard Castle by E. Finden after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts the moonlit ruins of Barnard Castle, County Durham. Barnard Castle features in Sir Walter Scott's poem Rokeby: 'Those towers, which in the changeful gleam | Throw murky shadows on the stream, | Those towers of Barnard hold a guest, | The emotions of whose troubled breast, | In wild and strange confusion driven, | Rival the flitting rack of heaven.' (Canto I, stanza 2, lines 1-6)
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Barnard Castle (England)

Title#1: Ben Lomond from above Luss, Dumbarton-shire
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Ben Lomond by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts a view of Loch Lomond with Ben Lomond in the background. The dramatic scenery of Loch Lomond and Ben Lomond feature prominently in both The Lady of the Lake and Rob Roy. While researching Rob Roy in July 1817, Scott visited the outlaw's cave at the head of Loch Lomond.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan. 1834 (t.p.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lomond, Loch (Scotland)

Title#1: Ashestiel: Scott's First House in the Border Country
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of Ashestiel by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Depicts a view of the house and gardens of Ashestiel near Selkirk, Scottish Borders. Ashestiel was Sir Walter Scott's summer residence from 1804 to 1811. It was here that Marmion and the first abortive chapters of Waverley were written. When the Ashestiel lease expired in May 1811 the Scott family moved to the site which was to become Abbotsford.
Source#1: Geddie, J. The Scott Country. London: Blackie & Son, 1922 (facing p. 55)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Ashestiel (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Ashestiel Bridge by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts a bridge over the River Tweed at Ashestiel, near Selkirk, Scottish Borders. Ashestiel was Sir Walter Scott's summer residence from 1804 to 1811. It was here that Marmion and the first abortive chapters of Waverley were written. When the Ashestiel lease expired in May 1811 the Scott family moved to the site which was to become Abbotsford.
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black. 1927 (facing p.38)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Ashestiel (Scotland)

Title#1: Scott's Favourite View: The Eildons and the Tweed from above Bemersyde
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of the Eildon Hills by G. Home
Description#1: Presents a view of the River Tweed, the Tweed Valley, and the Eildon Hills from Bemersyde Hill near Melrose, Scottish Borders. According to popular tradition, Sir Walter Scott so favoured this view and paused there so frequently on his way home to Abbotsford, that his horses eventually learned to stop without command. They are reputed to have stopped at the viewpoint even when drawing Scott's funeral carriage en route for Dryburgh Abbey in 1832.
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927 (facing p. 64)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Tweed River (Scotland and England)

Title#1: Scott's Favourite View from Bemersyde Hill, Roxburghshire.
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of the River Tweed and the Eildon Hills by H.S. Palmer
Description#1: Presents a view of the River Tweed, the Tweed Valley, and the Eildon Hills from Bemersyde Hill near Melrose, Scottish Borders. According to popular tradition, Sir Walter Scott so favoured this view and paused there so frequently on his way home to Abbotsford, that his horses eventually learned to stop without command. They are reputed to have stopped at the viewpoint even when drawing Scott's funeral carriage en route for Dryburgh Abbey in 1832.
Source#1: Smith, W., et al. Scott Country: Water-colours. London: A. & C. Black. 1932 (plate 14)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Tweed River (Scotland and England)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of Bemersyde House by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Presents a view of Bemersyde House, near Melrose, Scottish Borders, and its gardens. The view from Bemersyde Hill, near Melrose, which overlooks the Tweed Valley and Eildon Hills, was a particular favourite of Scott's. Directly under the brow of the hill lies Bemersyde House, seat of the Haigs of Bemersyde, where Scott was a frequent visitor. The house incorporates a rectangular tower built around 1535 which was restored and greatly extended in the 18th century.
Source#1: Geddie, J. The Scott Country. London: Blackie & Son, 1922 (p. 32)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Bemersyde House (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of Branxholme Castle by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Presents a view of Branxholme Castle, near Hawick, Scottish Borders, with the River Teviot in the foreground. Branxholme Castle is the ancient seat of the Dukes of Buccleuch, and provides the setting for much of The Lay of the Last Minstrel. Alternative spellings include Branxholm and Branksome, the latter preferred by Scott. The Lay of the Last Minstrel portrays the efforts of the Lady of Branksome to prevent marriage between her daughter and a feudal enemy and the siege of Branksome at the hands of an English army.
Source#1: Geddie, J. The Scott Country. London: Blackie & Son, 1922 (facing p. 21)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Branxholme Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Engraved picture of Cadzow Forest by W. Forrest after H. McCulloch
Description#1: Depicts Cadzow Forest, near Hamilton, Lanarkshire, with white cattle grazing. In the Introduction to Sir Walter Scott's ballad Cadyow Castle, he describes Cadyow (or Cadzow) Forest: 'In the immediate vicinity of Cadyow is a grove of immense oaks, the remains of the Caledonian Forest... they have witnessed the rites of the Druids... There was long preserved in this forest the breed of the Scottish wild cattle... Their appearance was beautiful, being milk-white, with black muzzles, horns, and hoofs.' Cadzow Forest was a favourite subject of Horatio McCulloch who depicted it in a number of paintings between 1834 and 1865. It is unknown which formed the basis for this engraving.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Surgeon's Daughter, and, Castle Dangerous. [Library Edition]. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1877
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Cadzow Forest (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved picture of Caerlaverock Castle by unknown artist
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Caerlaverock Castle, Dumfriesshire. Ellangowan Castle, seat of the Bertrams in Sir Walter Scott's Guy Mannering (1815), is often thought to be based on Caerlaverock Castle which Scott visited with Guthrie Wright in 1806. The engraver may be John Landseer who signed the frontispieces to The Beauties of Scotland (presumably working from his own design).
Source#1: Forsyth, R. The Beauties of Scotland. Edinburgh: Printed for Thomson Bonar and John Brown, 1805
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Caerlaverock Castle (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved view of Carlisle by E. Francis after W. Westall
Description#1: A prospect of the city of Carlisle, Cumbria, from the north bank of the River Eden, with St Mary's Church in the background. Scott married Margaret Charlotte Carpenter (or Charpentier) at St Mary's Church (which formed parted of what is now Carlisle Cathedral) on 24 December 1797. Carlisle also features in a number of Scott's works, most notably Waverley where Fergus MacIvor and Evan Dhu are executed at Carlisle Castle. Carlisle is also the scene of the trial and execution of Robin Oig M'Combich in 'The Two Drovers'.
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Carlisle (England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Carlisle Castle by E. Francis after R. Westall
Description#1: Depicts Carlisle Castle, Cumbria, with grazing cattle in the foreground. Edward Waverley visits the captive Fergus MacIvor in Carlisle Castle in Waverley ch. 69. MacIvor is subsequently executed outside the castle gate along with Evan Dhu. Besides featuring in a number of Scott's works, Carlisle was also the scene of Scott's wedding to Margaret Charlotte Carpenter on 24 December 1797.
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Carlisle Castle (Carlisle, England)

Title#1: Communion Rail, in the Old Church St. Mary, Carlisle
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the communion rail at St Mary's in Carlisle by W. H. MacFarlane
Description#1: Depicts the communion rail in St. Mary's Church in Carlisle, Cumbria. On Christmas Eve 1797 Sir Walter Scott married Margaret Charlotte Carpenter at St. Mary's Church, Carlisle (which formed part of what is now Carlisle Cathedral). According to C.S.M. Lockhart the ceremony took place at the communion rail depicted in this lithograph (The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, pp. 24-26). The lithograph by W. H. MacFarlane was based on a photograph taken by George Bell of Carlisle.
Source#1: Lockhart, C.S.M. The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. London: Virtue. 1871 (front.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Carlisle Cathedral (Carlisle, England)

Title#1: The Crown and Mitre Coffee House, English Street, Carlisle
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the Crown and Mitre Coffee House by W.H. MacFarlane
Description#1: Depicts the Crown and Mitre Inn and Coffee House in Carlisle, Cumbria. According to C.S.M. Lockhart, Scott put up at the Crown and Mitre Coffee House and Inn when visiting his fiancÌ©e Charlotte Carpenter in Carlisle in 1797 (The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, p. 21). The lithograph by W.H. MacFarlane was made from a photograph taken by J. Scott of Carlisle.
Source#1: Lockhart, C.S.M. The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. London: Virtue, 1871 (facing p.22)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Carlisle (England)

Title#1: No. 83, Castle Street and the Crown and Mitre Coffee House, Carlisle
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Castle Street and the Crown and Mitre Coffee House in Carlisle by W.H. McFarlane
Description#1: Depicts, left, the Crown and Mitre Inn and Coffee House in Carlisle, Cumbria, and, directly opposite, no. 83 Castle Street. According to C.S.M. Lockhart, Scott put up at the Crown and Mitre Coffee House and Inn when visiting his fiancÌ©e Charlotte Carpenter in Carlisle in 1797 (The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, p. 21). While in Carlisle, Charlotte Carpenter stayed with her friend Miss Nicholson at No. 83 Castle Street. The lithograph is taken from a photograph by either J. Scott or George Bell of Carlisle.
Source#1: Lockhart, C.S.M. The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. London: Virtue, 1871 (facing p.23)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Carlisle (England)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of No. 83 Castle Street, Carlisle by W.H. McFarlane
Description#1: Depicts No. 83 Castle Street, Carlisle, Cumbria. While in Carlisle in 1797, Sir Walter Scott's future wife, Charlotte Carpenter, stayed with her friend Miss Nicholson at No. 83 Castle Street. She remained there until her marriage to Scott was celebrated in St. Mary's Church, Carlisle, on 24 December 1797. The lithograph by W.H. MacFarlane was made from a photograph taken by J. Scott of Carlisle.
Source#1: Lockhart, C.S.M. The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. London: Virtue, 1871 (facing p.21)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Carlisle (England)

Title#1: Dunstaffnage Castle and Entrance to Loch Etive (West Highlands)
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Dunstaffnage Castle by E. Benjamin after T. Allom
Description#1: Depicts armed Highlanders outside Dunstaffnage Castle, near Oban, Argyllshire, with a vista of mountains in the background. Dunstaffnage Castle is often regarded as the model for Sir Duncan Campbell's castle of Ardenvohr in Scott's A Legend of Montrose. Scott visited the castle on 1 September 1814, but had earlier seen it from the sea when crossing to Mull in July 1810. This engraving was first published in William Beattie's Scotland Illustrated (1838).
Source#1: The Complete Works of Robert Burns and the Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott. Vol. II. Glasgow: William Collins, 1867 (facing p.224)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Dunstaffnage Castle (Scotland)

Title#1: The Inn at Clovenfords Where Scott Stayed
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Clovenfords Inn by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts Clovenfords Inn, near Galashiels, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott stayed at Clovenfords Inn (now Clovenfords Country Hotel) when fulfilling his duties as Sheriff-Depute of Selkirkshire until 1804 when he moved to Ashestiel.
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927 (facing p.35)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Clovenfords County Hotel (Galashiels, Scotland)

Title#1: Remains of the Old Castle of Douglas, Douglas-dale, Lanarkshire.
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the ruins of Douglas Castle by W. Forrest after J.C. Brown
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Douglas Castle, Lanarkshire, with an agricultural labourer and a draught horse in the foreground. Douglas Castle is portrayed as 'Castle Dangerous' in Scott's novel of that name. Scott, who had visited the castle in childhood, had previously contemplated writing a drama on it in 1802, and had discussed its role in the Wars of Independence in his 'Essay on Chivalry' (1818).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Surgeon's Daughter, and, Castle Dangerous. [Library Edition]. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1877
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Douglas Castle (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Drumlanrig Castle by Angus after F. Grose
Description#1: Engraving of Drumlanrig Castle, Dumfriesshire, and grounds. Scott and his family were frequent visitors at Drumlanrig Castle, seat of the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry, Scott's clan-chief and patron. The table in the dining room at Abbotsford was made from oak wood from the grounds of Drumlanrig Castle. This engraving was probably made by William Angus (1752-1821). The original drawing by Francis Grose was made before 1791.
Source#1: Forsyth, R. The Beauties of Scotland. Vol. II. Edinburgh: Printed for Thomson Bonar and John Brown, 1805
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Drumlanrig Castle (Scotland)

Title#1: Dryburgh Abbey: The Resting Place of Sir Walter Scott
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey by J. Le Keux after D. Roberts
Description#1: Depicts St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, the burial place of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Surgeon's Daughter: and, Castle Dangerous. [Library Edition]. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1877
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Tomb Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: Sir Walter Scott's Tomb, Dryburgh Abbey
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey by W. Banks and Son
Description#1: Depicts visitors at St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, the burial place of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here. The engraving may have been based on an original drawing by William Banks or his son. William Banks and Co. (or William Banks and Son) were active between 1858 and 1890.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Tomb Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a watercolour of Dryburgh Abbey by William Smith
Description#1: Depicts Gothic arches at Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, and a vista of Scott's burial place. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.
Source#1: Smith, W., et al. Scott Country: Water-colours. London: A. & C. Black. 1932 (Plate 15)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Tomb Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: [Facsimile of a painting of Sir Walter Scott's burial place at Dryburgh Abbey by T. Scott]
Description#1: Depicts lone visitor at St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, the burial place of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.
Source#1: Crockett, W.S. Footsteps of Scott. Edinburgh: T.N. Foulis, 1908 (facing p.198)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Tomb Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: Dryburgh Abbey: The Tomb of Sir Walter Scott
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of Sir Walter Scott's burial place at Dryburgh Abbey by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Depicts St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, the burial place of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.
Source#1: Geddie, J. The Scott Country. London: Blackie & Son, 1922 (facing p.28)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Tomb Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: Les debris de l'Abbaye de DRYBURGH
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey by J. Goeree
Description#1: Depicts tourist visiting the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, future resting place of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here. The original engraving, probably by Jan Goeree, was made expressly for Les dÌ©lices de la Grand' Bretagne, & de l'Irelande by James Beeverell. The engravings in this publication are largely based on previously published work.
Source#1: Beeverell, J. Les DÌ©lices de la Grand' Bretagne, & de l'Irelande. Vol. VI. A Leide: Pierre vander Aa, 1707 (facing p.1081)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Death and Burial Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: Vue du Bourg et des Ruines de l'Abbaye de DRYBURGH
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Dryburgh Abbey and its grounds by J. Goeree
Translated Title#1: View of the borough and of the ruins of the Abbey of Dryburgh
Description#1: Presents a view of the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, from the south bank of the River Tweed. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here. The original engraving, probably by Jan Goeree, was made expressly for Les dÌ©lices de la Grand' Bretagne, & de l'Irelande by James Beeverell. The engravings in this publication are largely based on previously published work.
Source#1: Beeverell, J. Les DÌ©lices de la Grand' Bretagne, & de l'Irelande. Vol. VI. A Leide: Pierre vander Aa, 1707 (facing p.1080)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Death and Burial Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: Dryburgh Abbey, Roxburghshire: (The Burial Place of Sir Walter Scott)
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey by J.C. Varrall after T. Allom
Description#1: Depicts the burial place of Sir Walter Scott in the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here. This engraving was originally published in William Beattie's Scotland Illustrated (1838).
Source#1: The Complete Works of Robert Burns and the Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott. Vol. II. Glasgow: William Collins, 1867 (facing p.56)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Tomb Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: Dryburgh Abbey: Sir Walter Scott's Sepulchre
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey by J. Johnstone after J. Bower
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, and the burial place of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here. The print was made by one, or possibly both, of the Edinburgh engravers James and John Johnstone.
Source#1: The History and Antiquities of Melrose, Old Melrose, and Dryburgh Abbeys. Melrose: J. Bower, 1852 (facing p.79)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Tomb Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Sir Walter Scott's burial place, Dryburgh Abbey by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts Sir Walter Scott's burial place in St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927 (facing p.73)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Tomb Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Dunstanburgh Castle by W. Floyd after J.W. Carmichael
Description#1: Depicts a storm-tossed sea boat with Dunstanburgh Castle, near Alnwick, Northumberland, in the background. Dunstanburgh (or Dunstanborough) Castle, dominates a stretch of coastline portrayed in Scott's Marmion: 'And next, they crossed themselves, to hear | The whitening breakers sound so near, | Where, boiling through the rocks, they roar | On Dunstanborough's caverned shore' (canto II, stanza 7, lines 17-20).
Source#1: The Gallery of Modern British Artists. London: Simpkin and Marshall, 1834. (facing p.42)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Dunstanburgh Castle (England)
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Elvet Bridge, Durham by E. Francis after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts the Elvet Bridge with Durham Castle in the background. The city of Durham features in a number of Scott's works, most notably Harold the Dauntless: 'Grey towers of Durham!... | Well yet I love thy mix'd and massive piles, | Half church of God, half castle 'gainst the Scot,' (canto III, pt. 1, lines 1,10-11). Jeannie Deans passes through Durham on her way to London in The Heart of Midlothian (ch. 27), and it also mentioned as the resting place of St Cuthbert in Marmion: 'There, deep in Durham's Gothic shade, | His relics are in secret laid' (canto II, stanza 14, lines 27-28).
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Durham (England)

Alternate Title#1: Coloured wood block engraving of Blenheim Palace by B. Fawcett after A.F. Lydon
Description#1: Depicts a view of Blenheim Palace, Oxfordshire, including the lake and Vanbrugh's Grand Bridge. The royal park and lodge featured in Sir Walter Scott's Woodstock have since been levelled and replaced by Blenheim Palace and the gardens of Capability Brown. The Palace is also mentioned in Waverley and Kenilworth. Scott visited Blenheim Palace with Richard Heber in May 1803. The original drawing (on wood) by A.F. Lydon was made expressly for The Ancestral Homes of Britain by F.O. Morris.
Source#1: Morris, F.O. The Ancestral Homes of Britain. London: Bell and Daldy, 1868
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Blenheim Palace (England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Canterbury Cathedral by E. Francis after W. Westall
