Description#1: Depicts Canterbury Cathedral, Kent, with grazing cattle in the foreground. Scott's son Walter was stationed in Canterbury as a Captain in the King's Hussars between 1827 and 1828. There are also brief references to Canterbury in Rob Roy, The Talisman, The Betrothed, and Count Robert of Paris.
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt. 1832.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Canterbury Cathedral

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the city of Chester by E. Francis after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts the River Dee and the city of Chester, Cheshire. Hugo de Lacy, the Constable of Chester, is a principal character in Sir Walter Scott's novel The Betrothed (1825).
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Chester (England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Dobbs Linn by W. Forrest after D.O. Hill
Description#1: An image of Dobbs Linn, near Moffat, Dumfriesshire, depicting a ravine with a waterfall cascading into a pool. A young girl, Katharine Laidlaw, is indicating the entrance to a hidden cave. Dobbs Linn was used as hiding-place by the Covenanters during the 'Killing Times'. The Linn and its surroundings influenced the geography of Sir Walter Scott's Tale of Old Mortality. ('Linn' can mean either a cascade, the pool into which a cascade falls, or a ravine.) The original painting by David Octavius Hill was made expressly for the 1837 edition of Tales and Sketches by the Ettrick Shepherd [i.e. James Hogg]. It illustrated a scene from 'The Brownie of Bodsbeck' where Katharine, daughter of the hero Walter Laidlaw, leads him to a hidden cave in the Linn.
Source#1: Hogg, J. Tales and Sketches by the Ettrick Shepherd. Vol. I. Glasgow: Blackie & Son, 1837 (front.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Dobbs Linn (Dumfriesshire, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of the Rhymer's Tower by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts the Rhymer's Tower in Earlston, Berwickshire, with fields of wheat in the foreground. The Rhymer's Tower is traditionally considered to have been the home of poet and prophet, Thomas the Rhymer. Sir Walter Scott included the ballad of Thomas the Rhymer in the second volume of his Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802), adding a 'Third Part' of his own composition. Scott also believed Thomas to be the author of 'Sir Tristrem', which he edited for publication in 1804.
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927. (facing p.6)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Rhymer's Tower (Earlston, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of a view of Edinburgh by W.H. Lizars after J.B. Kidd
Description#1: Presents a view of Edinburgh from Corstorphine Hill. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). The original work by Joseph Bartholomew Kidd was probably made expressly for Robert Chambers's The Picture of Scotland, a publication aimed at the tourist market.
Source#1: Chambers, R. The Picture of Scotland. Vol. II. Edinburgh: William Tait, 1827 (facing p.78)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Brown Square, Edinburgh by W. Forrest after D. Wilson
Description#1: Depicts a scene of daily life in Brown Square, Edinburgh. Brown Square or Brown's Square, named after the architect James Brown, was built as a residential development in 1763. It is the fictional home of Alan Fairford's family in Scott's novel Redgauntlet (1824). Brown Square was demolished in the 19th century to permit the building of George IV Bridge and Chambers Street. The original painting by Sir Daniel Wilson was made expressly for his book Memorials of Edinburgh in the Olden Time, which was first published in 1848.
Source#1: Wilson, D. Memorials of Edinburgh in the Olden Time. Vol. II. Edinburgh: A. and C. Black, 1891 (facing p.144)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Edinburgh (Scotland)

Title#1: Edinburgh Castle: From the Grey Friar's Church Yard.
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Edinburgh Castle by J.H. Kernot after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts a lone figure in Greyfriars Kirkyard with Edinburgh Castle in the background. Edinburgh Castle is the most prominent landmark of Scott's hometown. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). This engraving was first published in the first edition of Leitch Ritchie's Scott and Scotland (1835).
Source#1: Stevens, H.I. & A. Scott and Scotland, or, Historical and Romantic Illustrations of Scottish Story. London: H.I. & A. Stevens. 1845 (facing p.76)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh Castle (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Edinburgh Castle by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts Edinburgh Castle and Castle Rock with figures in the foreground. Edinburgh Castle is the most prominent landmark of Scott's hometown. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).
Source#1: Chambers, R. The Picture of Scotland. Vol. II. Edinburgh: W. Tait and Adam & Charles Black, 1834
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh Castle (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Edinburgh Castle by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts the Grassmarket with Edinburgh Castle in the background. Edinburgh Castle is the most prominent landmark of Scott's hometown. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).
Source#1: Black's Picturesque Tourist of Scotland. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black. 1840 (facing p. 42)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh Castle (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Edinburgh Castle by E. Francis after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts Princes Street Gardens with Edinburgh Castle in the background. Edinburgh Castle is the most prominent landmark of Scott's hometown. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh Castle (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: No 39, Castle Street, Edinburgh: The Town Residence of Sir Walter Scott for Upwards of Twenty-Five Years.
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of No.39 Castle Street, Edinburgh by W. Miller after J.M.W. Turner
Description#1: Depicts Castle Street with Edinburgh Castle in the background. During court term Sir Walter Scott lived with his family at 39 Castle Street, Edinburgh, from 1801 until 1826 when financial disaster compelled Scott to sell up.
Source#1: Lockhart, J.G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. Vol. IV. Edinburgh: Robert Cadell. 1839 (t.p.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland)

Title#1: Heriot's Hospital: From the Grass Market
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of George Heriot's School, Edinburgh by G. Aikman after J. Storer
Description#1: Depicts the Grassmarket, Edinburgh, with George Heriot's School in the background. George Heriot's School, formerly George Heriot's Hospital, was founded in 1628 as a result of a bequest by George Heriot, Goldsmith and Jeweller to James VI and I. Scott portrayed Heriot as 'Jingling Geordie' in his 1822 novel The Fortunes of Nigel. Scott also described the Hospital (i.e. orphanage) in Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). His family burial site lay in Greyfriars Kirkyard near the entrance to the Hospital.
Source#1: Black's Picturesque Tourist of Scotland. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1840
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts George Heriot's School
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Greyfriars Kirk, Edinburgh by T. Steuart after D. Wilson
Description#1: Presents a view of Greyfriars Kirk, Edinburgh, from (modern-day) Bristo Place, with Heriot's Hospital in the background. Greyfriars Kirk is mentioned in a number of Scott's novels, notably Guy Mannering and Redgauntlet. Scott's father and sister were both buried in the Scott family burial-plot in the Kirkyard. According to Lockhart, Scott also first made the acquaintance of his first love Williamina Belsches in the Kirkyard. Much of the older part of the church was destroyed by fire in 1845, but the building had been successfully restored by 1857.
Source#1: Wilson, D. Memorials of Edinburgh in the Olden Time. Vol. II. Edinburgh: A. and C. Black.,1891 (plate 19)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Kirk of the Greyfriars (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: Original Design for the Scott Monument
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of the design for the Scott Monument by G.M. Kemp
Description#1: Depicts the original design for the Scott Monument, Edinburgh, including small turrets at the corners. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in Edinburgh in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue of Scott by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.
Source#1: Bonnar, T. Biographical Sketch of George Meikle Kemp: Architect of the Scott Monument, Edinburgh. Edinburgh: Blackwood, 1892 (facing p.80)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Monuments Scott Monument (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Mary, Queen of Scot's Closet in the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh by J. Lewis after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts Mary, Queen of Scots' Closet in the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh. The Queen's 'closet' was a private meeting-room adjoining the Royal bed-chamber. It is best known as the scene of the murder of her secretary David Rizzio. This episode is described in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).The murder is also alluded to in The Abbot and Chronicles of the Canongate. This engraving was first published in the first edition of Leitch Ritchie's Scott and Scotland (1835).
Source#1: Stevens, H.I. & A. Scott and Scotland, or, Historical and Romantic Illustrations of Scottish Story. London: H.I. & A. Stevens, 1845 (facing p. 76)
Subject#1: Palace of Holyroodhouse (Edinburgh, Scotland) Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567
Related Work Title#1: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the Palace of Holyroodhouse by J. Fife after W. Westall
Description#1: Presents a view of the Palace of Holyroodhouse and Holyrood Park, Edinburgh, from Calton Hill. The Royal Palace of Holyroodhouse appears in a number of Scott's works, most notably in Waverley (1814) where it is occupied by Prince Charles Edward Stuart and is the scene of a ball (chapter 43). The Palace is also described in Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and is repeatedly mentioned in Tales of a Grandfather, First to Third Series (1828-30).
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt,1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Palace of Holyroodhouse (Edinburgh, Scotland)
Subject Person#1$1: Charles Edward, Prince grandson of James II, King of England
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Mary, Queen of Scot's Bedchamber by J. Lewis after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts Mary, Queen of Scots' bedchamber in the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh (with a seated Sir Walter Scott). The murderers of Mary Stuart's secretary David Rizzio dragged their victim from the Queen's presence into the royal bedchamber at the Palace of Holyroodhouse before dispatching him. This episode is described in Sir Walter Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).There are further references to the murder in The Abbot and Chronicles of the Canongate. The bedchamber was also the birth-place of Mary's son James who would unite the kingdoms of England and Scotland. He is a central character in Scott's 1822 novel The Fortunes of Nigel. This engraving was first published in the first edition of Leitch Ritchie's Scott and Scotland (1835).
Source#1: Stevens, H.I. & A. Scott and Scotland, or, Historical and Romantic Illustrations of Scottish Story. London: H.I. & A. Stevens. 1845 (facing p.37)
Subject#1: Palace of Holyroodhouse (Edinburgh, Scotland) Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567
Related Work Title#1: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of David Hume's Monument by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts Leith Wynd, Edinburgh, with a view of David Hume's tomb on Calton Hill. The Memorial to David Hume on Calton Hill, Edinburgh, was built to a design by Robert Adam in 1777. It is described in Sir Walter Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). Hume's History of England (1754-62) exerted a profound effect on Scott's own historical thought. In The Heart of Mid-Lothian, ch. 15, Sharpitlaw threatens to send Madge Wildfire to a workhouse in Leith Wynd.
Source#1: Black's Picturesque Tourist of Scotland. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1840
Subject#1: Hume, David, 1711-1776 - Monuments Calton Hill (Edinburgh, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of St. Anthony's Chapel, Edinburgh by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts St. Anthony's Chapel, Holyrood Park, Edinburgh, with Calton Hill in the background. In Sir Walter Scott's The Heart of Midlothian (ch. 15), the heroine Jeanie Deans meets her sister's seducer by moonlight beneath St. Anthony's Chapel. The Chapel is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).
Source#1: Black's Picturesque Tourist of Scotland. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1840
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings St. Anthony's Chapel (Edinburgh, Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Title#1: St. Giles' Church: From the N.West, Altered 1827
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of St. Giles' Cathedral by T. Steuart after D. Wilson
Description#1: Depicts the north-west face of St. Giles' Cathedral, Edinburgh. The Cathedral or High Kirk of St. Giles is described in Sir Walter Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). It is also mentioned in a number of Scott's other works, notably The Heart of Midlothian, Redgauntlet, The Antiquary, The Abbot, and The Fortunes of Nigel. The original work by Sir Daniel Wilson was made expressly for his book, Memorials of Edinburgh in the Olden Time, first published in 1848.
Source#1: Wilson, D. Memorials of Edinburgh in the Olden Time. Vol. II. Edinburgh: A. and C. Black, 1891 (plate 16)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts St. Giles' Cathedral
Related Work Title#1: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Salisbury Crags by J. Fife after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts the Salisbury Crags, Edinburgh, with Arthur's Seat in the background. The Salisbury Crags are described in Sir Walter Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). According to the General Preface to the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels (1829) Scott entertained his school-friends with his story-telling abilities during long walks in their vicinity. According to Lockhart, Scott also first tried his hand at composing verse during rambles on the Crags.
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Holyrood Park (Edinburgh, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Engraving by R. Scott of G.M. Kemp's design for the Scott Monument, Edinburgh
Description#1: Depicts the design for the Scott Monument in Princes Street, Edinburgh. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.
Source#1: Black's Picturesque Tourist of Scotland. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1840
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Monuments Scott Monument (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: Sir Walter Scott's Monument, From East Princes Street Gardens
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a watercolour of the Scott Monument by J. Fulleylove
Description#1: Depicts Princes Street Gardens, Edinburgh, and the Scott Monument. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.
Source#1: Smith, W., et al. Scott Country: Water-colours. London: A. & C. Black, 1932 (front.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Monuments Scott Monument (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Chromo-lithograph of Scott Monument by T. Nelson and Sons
Description#1: Depicts a view along Princes Street, Edinburgh, including the Scott Monument and Edinburgh Castle. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.
Source#1: Souvenir of Scotland: Its Cities, Lakes and Mountains. London: Nelson, 1890 (plate 3)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Monuments Scott Monument (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of St. Giles' Cathedral and Tolbooth by W. Forrest after D. Wilson
Description#1: Depicts the Tolbooth outside St. Giles' Cathedral, Edinburgh. The Old Tolbooth, a prison in Edinburgh's High Street nicknamed 'The Heart of Midlothian', features prominently in Sir Walter Scott's novel of that name, published in 1818. Although the Tolbooth was demolished in 1817, its former entrance is marked by a heart-shaped pattern of stones in the pavement by St. Giles' Cathedral. Following the demolition, the Tolbooth's doorway, door, and lock were incorporated into Scott's house of Abbotsford.
Source#1: Wilson, D. Memorials of Edinburgh in the Olden Time. Vol. I. Edinburgh: A. and C. Black. 1891. (facing p.71)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Old College, Edinburgh University by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts the Old College, University of Edinburgh. The foundation stone of the building now known as Old College was laid in 1789, but construction work was hindered by the Napoleonic Wars, and only a small part of Robert Adam's original design was built. The building was completed between 1817 and 1840 following an amended design by William Playfair. A dome by Robert Rowand Anderson was added in 1877. Scott attended the University of Edinburgh between 1783 and 1786 and between 1789 and 1792. The Old College faces College Wynd, Scott's birthplace.
Source#1: Black's Picturesque Tourist of Scotland. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1840
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Old College (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of West Bow, Edinburgh by J. Cousen after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts a street scene in West Bow, Edinburgh. In The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818), ch. 3, a group of people including Bartoline Saddletree and Reuben Butler discuss the reprieve of Captain Porteous while returning to their houses in the Lawnmarket via 'the steep declivity of the West Bow'. The West Bow was originally a steep winding road leading from the Grassmarket (site of the gallows) to Castle Hill, offering the only means of access to Edinburgh Castle from the South. It was largely demolished in the 1830s when Victoria Street and George IV Bridge were built to provide more convenient access. Only a small portion of the West Bow now survives at the foot of Victoria Street.
Source#1: Stevens, H.I. & A. Scott and Scotland, or, Historical and Romantic Illustrations of Scottish Story. London: H.I. & A. Stevens, 1845 (facing p. 82)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Edinburgh (Scotland)

Title#1: Cottage in Ettrick: The Birth Place of James Hogg
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Ettrick Cottage by D. Wilson after D.O. Hill
Description#1: Depicts Ettrick Cottage, Selkirkshire, with horse and cart on the road outside. The engraving shows the birthplace of novelist and poet James Hogg, known as the Ettrick Shepherd. Sir Walter Scott met Hogg while researching material for The Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border and became his lifelong friend and patron.
Source#1: Hogg, J. Tales and Sketches by the Ettrick Shepherd. Vol. V. Glasgow: Blackie & son, 1837 (front.)
Subject#1: Hogg, James, 1770-1835 - Birthplace Ettrick and Lauderdale (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Fast Castle by W. H. Lizars after J. Ewbank
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Fast Castle near St Abbs Head, Berwickshire. Fast Castle has been identified as an inspiration for Wolf's Crag, the home of the Master of Ravenswood in Sir Walter Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor (1819). In the Magnum Opus edition of the novel (1830), Scott claims that he cannot comment on the perceived resemblance between Wolf's Crag and Fast Castle as he has only seen the latter from the sea. He acknowledges, however, that the position of Fast Castle resembles that of Wolf's Crag as much as any other fortalice on the East Coast of Scotland. Scott also describes the castle in Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). Scott owned a painting of Fast Castle by the Rev. John Thomson (Letters, VIII, 459).
Source#1: Chambers, R. The Picture of Scotland. Vol. I. Edinburgh: W. Tait and Adam & Charles Black, 1834 (facing p. 52)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Fast Castle Site (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Flodden Field by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts a stormy sky over Flodden Field, Northumberland. Sir Walter Scott's poem Marmion culminates in one of the greatest disasters in Scottish history, the Battle of Flodden Field. It is described at length in Canto Sixth ('The Battle'). Scott visited the battlefield in August 1791.
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927 (facing p. 16)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Flodden, Battle of, England, 1513, in literature
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Floors Castle by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts a view of Floors Castle, Kelso, Scottish Borders, and grounds. Scott was a frequent visitor to Floors (formerly Fleurs) Castle which was built by William Adam for the 1st Duke of Roxburghe in 1721. In his unfinished Autobiography (1808) Sir Walter Scott describes the awakening of a sense of beauty during childhood stays in Kelso, 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic, village in Scotland'. Among its sights, he lists the castle 'which is so situated as to combine the ideas of ancient baronial grandeur with those of modern taste'. He again praises the beauty of Floors Castle in Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft (1830).
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927 (facing p. 28)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Floors Castle (Kelso, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Alternate Title#1: Coloured wood block engraving of Floors Castle by B. Fawcett after A.F. Lydon
Description#1: Depicts a view of Floors Castle, Kelso, Scottish Borders, and grounds. Scott was a frequent visitor to Floors (formerly Fleurs) Castle in Kelso which was built by William Adam for the 1st Duke of Roxburghe in 1721. In his unfinished Autobiography (1808; published in Lockhart's Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.) Sir Walter Scott describes the awakening of a sense of beauty during childhood stays in Kelso, 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic, village in Scotland'. Among its sights, he lists the castle 'which is so situated as to combine the ideas of ancient baronial grandeur with those of modern taste'. He again praises the beauty of Floors Castle in Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft (1830).
Source#1: Morris, F.O. The Ancestral Homes of Britain. London: Bell and Daldy, 1868 (facing p. 35)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Floors Castle (Kelso, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of 'The Popping Stone', Gilsland by W.H. McFarlane
Description#1: Depicts a large stone with hawthorn trees in the background. According to local tradition, the 'Popping Stone' in Gilsland, Cumbria, is where Sir Walter Scott proposed to his future wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter and the 'Kissing-Thorn' the site of their first kiss. The lithograph is taken from an uncredited photograph.
Source#1: Lockhart, C.S.M. The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. London: Virtue, 1871 (facing p. 20)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Gilsland (England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the city of Glasgow by E. Francis after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts Glasgow Green and the Clyde River with the city in the background. The city of Glasgow features prominently in Sir Walter Scott's Rob Roy (1817). Francis Osbaldistone crosses (and describes) Glasgow Green in Chapter 21 of the novel. Scott visited Glasgow on several occasions, notably in 1808, 1814, and 1817.
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Glasgow (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Keswick Bridge and Greta Hall by E. Francis after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts Keswick Bridge, Cumbria, with Greta Hall in the background. Greta Hall, when the home of Samuel Taylor Coleridge and, later, Robert Southey, played host to many literary figures including Sir Walter Scott, who visited Southey in August 1805, August 1813 and August 1825. In 1813, Scott was offered the post of Poet Laureate, but refused and instead suggested Southey.
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Southey, Robert, 1774-1843 - Homes and haunts Greta Hall (Keswick, England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Goldielands Tower by T. Vivares after F. Grose
Description#1: Depicts Goldilands Tower, near Hawick, Scottish Borders, overlooking the Teviot River. Goldilands (or Goldielands) Castle is a sixteenth-century peel tower built by the Scotts of Buccleuch to protect Branxholme Castle. It has been identified as the model for Westburnflat Tower in Sir Walter Scott's The Black Dwarf (1816). It is also mentioned in The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), where, on his way to Melrose Abbey, Sir William of Deloraine 'passed the Peel of Goldiland | And crossed old Borthwick's roaring strand' (canto I, stanza XXV, lines 7-8). The original drawing by Francis Grose was made expressly for his book The Antiquities of Scotland.
Source#1: F. Grose. The Antiquities of Scotland. London: Printed for S. Hopper, 1789-91
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Goldilands Tower (Hawick, Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Glencoe by W.H. Lizars after J.B. Kidd
Description#1: Depicts Glen Coe, Scottish Highlands, under a stormy sky. Sir Walter Scott wrote the poem 'On the Massacre of Glencoe' in 1814. He also described the massacre at length in Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1828).
Source#1: Chambers, R. The Picture of Scotland. Vol. II. Edinburgh: W. Tait and Adam & Charles Black, 1834 (facing p. 401)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Coe, Glen (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Title#1: Front View of the Old University at Glasgow
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Old College, Glasgow University by W.H. McFarlane
Description#1: Depicts the main faÌ¤ade of the Old College, Glasgow University. Old College Garden is the scene of a duel between Frank and Rashleigh Osbaldistone in Rob Roy (1817), ch. 25. There are further references to Glasgow University in Guy Mannering, The Fortunes of Nigel, A Legend of Montrose, and Old Mortality. Scott was elected Rector of Glasgow University in 1828 but declined the office. Old College was the location of Glasgow University until 1870 when it moved to its current premises. The lithograph is taken from an uncredited photograph.
Source#1: Lockhart, C.S.M. The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. London: Virtue, 1871 (facing p. 47)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts University of Glasgow

Title#1: View of the First College Court, in the Old University, Glasgow
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of courtyard in the Old College, Glasgow University by W.H. McFarlane
Description#1: Depicts courtyard in the Old College, Glasgow University. Old College Garden is the scene of a duel between Frank and Rashleigh Osbaldistone in Rob Roy (1817), ch. 25. There are further references to Glasgow University in Guy Mannering, The Fortunes of Nigel, A Legend of Montrose, and Old Mortality. Old College was the location of Glasgow University until 1870 when it moved to its current premises. The lithograph is taken from an uncredited photograph.
Source#1: Lockhart, C.S.M. The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. London: Virtue, 1871 (facing p.48)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts University of Glasgow

Title#1: Ground Plan of the House in which Walter Scott Was Born: From Edgar's Plan of Edinburgh, Drawn in 1742
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a map of Edinburgh showing Sir Walter Scott's birthplace
Description#1: Depicts a portion of a plan of Edinburgh showing College Wynd, the birthplace of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was born on 15 August 1771 in a house (since demolished) in College Wynd, Edinburgh. His family moved into new, healthier accommodation in George Square in 1774.
Source#1: Lockhart, C.S.M. The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. London: Virtue, 1871 (facing p.1)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland) - Maps

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing by W.J. Maskell of the Scott Monument
Description#1: Depicts the Scott Monument, Edinburgh, with the spire of St Giles' Cathedral visible in the background. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Monuments Scott Monument (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Hawthornden Castle by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts the North Esk River and Hawthornden Castle, Midlothian. The glen of Hawthornden, near Roslin, Midlothian, features in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rokeby, The Antiquary, 'The Gray Brother', and, in particular, The Lay of the Last Minstrel where 'a wondrous blaze... | 'Twas seen from Dryden's groves of oak, | And seen from cavern'd Hawthornden.' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 26-32). The site is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). The castle itself was built by the poet William Drummond in the seventeenth century.
Source#1: Chambers, R. The Picture of Scotland. Vol. II. Edinburgh: W. Tait: Adam & Charles Black, 1834 (facing p.86)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Hawthornden Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Hermitage Castle by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts Hermitage Castle, Scottish Borders, and surrounding countryside. The sixteenth-century castle of Hermitage was a favourite of Scott's and is described in his 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814). While gathering ballads in Liddesdale Scott carried out excavations at the Hermitage and made a sketch of the castle. A print derived from Scott's sketch was published in Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-04), and the backdrop of Sir Henry Raeburn's 1808 portrait of Scott is also based on it.
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927 (facing p. 89)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Hermitage Castle (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Inveraray Castle by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Inveraray Castle, Argyll and Bute, and surrounding countryside. The original castle of Inveraray features prominently as the seat of the Marquis of Argyle in Sir Walter Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose (1819). It was burnt down by the Marquis of Montrose in 1644 and the present castle, depicted here, was built in the 1740s. There are further references to Inveraray as the seat of the Duke of Argyll in The Heart of Mid-Lothian.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1837 (facing p. 109)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Inveraray Castle (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Jedburgh Abbey by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Jedburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott describes Jedburgh Abbey in his 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814), inaccurately praising its Anglo-Norman chapter-house as 'a very perfect specimen of Saxon architecture'. There are further references in The Black Dwarf and The Monastery. The Abbey was built by David I around 1138 but fell into ruin by the mid-sixteenth century. Scott was a frequent visitor to Jedburgh in his capacity as Sheriff Depute of Selkirkshire. He subscribed å£10 toward the repair-work on the Abbey's tower in 1824-1826.
Source#1: Forsyth, R. The Beauties of Scotland. Edinburgh: Printed for Thomson Bonar and John Brown, 1805
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Jedburgh Abbey (Jedburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a watercolour of Jedburgh Abbey by W. Smith
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Jedburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, with the River Tweed in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott describes Jedburgh Abbey in his 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814), inaccurately praising its Anglo-Norman chapter-house as 'a very perfect specimen of Saxon architecture'. There are further references in The Black Dwarf and The Monastery. The Abbey was built by David I around 1138 but fell into ruin by the mid-sixteenth century. Scott was a frequent visitor to Jedburgh in his capacity as Sheriff Depute of Selkirkshire. He subscribed å£10 toward the repair-work on the Abbey's tower in 1824-1826.
Source#1: Smith, W., et al. Scott Country: Water-Colours. London: A. & C. Black, 1932 (plate 9)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Jedburgh Abbey (Jedburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: [Facsimile of a painting of Jedburgh Abbey by T. Scott]
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Jedburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, with the River Tweed in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott describes Jedburgh Abbey in his 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814), inaccurately praising its Anglo-Norman chapter-house as 'a very perfect specimen of Saxon architecture'. Source#1: Crockett, W.S. Footsteps of Scott. Edinburgh: T.N. Foulis, 1908 (facing p. 152)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Jedburgh Abbey (Jedburgh, Scotland)

Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Jedburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, with the River Tweed in the foreground. Title#1: Kelso: The River Tweed and Abbey Ruins
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of Kelso Abbey by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Depicts the Tweed River and the ruins of Kelso Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott described Kelso in his unfinished Autobiography (1808) as 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Scott spent many summers in Kelso at his uncle Captain Robert Scott's house of Rosebank, which Scott inherited in 1804. In 1783, a convalescent Scott also attended Kelso Grammar School, where he made the acquaintance of his future business partner James Ballantyne. The Abbey at Kelso is one of four founded in the Borders by King David I. It is described in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).
Source#1: Geddie, J. The Scott Country. London: Blackie & Son, 1922 (facing p. 5)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Kelso (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Kelso Abbey by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts the bridge over the Tweed River and the ruins of Kelso Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott described Kelso in his unfinished Autobiography (1808) as 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Scott spent many summers in Kelso at his uncle Captain Robert Scott's house of Rosebank, which Scott inherited in 1804. In 1783, a convalescent Scott also attended Kelso Grammar School, where he made the acquaintance of his future business partner James Ballantyne. The Abbey at Kelso is one of four founded in the Borders by King David I. It is described in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927 (facing p. 83)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Kelso Abbey (Kelso, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Kelso Abbey, Scottish Borders. The Abbey at Kelso is one of four founded in the Borders by King David I. It is described in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).
Source#1: Forsyth, R. The Beauties of Scotland. Edinburgh: Printed for Thomson Bonar and John Brown, 1805 (facing p.100)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Kelso Abbey (Kelso, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Title#1: Loch of Monteath, Perthshire: Looking South East
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the Lake of Menteith by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts the Lake of Menteith and Inchmahome Priory, Stirling, with a family seated by the shore. The Lake of Menteith (or Monteath) on the Flanders Moss is often called the only lake, as opposed to 'loch', in Scotland. It is glimpsed briefly in Rob Roy, ch. 32. There are further references to the historical lands of Menteith in The Lady of the Lake and in A Legend of Montrose, where the Earl of Menteith plays a significant role. An island on the lake is the site of Inchmahome Priory where the infant Mary Queen of Scots took refuge after the defeat of the Scottish army at Pinkie Cleuch (1547).
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 41)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Menteith, Lake of (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Lancaster Castle by R. Parr after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts the John O' Gaunt Gateway, Lancaster Castle, Lancashire. Lancaster Castle was founded by Roger of Poitou at the end of the eleventh century. Sir Walter Scott, in his Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft, describes the Lancashire witch trials of 1612 (Letter VIII) where ten women were convicted of witchcraft at Lancaster Castle and hanged.
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lancaster Castle

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Lincluden Collegiate Church by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Lincluden Collegiate Church, Dumfriesshire. Lincluden College was established in 1389 by Archibald the Grim, Lord of Galloway. According to the Magnum Opus edition of The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1830), it was here that Helen Goldie, Scott's source for the tale, first met Helen Walker, the prototype for Jeanie Deans. It has also been suggested that the monastic ruins which Guy Mannering sketches in the opening chapter of the novel of that name are those of Lincluden College.
Source#1: Forsyth, R. The Beauties of Scotland. Edinburgh: Printed for Thomson Bonar and John Brown, 1805.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lincluden Collegiate Church (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Linlithgow Palace by W.H. Lizars after J.B. Kidd
Description#1: Depicts Linlithgow Palace, West Lothian, beside the shore of Linlithgow Loch. Linlithgow Palace was built in the eleventh century and was a royal residence from the twelfth to the late sixteenth century. It was accidentally gutted by fire in 1746. In Marmion (1808), Sir Walter Scott describes Linlithgow as: 'Of all the palaces so fair, | Built for the royal dwelling, | In Scotland, far beyond compare | Linlithgow is excelling;' (canto IV, stanza XV, lines 1-4). The Palace is more fully described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and features in a number of his other works, notably Waverley (1814) and Tales of a Grandfather (1828-1830). The entrance porch at Scott's home of Abbotsford was modelled after that of Linlithgow Palace.
Source#1: Chambers, R. The Picture of Scotland. Vol. II. Edinburgh: W. Tait: Adam & Charles Black, 1834
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Linlithgow Palace (Linlithgow, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Title#1: Loch Achray (Perthshire): From the Black Rock
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Achray by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts cattle grazing by the shores of Loch Achray, Stirling. Loch Achray appears in Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810): 'The Minstrel came once more to view | The eastern ridge of Benvenue, | For, ere he parted, he would say | Farewell to lovely Loch Achray--- | Where shall he find, in foreign land, | So lone a lake, so sweet a strand!' (canto VI, stanza XV, lines 1-6).
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 29)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Achray, Loch (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Ard by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Ard, Stirling, and the surrounding countryside. Loch Ard is described in chapter 20 of Scott's Rob Roy (1817): 'But the road now suddenly emerged from the forest ground, and, winding close by the margin of the loch, afforded us a full view of its spacious mirror, which now, the breeze having totally subsided, reflected in still magnificence the high dark heathy mountains, huge grey rocks, and shaggy banks, by which it is encircled.' The Falls of Ledard at the head of the Loch are thought to be the model for the waterfall in the Glen of Glennaquoich in Waverley, ch. 22. Scott recommended the Loch and the Falls as artistic subjects to Sir David Wilkie and James Skene (Letters, IV, 484, and IX, 224).
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 39)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Ard, Loch (Scotland)

Title#1: Loch Awe and Kilchurn Castle (Argyleshire): From the Gooses Rock
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Awe and Kilchurn Castle by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Kilchurn Castle on the shores of Loch Awe (Argyll and Bute). Loch Awe and its surrounding countryside feature in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works. 'The Highland Widow' (1827) is set on its banks. In 'Nora's Vow', translated from the Gaelic for Albyn's Anthology (published by Alexander Campbell in 1816), the heroine protests that she will never marry the Earl's son even if 'The Awe's fierce stream may backward turn, | Ben-Cruaichan fall, and crush Kilchurn' (III.3-4). Loch Awe also appears in A Legend of Montrose, ch. 17. In a letter to the painter Sir David Wilkie, dated 2 August 1817), Scott recommends that he 'visit the head of Loch Awe, which I look upon as equal to any thing in the Highlands' (Letters, IV, 484).
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 115)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Awe, Loch (Scotland)

Title#1: Loch-Awe (Argylshire): From above Cladich Looking North
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Awe by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Awe (Argyll and Bute) and surrounding countryside. Loch Awe and its surrounding countryside feature in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works. 'The Highland Widow' (1827) is set on its banks. In 'Nora's Vow', translated from the Gaelic for Albyn's Anthology (published by Alexander Campbell in 1816), the heroine protests that she will never marry the Earl's son even if 'The Awe's fierce stream may backward turn, | Ben-Cruaichan fall, and crush Kilchurn' (III.3-4). Loch Awe also appears in A Legend of Montrose, ch. 17. In a letter to the painter Sir David Wilkie, dated 2 August 1817), Scott recommends that he 'visit the head of Loch Awe, which I look upon as equal to any thing in the Highlands' (Letters, IV, 484).
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 119)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Awe, Loch (Scotland)

Title#1: Loch Awe (Argyleshire): From the Island of Fraoch Looking North
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Awe by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Awe (Argyll and Bute) and surrounding countryside. Loch Awe and its surrounding countryside feature in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works. 'The Highland Widow' (1827) is set on its banks. In 'Nora's Vow', translated from the Gaelic for Albyn's Anthology (published by Alexander Campbell in 1816), the heroine protests that she will never marry the Earl's son even if 'The Awe's fierce stream may backward turn, | Ben-Cruaichan fall, and crush Kilchurn' (III.3-4). Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Awe, Loch (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Earn by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Earn, Scottish Highlands, and surrounding mountains. Much of Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819) is set on the south bank of Loch Earn in or around the fictional Darlinvarich Castle, which is modelled on Ardvoirlich Castle. The Loch is also mentioned briefly in The Fair Maid of Perth (1828).
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 61)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Earn, Loch (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Earn by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Earn, Scottish Highlands, and surrounding mountains. Much of Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819) is set on the south bank of Loch Earn in or around the fictional Darlinvarich Castle, which is modelled on Ardvoirlich Castle. The Loch is also mentioned briefly in The Fair Maid of Perth (1828).
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p.63)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Earn, Loch (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Katrine by R. Sands after T. Allom
Description#1: Depicts a man and horse in a secluded bay of Loch Katrine, Stirling. Loch Katrine provides the setting for Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810). Following the success of the poem, the Loch and the surrounding Trossachs region became major tourist attractions. The original work by Thomas Allom was made expressly for William Beattie's Scotland Illustrated (1836).
Source#1: The Complete Works of Robert Burns and the Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott. Vol. II. Glasgow: William Collins, 1867 (facing p. 8)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Katrine, Loch (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Katrine by W.H. Lizars after J.B. Kidd
Description#1: Depicts Loch Katrine, Stirling, with Ben Venue in the background. Loch Katrine provides the setting for Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810). Following the success of the poem, the Loch and the surrounding Trossachs region became major tourist attractions.
Source#1: Chambers, R. The Picture of Scotland. Vol. II. Edinburgh: W. Tait: Adam & Charles Black, 1834
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Katrine, Loch (Scotland)

Title#1: West End of Loch Katrine (Perthshire): From the Garrow of Stronalachar
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Katrine by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Katrine, Stirling, and surrounding countryside. Loch Katrine provides the setting for Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810). Following the success of the poem, the Loch and the surrounding Trossachs region became major tourist attractions.

Title#1: Loch Katrine (Perthshire): From Craiginnes Looking South West
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Katrine by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Katrine, Stirling, in the moonlight. Loch Katrine provides the setting for Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810). Following the success of the poem, the Loch and the surrounding Trossachs region became major tourist attractions.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 23)

Title#1: East End of Loch Katrine, and Benvenue (Perthshire): Looking South
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Katrine and Ben Venue by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Katrine and Ben Venue. Loch Katrine in Perthshire provides the setting for Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810). Following the success of the poem, the Loch and the surrounding Trossachs region became major tourist attractions.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 25)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Katrine, Loch (Scotland)

Title#1: Loch Katrine & Helen's Isle (Perthshire): Looking South
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Katrine and Ellen's Isle by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Ellen's Isle in Loch Katrine, Stirling. In Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810), the Earl of Bothwell and his daughter Ellen take refuge on an island in Loch Katrine. Following the success of the poem, the Loch became a major tourist attractions and one of its islands was identified as Scott's setting and became known as 'Ellen's Isle'.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 27)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Katrine, Loch (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Leven Castle by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts three figures among the ruins of Loch Leven Castle, Fife. Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) centres around the imprisonment and escape from Loch Leven Castle of Mary, Queen of Scots. The thirteenth-century castle, built on the largest island in the Loch, also figures repeatedly in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p.207)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Loch Leven Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Leven and Loch Leven Castle by R. Brandard after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts figures in 16th-century military attire on the shore of Loch Leven, Fife, with Loch Leven Castle in the background. Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) centres around the imprisonment and escape from Loch Leven Castle of Mary, Queen of Scots. The thirteenth-century castle, built on the largest island in the Loch, also figures repeatedly in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828). This engraving was first published in the first edition of Leitch Ritchie's Scott and Scotland (1835).
Source#1: Black's Picturesque Tourist of Scotland. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1840
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Loch Leven Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Title#1: Loch Lochy (Invernesshire): From Tor-a-cromerk, Looking North East
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Lochy by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts a small farmstead on the shores of Loch Lochy, Scottish Highlands. Loch Lochy appears in Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819), ch. 18, as the Marquis of Argyll's army prepares to set up headquarters in Inverlochy Castle.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p.129)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lochy, Loch (Scotland)

Title#1: Loch Lomond (Dumbartonshire): From Mount Misery Looking North
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Lomond by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Lomond and surrounding mountains. Loch Lomond forms a dramatic part of the scenery in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rob Roy and The Lady of the Lake, where Roderick Dhu is portrayed as 'the terror of Loch Lomond's side' (canto II, stanza XI, line 14). Scott visited the Loch with his wife in the summers of 1809, 1816, and 1817.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 9)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lomond, Loch (Scotland)

Title#1: Loch Lomond, Ben Lomond, etc. (Dumbartonshire): From Ardleishdoun
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Lomond and Ben Lomond by J. Swan and J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Lomond with Ben Lomond in the background. Loch Lomond forms a dramatic part of the scenery in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rob Roy and The Lady of the Lake, where Roderick Dhu is portrayed as 'the terror of Loch Lomond's side' (canto II, stanza XI, line 14). Scott visited the Loch with his wife in the summers of 1809, 1816, and 1817.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 11)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lomond, Loch (Scotland)

Title#1: Loch Lomond, Dumbartonshire: From Upper Inveruglas
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Lomond by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Lomond and surrounding mountains. Loch Lomond forms a dramatic part of the scenery in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rob Roy and The Lady of the Lake, where Roderick Dhu is portrayed as 'the terror of Loch Lomond's side' (canto II, stanza XI, line 14). Scott visited the Loch with his wife in the summers of 1809, 1816, and 1817.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834. (facing p.13)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lomond, Loch (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Lomond and Ben Lomond by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts Loch Lomond with Ben Lomond in the background. Loch Lomond forms a dramatic part of the scenery in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rob Roy and The Lady of the Lake, where Roderick Dhu is portrayed as 'the terror of Loch Lomond's side' (canto II, stanza XI, line 14). Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lomond, Loch (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Vennachar by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Vennachar, Perthshire, and surrounding countryside. Loch Vennachar, Perthshire, figures prominently in both Marmion (1808) and The Lady of the Lake (1810). In canto V of the latter, the wounded Roderick Dhu is carried on horseback from the shores of Loch Vennachar to Stirling Castle. In September 1809, Scott made the same ride himself to verify whether it was possible in the time he planned to allot to it in the poem.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 33)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Vennachar, Loch (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Hawick by W. Warwick after D.O. Hill
Description#1: Depicts the town of Hawick, Scottish Borders, and the surrounding countryside. Hawick appears in Sir Walter Scott's The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'Dimly he view'd the Moat-hill's mound, | Where Druid shades still flitted round; | In Hawick twinkled many a light' (canto I, stanza XXV, lines 9-11). It is described in detail in Scott's Border Antiquities of England and Scotland (1814). Hawick is also connected to Scott through the prototype for Old Mortality, Robert Patterson, who was a native of the town.
Source#1: Hogg, J. Tales and Sketches by the Ettrick Shepherd. Vol. VI. Glasgow: Blackie & Son, 1837 (front.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Hawick (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Lubnaig by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Lubnaig, Stirling, and surrounding countryside. Loch Lubnaig appears in Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810): 'Then, trusting not a second look, | In haste he sped him up the brook, | Nor backward glanced, till on the heath | Where Lubnaig's lake supplies the Teith' (canto III, stanza XXII, lines 5-8). Scott had first seen the Loch when travelling to Crieff in September 1796.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 47)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lubnaig, Loch (Scotland)

Title#1: Loch Oich & Invergarry Castle (Inverness-shire): Looking West
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Oich by J. Swan after J. Fleming
Description#1: Depicts Loch Oich, Scottish Highlands, with Invergarry Castle on the far shore. Invergarry Castle was the seat of the MacDonells of Glengarry until it was burned down in 1746 following the battle of Culloden. The fugitive Prince Charles Edward Stuart is reputed to have taken refuge in the castle, an episode which Scott relates in Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1830). In The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818), the Jacobite Captain of Knockdunder recalls being garrisoned in the Castle during the '45.
Source#1: Leighton, J.M. The Lakes of Scotland: A Series of Views. Glasgow: J. Swan, 1834 (facing p. 141)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Oich, Loch (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Title#1: Loch Skene: A Retreat of the Covenanters
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Skene by W. Forrest after D.O. Hill
Description#1: Depicts a coventicle (an illegal open air religious service) on the banks of Loch Skeen (or Skene), Dumfries and Galloway. Scott describes the 'savage scene [...] which frowns round dark Loch-skene' in the Introduction to Canto II of Marmion (1808), lines 237-63. The same Moffatdale landscape, a refuge for the Covenanters, is also invoked in Old Mortality (1816). Scott first visited Moffatdale in 1805 in the company of James Skene of Rubislaw, Sir Adam Fergusson and James Hogg.
Source#1: Hogg, J. Tales and Sketches by the Ettrick Shepherd. Vol. II. Glasgow: Blackie & Son, 1837 (t.p.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Skene, Loch (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Title#1: The Heart of London: From Tower Bridge
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of London by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Depicts a view of London from the Tower Bridge, including the Thames River and St. Paul's Cathedral. Sir Walter Scott visited London on several occasions, and the city appears in a number of his novels, most notably The Fortunes of Nigel (1822) and Peveril of the Peak (1823).
Source#1: Jerrold, W. The Heart of London. London: Blackie and Son, 1924 (front.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts London (England)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of the Tower of London by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Depicts a guard at the Gateway to the Tower of London. The eponymous hero of Sir Walter Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel (1822) is imprisoned on a charge of treason in the Tower of London, as are Julian and Sir Geoffrey Peveril in Peveril of the Peak (1823).
Source#1: Jerrold, W. The Heart of London. London: Blackie and Son, 1924.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Tower of London (London, England)

Title#1: Looking West up Fleet Street to the Law Courts
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of Fleet Street by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Depicts a view down Fleet Street, London, to the Royal Courts of Justice. Fleet Street is the location for the shop of David Ramsay, the watchmaker, in Sir Walter Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel (1822). Nigel's retainer Richie Moniplies is wounded in an affray on Fleet Street in the first chapter of the novel.
Source#1: Jerrold, W. The Heart of London. London: Blackie and Son, 1924
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Fleet Street (London, England)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of Temple Church by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Depicts the Gothic arches of the porch of Temple Church, London. In chapter 14 of The Fortunes of Nigel (1822), Nigel Olifaunt compares the face of his retainer Richie Moniplies to one of the gargoyles of the 12th-century Temple Church. There is also a reference in chapter 35 of Ivanhoe (1819), where the Grand Master of the Knights Templar declares: 'Not one object in England hath met mine eye which it could rest upon with pleasure, save the tombs of our brethren, beneath the massive roof of our Temple Church in yonder proud capital.' The Temple Church was built by the Knights Templar in the 12th century as their English headquarters.
Source#1: Jerrold, W. The Heart of London. London: Blackie and Son, 1924
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Temple Church (London, England)

Title#1: Melrose from the East: The Tweed in the Foreground
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Melrose by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts a view of the Melrose countryside, Scottish Borders, with the River Tweed in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott's home of Abbotsford lay only a few miles west of the town of Melrose in the Scottish Borders. Melrose is set in the heart of the 'Scott Country', and is featured in many of his works, most notably The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) and, under the guise of 'Kennaquhair', in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820). Town and abbey are described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927 (facing p.67)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Melrose (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a watercolour painting of Melrose by S. Palmer
Description#1: Depicts the countryside of Melrose, Scottish Borders, with the Abbey in the background. Sir Walter Scott's home of Abbotsford lay only a few miles west of the town of Melrose in the Scottish Borders. Melrose is set in the heart of the 'Scott Country', and is featured in many of his works, most notably The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) and, under the guise of 'Kennaquhair', in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820). Town and abbey are described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).
Source#1: Smith, W., et al. Scott Country: Water-Colours. London: A. & C. Black, 1932 (plate 4)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Melrose (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the ruins of Melrose Abbey by E. Finden after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts the Gothic vaulted arches of the ruins of Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott coordinated the restoration of Melrose Abbey in 1822. The Abbey features in many of Scott's works, most famously The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'If thou would'st view fair Melrose aright, | Go visit it by the pale moonlight [...] | Then view St. David's ruin'd pile; | And, home returning, soothly swear, | Was never scene so sad and fair!' (canto II, stanza I, lines 1-2, 16-18). The religious house of Kennaquhair in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) is based on the Abbey, and it is described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose Abbey
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

The Abbey features in many of Scott's works, most famously The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'If thou would'st view fair Melrose aright, | Go visit it by the pale moonlight [...] | Then view St. David's ruin'd pile; | And, home returning, soothly swear, | Was never scene so sad and fair!' (canto II, stanza I, lines 1-2, 16-18). The religious house of Kennaquhair in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) is based on the Abbey, and it is described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814). The original painting by Samuel Prout (1783-1852) was made before 1830.
Source#1: Martin, J. Landscape Illustrations of the Waverley Novels. Vol. II. London: Charles Tilt, 1832 (facing p.46)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose Abbey
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Title#1: [Facsimile of a painting of Melrose Abbey by Thomas Scott]
Description#1: Depicts tourists at the ruins of Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott coordinated the restoration of Melrose Abbey in 1822. The Abbey features in many of Scott's works, most famously The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'If thou would'st view fair Melrose aright, | Go visit it by the pale moonlight [...] | Then view St. David's ruin'd pile; | And, home returning, soothly swear, | Was never scene so sad and fair!' (canto II, stanza I, lines 1-2, 16-18). The religious house of Kennaquhair in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) is based on the Abbey, and it is described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).
Source#1: Crockett, W.S. Footsteps of Scott. Edinburgh: T.N. Foulis, 1908 (facing p. 164)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose Abbey
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Engraving by T. Higham after G. Cattermole of a scene from Scott's novel The Abbot
Description#1: Depicts Magdalen and Roland Graeme visiting Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders, after it has been sacked by the Reformers (The Abbot, ch. 8). Kennaquhair Abbey in Scott's novels The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) is generally thought to be based on Melrose Abbey. This engraving illustrates a scene from chapter 13 of The Abbot: 'Magdalen and Roland remained alone in that great vaulted space... and in the pell-mell havoc, the tombs of warriors and of princes had been included in the demolition of the idolatrous shrines. Lances and swords of antique size, which had hung over the tombs of mighty warriors of former days, lay now strewed among relics.' The engraving was first published in the first edition of Leitch Ritchie's Scott and Scotland (1835).
Source#1: Stevens, H.I. & A. Scott and Scotland, or, Historical and Romantic Illustrations of Scottish Story. London: H.I. & A. Stevens, 1845 (facing p.107)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose Abbey

Title#1: Neidpath Castle on the Tweed, Peebleshire
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a watercolour painting of Neidpath Castle by S. Palmer
Description#1: Depicts Neidpath Castle, Scottish Borders, on a bluff overlooking the River Tweed. Sir Walter Scott's poem, 'The Maid of Neidpath', was published in William Whyte's A Collection of Scottish Airs (1806-07): 'Disease had been in Mary's bower | And slow decay from mourning, | Though now she sits on Neidpath's tower | To watch her Love's returning' (lines 5-8). Neidpath, near Peebles, is a 14th-century castle converted into a 17th-century tower house. At the turn of the 19th century, it was home to Scott's close friend Adam Ferguson. Neidpath Castle has also been suggested as the model for Saint Ronan's Castle as described in chapter I of Saint Ronan's Well (1823).
Source#1: Smith, W., et al. Scott Country: Water-Colours. London: A. & C. Black, 1932 (plate 8)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Neidpath Castle (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Newark Castle by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts Newark Castle, Scottish Borders, overlooking the River Yarrow. In Sir Walter Scott's The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), the minstrel receives hospitality from the Duchess of Buccleuch at Newark Castle and, in return, recites a tale about her ancestors. Scott accompanied William Wordsworth on a visit to the ruined 15th-century castle in September 1831 which inspired Wordsworth's poem 'Yarrow Revisited'.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Newark Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Norham Castle by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts the River Tweed with Norham Castle, Northumberland, in the background. Sir Walter Scott's Marmion (1808) begins with the arrival of Lord Marmion at Norham Castle: 'Day set on Norham's castled steep, | And Tweed's fair river, broad and deep, | And Cheviot's mountains lone: | The battled towers, the donjon keep, | The loophole grates, where captives weep, | The flanking walls that round it sweep, | In yellow lustre shone' (canto I, stanza I, lines 1-7) . Lord Marmion spends the night at Norham then proceeds on a mission to the Scottish Court.
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927 (facing p. 48)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Norham Castle
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Title#1: Entrance to the Peak Cavern, Derbyshire
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Peak Cavern by E. Finden after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts cottages within the entrance of Peak Cavern, Derbyshire, and villagers making ropes. The hero of Sir Walter Scott's novel, Peveril of the Peak, is the descendant of the Norman knight William Peveril who built a castle overhanging the Peak Cavern or Devil's Cavern in Derbyshire. Peak Cavern has the largest natural cave entrance in the British Isles. A village was established within the entrance whose inhabitants made ropes for the local lead mines.
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Peak Cavern (England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Preston, Lancashire by E. Finden after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts a view of the windmills of the city of Preston, Lancashire. The Battle of Preston (1715), in which the Jacobites were defeated by the Hanoverian army, features in a number of Scott's works. In Waverley (1814), Sir Everard Waverley befriends the Baron of Bradwardine when the latter is taken prisoner after the battle (ch. 6). In Rob Roy (1817), Frank Osbaldistone's uncle Sir Hildebrand and cousin John are taken prisoner and his cousin Wilfred killed in the engagement (ch. 37). In The Black Dwarf (1816), Sir Frederick Langley is also taken captive after the battle and subsequently executed. The Jacobite campaign of 1715 is discussed in depth in Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1830).
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Preston (Lancashire, England)
Subject Event#1$2: Preston, Battle of, Preston, Lancashire, England, 1715
Related Work Title#4: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of a street in Preston, Lancashire, by E. Finden after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts the Church of St John the Evangelist in Preston, Lancashire, with a view of Church Street and Fishergate. The Battle of Preston (1715), in which the Jacobites were defeated by the Hanoverian army, features in a number of Scott's works. In Waverley (1814), Sir Everard Waverley befriends the Baron of Bradwardine when the latter is taken prisoner after the battle (ch. 6). In Rob Roy (1817), Frank Osbaldistone's uncle Sir Hildebrand and cousin John are taken prisoner and his cousin Wilfred killed in the engagement (ch. 37). In The Black Dwarf (1816), Sir Frederick Langley is also taken captive after the battle and subsequently executed. The Jacobite campaign of 1715 is discussed in depth in Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1830). The church building depicted in this engraving was demolished in 1853 and a new church, Preston Minster, was built on the original foundations.
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Preston (Lancashire, England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Roslin Castle by W. Forrest after D.O. Hill
Description#1: Depicts two female figures by the banks of the River Esk with Rosslyn Castle, Midlothian, in the background. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Castle is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'O'er Roslin all that dreary night, | A wondrous blaze was seen to gleam; | 'Twas broader than the watch-fire's light, | And redder than the bright moon-beam' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 25-28). The castle, a ruined 14th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).
Source#1: Hogg, J. Tales and Sketches by the Ettrick Shepherd. Vol. III. Glasgow: Blackie & Son, 1837 (front.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Rosslyn Castle (Roslin, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Roslin Chapel by an unattributed artist
Description#1: Depicts the interior of the south-east end of Rosslyn Chapel, Midlothian. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Chapel is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'Seem'd all on fire that chapel proud, | Where Roslin's chiefs uncoffin'd lie... | Seem'd all on fire within, around, | Deep sacristy and altar's pale; | Shone every pillar foliage-bound, | And glimmer'd all the dead men's mail' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 33-40). The chapel, a 15th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and is thought to have provided the model for the convent of Engaddi in The Talisman (1825). Its architecture inspired the rich moulded ceiling of the library at Scott's home of Abbotsford.
Source#1: Chambers, R. The Picture of Scotland. Vol. II. Edinburgh: W. Tait and Adam & Charles Black, 1834 (facing p. 119)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Rosslyn Chapel (Roslin, Scotland)
