Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of Roxburgh Castle by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Depicts the River Teviot with the ruins of Roxburgh Castle, Scottish Borders, in the background. In his unfinished Autobiography (1808), Scott lists the 'distant vestiges of Roxburgh Castle' among the sights which make Kelso 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Roxburgh Castle is a ruined 11th-century royal residence which repeatedly changed hands during the Wars of Independence. Scott relates the tale of its daring capture by Sir James Douglas (the 'Black Douglas') in 1313 in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828). There are further brief mentions of the castle in The Monastery (1820) and The Talisman (1825). The entrance hall at Abbotsford boasts two cannonballs supposed to have been used in the siege of Roxburgh Castle in 1460.
Source#1: Geddie, J. The Scott Country. London: Blackie & Son, 1922 (facing p.16)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Roxburgh Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Roxburgh Castle by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts the River Teviot with the ruins of Roxburgh Castle, Scottish Borders, in the background. In his unfinished Autobiography (1808), Scott lists the 'distant vestiges of Roxburgh Castle' among the sights which make Kelso 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Roxburgh Castle is a ruined 11th-century royal residence which repeatedly changed hands during the Wars of Independence. Scott relates the tale of its daring capture by Sir James Douglas (the 'Black Douglas') in 1313 in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828). The entrance hall at Abbotsford boasts two cannonballs supposed to have been used in the siege of Roxburgh Castle in 1460. Sir Walter Scott described Kelso in his unfinished Autobiography (1808) as 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Scott spent many summers in Kelso at his uncle Captain Robert Scott's house of Rosebank, which Scott inherited in 1804.

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the village of Moffat by W. Forrest after D. O. Hill
Description#1: Depicts a group camped on a hillside overlooking the village of Moffat, Dumfries and Galloway, and surrounding countryside. Much of the scenery for Sir Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816) was derived from a visit Scott made in 1805 to the region around Moffat, Dumfriesshire, with James Skene of Rubislaw, Sir Adam Ferguson and James Hogg. Moffatdale provided refuge for many Covenanters during the 'Killing Times'.
Source#1: Hogg, J. Tales and Sketches by the Ettrick Shepherd. Vol. IV. Glasgow: Blackie & Son, 1837 (t.p.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Moffat (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of St. Mary's Loch by W. Miller after P. Paton
Description#1: Depicts a man and a woman by the banks of St. Mary's Loch, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott most famously describes St. Mary's Loch in Marmion (1808): 'Oft in my mind such thoughts awake, | By lone Saint Mary's silent lake; | Thou know'st it well,---nor fen, nor sedge, | Pollute the pure lake's crystal edge; | Abrupt and sheer, the mountains sink | At once upon the level brink; | And just a trace of silver sand | Marks where the water meets the land' (Introduction to Canto Second, lines 146-153). Scott made many excursions to the loch, situated near Moffat in the Scottish Borders. The surrounding landscape (Moffatdale) is featured in Old Mortality (1816).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Waverley Novels: St. Ronan's Well. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1877
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings St Mary's Loch (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the town of Selkirk by W. Miller after P. Paton
Description#1: Depicts the town of Selkirk, Scottish Borders, and surrounding countryside. On 16 December 1799 Sir Walter Scott was appointed Sheriff Depute of Selkirkshire, a post which he held until his death in 1832. The post required Scott to reside in the county for part of the year, in order to perform his duties at Selkirk Sheriff Court. Initially Scott stayed at Clovenfords Inn, near Galashiels, but eventually in 1804 leased the property of Ashestiel. Selkirk is often thought to be the model for Middlemass, the Border town portrayed in the opening chapters of 'The Surgeon's Daughter' (1827).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Surgeon's Daughter, and, Castle Dangerous. [Library Edition]. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1877
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Selkirk (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the city of Sheffield by E. Finden after W. Westall
Description#1: Depicts the River Don with the city of Sheffield, South Yorkshire, in the background. Sir Walter Scott's Ivanhoe (1819) is largely set in a tract of forest lying between the cities of Doncaster and Sheffield in South Yorkshire. The disguised hero accompanies the Jewish financier Isaac of York as far as Sheffield in chapter 6 of the novel. Scott passed through Sheffield when returning to Edinburgh from London in May 1807. His son Walter was stationed there in 1830.
Source#1: Moule, T. The Landscape Album, or, Great Britain Illustrated: In a Series of Sixty Views. London: Charles Tilt, 1832
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Sheffield (England)

Title#1: [Facsimile of a painting of Smailholm Tower by Thomas Scott]
Description#1: Depicts Smailholm Tower (Scottish Borders) atop Sandyknowe Crag with a horse and rider in the foreground. Smailholm Tower, near Kelso, is a fifteenth-century peel tower which was the home of Sir Walter Scott's ancestors the Scotts of Harden. The tower is situated on Sandyknowe Crag, above Sandyknowe Farm where Walter Scott spent much of his early childhood at the home of his paternal grandparents: 'Then rise those crags, that mountain tower, | Which charm'd my fancy's wakening hour.' (Marmion, Introduction to Canto Third, lines 158-59). Besides celebrating Smailholm Tower in Marmion, Scott set his ballad 'The Eve of St John' (1799) there and is thought to have modelled Avenel Castle in The Monastery and the Abbot (both 1820) on the tower.
Source#1: Crockett, W.S. Footsteps of Scott. Edinburgh: T.N. Foulis, 1908 (facing p. 22)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Smailholm Tower (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a watercolour painting of Smailholm Tower by W. Smith
Description#1: Depicts Smailholm Tower (Scottish Borders) atop Sandyknowe Crag. Smailholm (or Sandyknowe) Tower, near Kelso, is a fifteenth-century peel tower which was the home of Sir Walter Scott's ancestors the Scotts of Harden. The tower is situated on Sandyknowe Crag, above Sandyknowe Farm where Walter Scott spent much of his early childhood at the home of his paternal grandparents: 'Then rise those crags, that mountain tower, | Which charm'd my fancy's wakening hour.' (Marmion, Introduction to Canto Third, lines 158-59). Besides celebrating Smailholm Tower in Marmion, Scott set his ballad 'The Eve of St John' (1799) there and is thought to have modelled Avenel Castle in The Monastery and the Abbot (both 1820) on the tower.
Source#1: Smith, W., et al. Scott Country: Water-Colours. London: A. & C. Black, 1932 (plate 4)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Smailholm Tower (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of Smailholm Tower by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Depicts Smailholm Tower (Scottish Borders) atop Sandyknowe Crag. Smailholm Tower, near Kelso, is a fifteenth-century peel tower which was the home of Sir Walter Scott's ancestors the Scotts of Harden. The tower is situated on Sandyknowe Crag, above Sandyknowe Farm where Walter Scott spent much of his early childhood at the home of his paternal grandparents: 'Then rise those crags, that mountain tower, | Which charm'd my fancy's wakening hour.' (Marmion, Introduction to Canto Third, lines 158-59). Besides celebrating Smailholm Tower in Marmion, Scott set his ballad 'The Eve of St John' (1799) there and is thought to have modelled Avenel Castle in The Monastery and the Abbot (both 1820) on the tower.
Source#1: Geddie, J. The Scott Country. London: Blackie & Son, 1922 (facing p. 12)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Smailholm Tower (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Fingal's Cave at Staffa by G. Aikman after T. Allom
Description#1: Depicts the basalt columns of Fingal's Cave, Staffa, Inner Hebrides. Walter Scott visited Fingal's Cave in 1810: 'It exceeded in my mind every description I had heard of it [...] the appearance of the cavern composed entirely of basaltic pillars as high as the roof of a cathedral and running deep into the rock, eternally swept by a deep and swelling sea, and paved as it were with ruddy marble baffles all description' (Letter to Joanna Baillie, July 19, 1810). He subsequently described the cave in The Lord of the Isles (1815), canto IV, stanza X: 'that wondrous dome, | Where, as to shame the temples deck'd | By skill of earthly architect, | Nature herself, it seem'd, would raise | A Minster to her Maker's praise!' (lines 13-17).
Source#1: Black's Picturesque Tourist of Scotland. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1840
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Fingal's Cave (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Stirling Castle by W. Wallis after T. Allom
Description#1: Depicts the ramparts of Stirling Castle with soldiers in Highland dress. The concluding scenes of Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810) take place in 'the bulwark of the North, | Grey Stirling, with her towers and town' (canto V, stanza XVIII, lines 34-35). The castle features in a number of Scott's works, most notably Waverley, ch. 38, where the Jacobite party guarding Edward Waverley exchange fire with the castle's garrison. The stained glass portraits of Scottish kings in the armoury window at Scott's home of Abbotsford are based on carvings in the presence chamber of Stirling Castle.
Source#1: The Complete Works of Robert Burns and the Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott. Vol. II. Glasgow: William Collins, 1867 (facing p. 40)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Stirling Castle (Stirling, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Traquair by D. Wilson after D.O. Hill
Description#1: Depicts a shepherd with his flock in the countryside of Traquair, Scottish Borders. Traquair House, near Peebles, parts of which date from the twelfth century, is considered to be the oldest continually inhabited house in Scotland. It was one of Walter Scott's favourite haunts and has been suggested as a model for the castles of Tully Veolan in Waverley (1814) and Ellieslaw in The Black Dwarf (1816). The area around Traquair and Innerleithen is thought to be the setting for Scott's Saint Ronan's Well (1823).
Source#1: Hogg, J. Tales and Sketches by the Ettrick Shepherd. Vol. VI. Glasgow: Blackie & Son,1837 (t.p.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Traquair (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a painting of Traquair House by E.W. Haslehust
Description#1: Depicts Traquair House, Scottish Borders, behind closed gates. Traquair House, near Peebles, parts of which date from the twelfth century, is considered to be the oldest continually inhabited house in Scotland. It was one of Walter Scott's favourite haunts and has been suggested as a model for the castles of Tully-Veolan in Waverley (1814) and Ellieslaw in The Black Dwarf (1816).
Source#1: Geddie, J. The Scott Country. London: Blackie & Son, 1922 (facing p. 48)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Traquair House (Innerleithen, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of the Bear Gates, Traquair House by G. Home
Description#1: Depicts the closed Bear Gates of Traquair House, Scottish Borders. Traquair House, near Peebles, parts of which date from the twelfth century, is considered to be the oldest continually inhabited house in Scotland. It was one of Walter Scott's favourite haunts and has been suggested as a model for the castles of Tully-Veolan in Waverley (1814) and Ellieslaw in The Black Dwarf (1816). In particular, the recurring bear motif at Tully-Veolan is thought to have been suggested by the Bear Gates of Traquair. According to tradition, the Bear Gates have been closed ever since the 5th Earl of Traquair bid farewell to Prince Charles Edward Stuart and swore that the gates would not re-open until the Stuart monarchy was restored.
Source#1: Baikie, J. The Charm of the Scott Country. London: A. & C. Black, 1927 (facing p. 3)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Traquair House (Innerleithen, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Turnberry Castle by J. Stewart after P. Gibson
Description#1: Depicts Turnberry Castle, Ayrshire, with Ailsa Craig in the background. Edith, the heroine of Walter Scott's The Lord of the Isles (1815), is captured by the English at Turnberry Castle, the ancestral home and birthplace of Robert the Bruce. The Bruce lays siege to the castle, rescues Edith, and goes on to regain most of Scotland. Scott had never visited Turnberry Castle so, while working on The Lord of the Isles in 1814, requested and obtained local information from his friend the Gallowegian antiquarian Joseph Train. The castle was demolished by the Bruce himself in 1310 to prevent it from falling into English hands. It was never rebuilt.
Source#1: Forsyth, R. The Beauties of Scotland. Vol. II. Edinburgh: Printed for Thomson Bonar and John Brown, 1805 (facing p. 483)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Turnberry Castle (Scotland)

Title#1: [Facsimile of a painting of Yarrow by Thomas Scott]
Description#1: Depicts a seated woman with dog in the Yarrow countryside, Scottish Borders. The Yarrow Valley (or Yarrowdale) was one of the favourite haunts of Walter Scott and fertile ground for gathering songs for his Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-03). The district is particularly celebrated in The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), where the aging minstrel sings: 'By Yarrow's stream still let me stray, | Though none should guide my feeble way' (canto VI, stanza II, lines 14-15).
Source#1: Crockett, W.S. Footsteps of Scott. Edinburgh: T.N. Foulis, 1908 (facing p. 44)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Yarrow (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Title#1: Henry IV: From the Original Picture by Porbus [sic] in the Collection of the MusÌ©e Royal, Paris
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Henri IV by T. Woolnoth after F. Pourbus
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Henri IV, King of France (1553-1610). In ch. 22 of Sir Walter Scott's novel Woodstock (1826), the heroine Alice Lee hopes that the exiled Charles II will unite all the kingly virtues of his grandfather Henri IV of France: his 'chivalrous courage', 'warlike skill', 'all his benevolence, love of his people, patience even of unpleasing advice, sacrifice of his own wishes and pleasures to the commonweal'. While in Paris in 1815, Walter Scott spent time in the King's Library reading letters of Henri IV to his mistress Gabrielle d'EstrÌ©es. The original portrait by Frans Pourbus the Younger was painted between 1605 and 1610.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets. Vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co, 1853
Subject#1: France - Kings and rulers - Portraits Henri IV, King of France, 1553-1610 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of Sir John Cam Hobhouse by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Sketch of British statesman John Cam Hobhouse (1786-1869) addressing an election crowd, with facsimile of signature. John Cam Hobhouse, Lord Broughton, was one of Lord Byron's closest friends. Such was his loyalty to the poet that he came to be known as 'Byron's bulldog'. Hobhouse corresponded with Scott in 1826 and 1828 concerning a monument to Byron to which Scott subscribed. This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-38, under the title of 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p.190)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Broughton, John Cam Hobhouse, Baron, 1786-1869 - Portraits

Title#1: Hogarth: From the Original Picture by Himself in the National Gallery
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of William Hogarth by J. Mollison after W. Hogarth
Description#1: Engraved self-portrait of English artist William Hogarth (1697-1764) with pug dog. Walter Scott owned a Hogarth self-portrait (not that engraved here) which he displayed in the dining room at Abbotsford. Scott consistently cited Hogarth as the supreme artist. In chapter 1 of The Bride of Lammermoor (1819), the artist Dick Tinto wonders why he should shun the name of 'an out-of-doors artist' when Hogarth himself 'has introduced himself in that character in one of his best engravings'. The engraving by James Mollison was made from a self-portrait painted in 1745.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets. Vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co, 1853
Subject#1: Painters - England - Portraits Hogarth, William, 1697-1764 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of James Hogg by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Sketch of Scottish author James Hogg (1770-1835) draped in a plaid, with facsimile of signature. Sir Walter Scott met the poet and novelist James Hogg while researching material for Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1803) and became his lifelong friend and patron. Following Scott's death, Hogg published The Domestic Manners and Private Life of Sir Walter Scott (1834). The 'Chaldee Manuscript' was a satire on Edinburgh's literary scene published in Blackwood's Magazine (1817). This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title of 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'. The portrait is signed 'A. Croquis', an alias occasionally used by Maclise.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p.54)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Hogg, James, 1770-1835 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of James Hogg by W.T. Fry after W. Nicholson
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Scottish author James Hogg (1770-1835), with decorated border. Sir Walter Scott met the poet and novelist James Hogg, known as the 'Ettrick Shepherd', while researching material for Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1803)and became his lifelong friend and patron. Following Scott's death, Hogg published The Domestic Manners and Private Life of Sir Walter Scott (1834). The original portrait by Nicholson was made in 1817.
Source#1: Percy, S., and R. Percy. The Percy Anecdotes Original and Select. London: George Berger, 1822
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Hogg, James, 1770-1835 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of James Hogg by G. J. Stodart after J. W. Gordon
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Scottish author James Hogg (1770-1835). Sir Walter Scott met the poet and novelist James Hogg, known as the 'Ettrick Shepherd', while researching material for Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1803) and became remained his lifelong friend and patron. Following Scott's death, Hogg published The Domestic Manners and Private Life of Sir Walter Scott (1834). The original portrait by John Watson Gordon was painted in 1830. It is part of the collection of the Scottish National Portrait Gallery.
Source#1: Wilson, J.G. The Poets and Poetry of Scotland. London: Blackie & Son, 1876-77
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Hogg, James, 1770-1835 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of James Hogg by W. H. Lizars after J. G. Lockhart
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Scottish author James Hogg (1770-1835). Sir Walter Scott met the poet and novelist James Hogg, known as the 'Ettrick Shepherd', while researching material for Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-03). Scott remained his lifelong friend and patron. Following Scott's death, Hogg published The Domestic Manners and Private Life of Sir Walter Scott (1834). This portrait was engraved by William Home Lizars, son of Daniel Lizars. Although Daniel Lizars died in 1812, the family occasionally continued to use W&D Lizars as their signature. The artist signature P.M. refers to Peter Morris, the alias adopted by J. G. Lockhart in Peter's Letters to his Kinfolk (1819).
Source#1: Lockhart, J. G. Peter's Letters to His Kinsfolk. Vol. III. Edinburgh: William Blackwood, 1819 (facing p. 141)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Hogg, James, 1770-1835 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of Theodore Hook by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Sketch of English author Theodore Hook (1788-1841), with facsimile of signature. Walter Scott expressed admiration for Theodore Hook's 'Sayings and Doings' and offered support during Hook's imprisonment as a state debtor. It was largely through Scott's offices that Hook was appointed editor of the Tory newspaper John Bull in 1820. However, Scott also warned J. G. Lockhart that too much social contact with such a 'raffish' fellow could damage Lockhart's reputation (Letters of 15 October and November 1825). This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-38, under the title of 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 126)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Hook, Theodore Edward, 1788-1841 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Photogravure of a portrait of Charles Hope, Lord Granton by J. W. Gordon
Description#1: Portrait of Charles Hope of Granton (1763-1851) as Lord President of the Court of Session. Charles Hope, Lord Granton was Lord Justice Clerk (1804-1811) and later Lord President of the Court of Session (1811-1841) while Sir Walter Scott was Clerk of Session. The Hopes were also social acquaintances of the Scotts. The original portrait was painted in 1832 by John Watson Gordon.
Source#1: The History of the Speculative Society, 1764-1904. Edinburgh: Printed for the Society by T. and A. Constable, 1905 (facing p. 96)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Granton, Charles Hope, Lord, 1763-1851 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a portrait of Francis Horner by H. Raeburn
Description#1: Portrait of English politician and economist Francis Horner (1778-1817). Francis Horner was one of the founders of the Edinburgh Review, to which Scott contributed reviews between 1803 and 1806 before withdrawing for political reasons. Scott found Horner's writings solemn and humourless: 'I will not admire your Horner: he always puts me in mind of Obadiah's bull, who, although, as Father Shandy observed, he never produced a calf, went through his business with such a grave demeanour, that he always maintained his credit in the parish!' (quoted in J. G. Lockhart, Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.). Horner was also a founding member with Scott of the influential literary and social 'Friday Club' in 1803. The original portrait by Henry Raeburn was painted in 1812.
Source#1: The History of the Speculative Society, 1764-1904. Edinburgh: Printed for the Society by T. and A. Constable, 1905
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Horner, Francis, 1778-1817 - Portraits

Title#1: David Hume: From a Print by A. Smith after a Picture by Allan Ramsay
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of David Hume by W. Holl after A. Smith after A. Ramsay
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the Scottish philosopher, David Hume (1711-1776). Scott's concept of history owes much to that developed by David Hume. Scott jokingly suggested publishing a complete poetic works of David Hume with illustrations and explanatory texts - there is only one short doggerel poem, scratched in the glass at an inn at Carlisle, which is accredited to Hume (letter to J.B.S. Morritt, 2 October 1815). This portrait was engraved by William Holl the Elder from an earlier engraving by Anker Smith published in 1806. The original portrait by Allan Ramsay was painted in 1766.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets. Vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co, 1853
Subject#1: Philosophers - Scotland - Portraits Hume, David, 1711-1776 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of a portrait of Baron Hume by H. Raeburn
Description#1: Black and white facsimile of a portrait of David Hume (1757-1838) as Baron of the Exchequer. Walter Scott enjoyed the University lectures of his Scots Law professor, David Hume (nephew and heir to the philosopher of the same name). In his unfinished 'Autobiography' (1808), Scott praised Hume's 'penetration and clearness of conception' and hailed him as an 'architect' to the law of Scotland. In 1811, Scott and Hume were rival candidates for the post of Principal Clerk to the Court of Session. Hume was offered the post and irritated Scott by vacillating for some time before accepting. Nonetheless, Hume remained a valued friend and colleague and was one of the first to guess the identity of the 'Author of Waverley'. The original portrait by Raeburn was commissioned by the Society of Writers to Her Majesty's Signet in 1822. It remains part of the Society's collection.
Source#1: The History of the Speculative Society, 1764-1904. Edinburgh: Printed for the Society by T. and A. Constable, 1905
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Hume, David, 1757-1838 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of Leigh Hunt by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Sketch of English author Leigh Hunt (1784-1859), with facsimile of signature. Scott wrote 'Mr. Leigh Hunt I only know from his writings but these show so much more cleverness than judgement' and considered his Lord Byron and Some of His Contemporaries to be 'injudicious and open to much censure' (letter to Horatio Smith, 1 February 1828). Scott felt that 'having eaten Byrons [sic] salt while he lived Mr Hunt should have spared his memory when he was departed'. In letters of 5 February and 4 March to J. G. Lockhart, he urged his son-in-law to treat the volume severely when reviewing it for the Quarterly Review. Hunt had already offended Scott by satirizing him in his The Feast of the Poets (1815). Writing in his Autobiography (1850), Hunt regretted the offence, wishing that political differences had not prevented him from seeing that Scott was a 'man of a kindly nature'. This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title of 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 132)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Hunt, Leigh, 1784-1859 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of Washington Irving by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Sketch of American author Washington Irving (1783-1859), with facsimile of signature. Walter Scott was an ardent admirer of Washington Irving and his work, particularly Knickerbocker's History of New York. While visiting Scotland, Irving was invited to stay at Abbotsford (30 August-3 September 1817). Irving's recollections of his stay were published in Abbotsford and Newstead Abbey (1835). This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 46)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Irving, Washington, 1783-1859 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Francis Jeffrey by J. G. Lockhart
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the Scottish lawyer and critic Francis Jeffrey (1773-1850). Francis Jeffrey was one of the founders of the Edinburgh Review and responsible for asking his fellow advocate Walter Scott to contribute. The Review flourished with Jeffrey as editor, and he became a powerful and influential critic. Jeffrey reviewed a number of Scott's own works making few concessions to personal friendship. Scott was particularly hurt by his critique of Marmion (1808), feeling that it might have been couched 'in language rather more civil to a personal friend'. While entertaining the highest regard for Jeffrey's talents, Scott felt he lacked 'the taste for poetry which is essentially necessary to enjoy and of course to criticize it with justice', and specifically 'that enthusiastic feeling which like sun-shine upon a landscape lights up every beauty and palliates if it cannot hide ever defect' (letter to Joanna Baillie, 31 October 1808). The signatures P.M. and W. Wastle refer to Peter Morris and William Wastle, both aliases adopted by Lockhart in his Peter's Letters to His Kinfolk (1819). Lockhart, then, appears to have engraved the print after his own design.
Source#1: Lockhart, J. G. Peter's Letters to His Kinsfolk. Vol. II. Edinburgh: William Blackwood, 1819 (facing p. 59)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Jeffrey, Francis Jeffrey, Lord, 1773-1850 - Portraits

Title#1: The Editor of the Literary Gazette
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of William Jerdan by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Sketch of Scottish journalist William Jerdan (1782-1869), with facsimile of signature. A native of Kelso, William Jerdan was the founder and editor of the Literary Gazette. His father John Jerdan was an early acquaintance of Scott and a schoolfriend of his father and uncle. In his Autobiography (London: A. Hall, Virtue, 1852-1853), Jerdan regrets having offended Scott by his strictures on some of his works. However, in the later years of Scott's life, Jerdan adds, he was 'on most friendly terms' with Scott and 'among the foremost of his acquaintances' when he visited London (vol. IV, pp. 344-45). Jerdan also included a biographical sketch of Scott in his Men I Have Known (1866). Scott's correspondence reveals irritation at Jerdan's habit of inserting premature or erroneous announcements of new publications by Scott. This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title of 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 8)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Jerdan, William, 1782-1869 - Portraits

Title#1: Johnson: From a Picture by Sir J. Reynolds in the Possession of Sir Robert Peel, Bart.
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Samuel Johnson by W. Holl after J. Reynolds
Description#1: Engraved portrait of English author Samuel Johnson (1709-1784). Sir Walter Scott was intimately acquainted with and frequently quoted from the works of Samuel Johnson. He particularly admired Johnson's satirical poems London and The Vanity of Human Wishes. In 1823, Scott edited Johnson's Rasselas for Ballantyne's Novelists Library, and provided a biographical sketch of the author which was subsequently reprinted as one of his Lives of the Novelists. In 1829, Scott supplied J.W. Croker with numerous anecdotes concerning Johnson for his edition of Boswell's Life of Johnson. The original portrait by Joshua Reynolds was painted in 1772. The engraving by William Holl the Elder was first published in 1814.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets. Vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co, 1853
Subject#1: Authors, English - Portraits Johnson, Samuel, 1709-1784 - Portraits

Title#1: Ben Jonson. From a Picture in the Possession of Mr. Knight
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Ben Jonson by E. Scriven after A. Blyenberch
Description#1: Engraved portrait of English poet and playwright, Ben Jonson (1573?-1637). Walter Scott drew liberally on Ben Jonson's comedies when depicting 17th-century London life in his novel The Fortunes of Nigel (1822). Scott considered Jonson 'one of our our neglected classics' and urged the Rev. Edward Forster to prepare a 'handsome and complete' edition of his dramas (letter of 27 October 1805). Scott frequently quoted from Jonson in his published works and correspondence, particularly favouring Every Man in His Humour. The original portrait by Abraham van Blyenberch was painted ca. 1617.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets. Vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co, 1853
Subject#1: Dramatists, English - Portraits Jonson, Ben, 1573?-1637 - Portraits

Title#1: John Knox: From a Picture in the Possession of Lord Somerville
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of John Knox by B. Holl after an unknown artist
Description#1: Engraved portrait of an unidentified 17th-century Scottish divine, once thought to be John Knox (ca. 1514-1572). Scott never portrayed John Knox directly in his fiction, but his 1820 novels The Monastery and The Abbot portray the triumph of the Knox-inspired Reformation in Scotland. Scott's preacher Henry Warden is presented as second only in power and eloquence to Knox. In The Abbot even the Catholic Mary Queen of Scots salutes Knox's power, describing him as 'the ablest and most powerful of heresiarchs' (ch. 25). Scott also described Knox's role in the Reformation in the historical Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828), where Knox is introduced as 'a man of great corage, zeal, and talents' and as the 'bold and inflexible father of the Scottish Reformation'. For each of these works, Knox's own Historie of the Reformation of the Church of Scotland was an important source. The Somerville portrait, whose authenticity was asserted by Thomas Carlyle, is no longer thought to be an image of Knox.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets. Vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co, 1853
Subject#1: Theologians - Scotland - Portraits Knox, John, c.1505-1572 - Portraits
Related Work Title#3: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of Charles Lamb by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Sketch of English essayist Charles Lamb (1775-1834) at his desk, with facsimile of signature. Walter Scott met the essayist Charles Lamb in the London studio of the painter Benjamin Robert Haydon in March 1821. Scott later contributed to Charles Lamb's fundraising efforts for William Godwin, and issued an invitation for Lamb to visit should he ever be in Scotland, 'though I have not forgotten his metropolitan preference of houses to rocks, and citizens to wild rustics and highland men' (Letter to Benjamin Robert Haydon, October 1822). Lamb replied on 29 October 1822, saying that he would be delighted to take up Scott's offer in the unlikely event of his ever visiting Scotland. This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 148)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Lamb, Charles, 1775-1834 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of Dionysius Lardner by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Facsimile of a profile sketch of the Irish scientific writer Dionysius Lardner (1793-1859), with facsimile of signature. Walter Scott contributed a two volume History of Scotland (1830) to the scientific writer Dionysius Lardner's Cabinet Cyclopaedia. Writing in his Journal on 16 July 1829, Scott commented: 'Goodness be with us, what a name!' This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 72)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Lardner, Dionysius, 1793-1859 - Portraits

Title#1: Leibnitz: From a Picture in the Florence Gallery
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz by B. Holl after an unknown artist
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the German philosopher and mathematician, Gottfried Wilhelm Leibnitz (1646-1716). While working on his 1829 novel Anne of Geierstein, Sir Walter Scott asked Robert Cadell to procure a number of works dealing with the Vehmgericht (Invisible Tribunal) in Germany. In a letter of 6 August 1828 he requested a copy of the Scriptores Rerum Brunswicensium, edited by the philosopher and mathematician Leibnitz.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets. Vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co, 1853
Subject#1: Philosophers - Germany - Portraits Leibniz, Gottfried Wilhelm, Freiherr von, 1646-1716 - Portraits

Title#1: [Engraving by W. Holl of a self-portrait by C. R. Leslie]
Description#1: Engraved portrait of the Anglo-American painter Charles Robert Leslie (1794-1859). In September 1824, Leslie visited Abbotsford to paint a portrait of Scott which had been commissioned by the American academic Prof. George Ticknor. Leslie was also a prolific illustrator of Scott's works, contributing to The Novels and Tales of the Author of Waverley (1823), the 'Magnum Opus' edition of the Waverley Novels (1829-32), Charles Heath's Waverley Album (1832) and Portraits of the Principle Female Characters in the Waverley Novels (1833-34). In his General Preface to the 'Magnum Opus' edition of the Waverley Novels, Scott thanks Leslie for his efforts as an illustrator as 'a friend as well as an author'. While at Abbotsford he also painted Scott's factotum Tam Purdie.
Source#1: Leslie, C.R. Autobiographical Recollections. London: J. Murray, 1860 (front.)
Subject#1: Painters - United States - Portraits Leslie, Charles Robert, 1794-1859 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of Edmund Lodge by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Facsimile of sketch of English historian Edmund Lodge (1756-1839) dressed in the robes of office of Norroy, King of Arms. Scott admired the work of Edmund Lodge and frequently drew upon his Illustrations of British History (1791). Lodge's Portraits of Illustrious Personages of Great Britain (1821-35) was prefixed by a letter of recommendation from Scott. The twelfth and final volume of Lodge's portraits contained a biographical sketch of Scott. This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-38, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 206)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Lodge, Edmund, 1756-1839 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Rob Roy by W. Worthington after an original drawing
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Rob Roy MacGregor (1671-1734). The 18th-century Scottish freebooter and folk hero Rob Roy MacGregor is one of the principal characters (but not the protagonist) of Sir Walter Scott's 1817 novel Rob Roy. The 1829 'Magnum Opus' of the novel came complete with a historical introduction to the lives of Rob Roy and his sons, supplemented by letters and other documentation. Scott began collecting anecdotes of Rob Roy when his apprenticeship in his father's legal firm (1786-87) brought him into contact with Highland clients and eventually led to his first trips to the Highlands. One client, in particular, Alexander Stewart of Invernahyle had once fought a duel with Rob Roy. The portrait is engraved by William Henry Worthington from 'an original drawing' quite possibly by Worthington himself.
Subject#1: MacGregor, Rob Roy, 1671-1734 - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Henry Mackenzie by W. H. Lizars after J. G. Lockhart
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Scottish novelist Henry Mackenzie (1745-1831). Scott read Henry Mackenzie's novels in his youth and became his friend and colleague in adulthood. Mackenzie contributed to Walter Scott's Edinburgh Annual Register and both men were trustees of the Edinburgh Theatre. In 1823, Scott edited Mackenzie's fiction for Ballantyne's Novelists Library, and provided a biographical sketch of the author which was subsequently reprinted as one of his Lives of the Novelists. This portrait was engraved by William Home Lizars, son of Daniel Lizars. Although Daniel Lizars died in 1812, the family occasionally continued to use W&D Lizars as their signature. The artist signature P.M. refers to Peter Morris, the alias adopted by J.G. Lockhart in Peter's Letters to his Kinfolk.
Source#1: Lockhart, J. G. Peter's Letters to His Kinsfolk. Vol. II. Edinburgh: William Blackwood. 1819. (facing p.99)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Mackenzie, Henry, 1745-1831 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Henry Mackenzie by J. Horsburgh after C. Smith
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Scottish novelist Henry Mackenzie (1745-1831) at the age of eighty-three. Scott read Henry Mackenzie's novels in his youth and became his friend and colleague in adulthood. Mackenzie contributed to Walter Scott's Edinburgh Annual Register and both men were trustees of the Edinburgh Theatre. In 1823, Scott edited Mackenzie's fiction for Ballantyne's Novelists Library, and provided a biographical sketch of the author which was subsequently reprinted as one of his Lives of the Novelists. The original portrait by Colvin Smith was painted in 1828.
Source#1: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. Edinburgh: Robert Cadell, 1834-1836
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Mackenzie, Henry, 1745-1831 - Portraits

Title#1: [Facsimile reproduction of a self-portrait by Daniel Maclise]
Description#1: Self-portrait of Irish artist Daniel Maclise (1806-1870) with facsimile of signature. During Sir Walter Scott's Irish tour of 1825, the young Daniel Maclise made a surreptitious sketch of the writer, which he subsequently made into a highly popular lithograph. The portrait of Scott was the foundation for a successful artistic career. Maclise moved to London and became celebrated as a portrait artist working primarily in pencil. This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 228)
Subject#1: Artists - Ireland - Portraits Maclise, Daniel, 1806-1870 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Robert Macqueen, Lord Braxfield by W. H. Lizars after H. Raeburn
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of Robert Macqueen, Lord Braxfield (1722-1799) in his judicial robes. When the young Sir Walter Scott's family moved to George Square, Edinburgh, in 1774, one of their neighbours was Robert Macqueen, Lord Braxfield, Lord Justice Clerk and a judge of notorious severity. When studying for the Bar, Scott politically dedicated his thesis to Braxfield, a move which paid off when Braxfield found the young advocate work at the circuit court at Jedburgh. This portrait was engraved by William Home Lizars, son of Daniel Lizars. Although Daniel Lizars died in 1812, the family occasionally continued to use W&D Lizars as their signature.
Source#1: Lockhart, J. G. Peter's Letters to His Kinsfolk. Vol. II. Edinburgh: William Blackwood, 1819. (facing p.112)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Braxfield, Robert Macqueen, Lord, 1722-1799 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Mary, Queen of Scots by G. B. Shaw after J. Thomson after an unknown artist
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Mary, Queen of Scots (1542-1587) in a black velvet robe. The plot of Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) revolves around the imprisonment and escape from Loch Leven Castle, Fife, of Mary, Queen of Scots. Scott also treats her reign at length in his historical works Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828) and The History of Scotland (1830). The following quote from Walter Scott's The Abbot (Chapter 21) is below the engraved portrait: "Her dress was a robe of black velvet, a small ruff open in front, gave a full view of her beautifully formed chin and neck. On her head she wore a small cap of lace, and a transparent white veil hung from her shoulders over the long black robe in, large loose folds." The engraving by George B. Shaw is based on an earlier engraving by James Thomson which appeared in Edmund Lodge's Portraits of Illustrious Personages of Great Britain. The original painting by an unknown artist is known as the Morton or Dalmahoy Portrait.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Abbot. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1877
Subject#1: Scotland - Kings and rulers - Portraits Mary, Queen of Scots, 1542-1587 - Portraits
Related Work Title#3: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Henry Dundas, Lord Melville by an unknown artist probably after J. Reynolds
Description#1: Engraved oval portrait of British statesman Henry Dundas, Lord Melville (1742-1811). Henry Dundas, Lord Melville was a close friend and colleague of William Pitt the Younger, serving as Treasurer of the Navy, Secretary of War and later first Lord of the Admiralty. He also controlled Crown patronage in Scotland and was often described as ipso facto ruler of Scotland. His support was thus essential when Scott applied for and obtained the posts of Sheriff-Depute of Selkirkshire (1799) and Principal Clerk to the Court of Session (1806). Lord and Lady Melville also became close friends of the Scotts. They had been Scott's childhood neighbours in George Square, Edinburgh, and Melville Castle was situated close to Scott's summer home of Lasswade. When Lord Melville was impeached for financial mismanagement in 1804, Scott composed two songs in celebration of his acquittal which were sung by James Ballantyne at a public dinner in Melville's honour. The original portrait from which this engraving was taken is probably that painted by Sir Joshua Reynolds in 1782.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Melville, Henry Dundas, Viscount, 1742-1811 - Portraits

Title#1: John Milton: From a Miniature of the Same Size by Faithorne, Anno 1667; in the Possession of William Falconer Esq.
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of John Milton by T. Woolnoth after W. Faithorne
Description#1: Engraved oval portrait of English poet John Milton (1608-1674). Walter Scott was familiar with the works of Milton from early childhood. Alison Cockburn, a distant relative of Scott's mother, recorded her astonishment at the six-year-old Scott's precocity. When she asked his opinion of Milton, Scott expressed puzzlement that the newly-created Adam should know everything. She satisfied him with the reply that he was created perfect by God (quoted in J. G. Lockhart's Memoir of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.). Later, in the Introduction to Canto I of Marmion (1808), Scott cited Milton among the 'mightiest chiefs of British song' who did not disdain chivalrous or romantic legends: 'They gleam through Spenser's elfin dream, | And mix in Milton's heavenly theme' (lines 273-74).
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets. Vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co, 1853
Subject#1: Poets, English - Portraits Milton, John, 1608-1674 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Title#1: MoliÌ¬re: From the Original Picture of Lebrun's School, in the Collection of the MusÌ©e Royale [sic], Paris
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of MoliÌ¬re by J. Posselwhite after an unknown artist from the School of LeBrun
Description#1: Engraved portrait of French playwright MoliÌ¬re (1622-1673). Scott was a great admirer of the French playwright MoliÌ¬re, from whose comedies he frequently quoted in both his published work and correspondence. In an article on MoliÌ¬re for the Foreign Quarterly Review in 1828, Scott saluted him as 'a complete master of comedy [...] the property, not of that country alone which was honoured with his birth, but of the civilized world'. In 1829, Scott sent his son Charles an edition of MoliÌ¬re's complete works, 'confident I cannot contribute more to your amusement' (letter of 17 November 1829).
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets. Vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co, 1853
Subject#1: Dramatists, French - Portraits MoliÌ¬re, 1622-1673 - Portraits

Title#1: James Montgomery, Author of 'The World Before the Flood', 'Songs of Zion', &c.
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of James Montgomery by F. A. Roberts after T. H. Illidge
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Scottish poet and hymnist James Montgomery (1771-1854) seated at his desk In 1824 James Montgomery asked Walter Scott to contribute a poem for a propaganda work entitled The Chimney-Sweeper's Friend. Scott declined, but a portion of his response was published in the Preface. Here Scott expressed his support for Montgomery's cause, and wrote that he had had the chimneys at Abbotsford made circular and smooth so that they could be cleaned by a 'simple machine', rather than a child (letter to James Montgomery, January 4, 1824). Montgomery, who published a critical account of Marmion in The Critical Review (1808) considered Scott 'an admirable writer' except when he dealt with modern subjects: 'in his magic circle he is inimitable - out of it, a gentleman who writes with ease' (quoted in Helen C. Knight's Life of James Montgomery (1857), p. 133). He was, however, an unconditional admirer of Lockhart's biography of Scott, finding Scott's life 'more intensely attractive to my mind, and in itself even more marvellous, than any of his fictions' (ibid., p. 316). The original painting by T. H. Illidge was made in 1841 and this engraving first appeared in an edition of Robert Chambers's Lives of Illustrious and Distinguished Scotsmen.
Source#1: Wilson, J.G. The Poets and Poetry of Scotland. London: Blackie & Son, 1876-1877
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Montgomery, James, 1771-1854 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of Thomas Moore by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Facsimile of sketch of Irish poet, Thomas Moore (1779-1852), with facsimile of signature. Sir Walter Scott was a friend and admirer of Moore. He secured his collaboration in the Quarterly Review and published some of his verse in his English Minstrelsy (1810). In 1809 Walter Scott wrote an anonymous poetic imitation of Moore for the Edinburgh Annual Register. In good-humoured retaliation, Moore teased Scott in his Intercepted Letters (1813): 'Having quitted the Border to seek new renown | Is coming, by long Quarto stages to Town | And beginning with Rokeby (the job's sure to pay) | Means to do all the Gentlemen's Seats by the way.' Moore visited Scott at Abbotsford in October 1825. Scott, who had been fascinated by Moore's anecdotes of Byron, later supplied him with two letters from Byron for his edition of Letters and Journals of Lord Byron (1830). This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 18)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Moore, Thomas, 1779-1852 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Thomas Moore by J. Heath after a miniature by A. Plimer
Description#1: Engraved oval-framed miniature of Irish poet, Thomas Moore (1779-1852). Sir Walter Scott was a friend and admirer of Moore. He secured his collaboration in the Quarterly Review and published some of his verse in his English Minstrelsy (1810). In 1809 Walter Scott wrote an anonymous poetic imitation of Moore for the Edinburgh Annual Register. In good-humoured retaliation, Moore teased Scott in his Intercepted Letters (1813): 'Having quitted the Border to seek new renown | Is coming, by long Quarto stages to Town | And beginning with Rokeby (the job's sure to pay) | Means to do all the Gentlemen's Seats by the way.' Moore visited Scott at Abbotsford in October 1825. Scott, who had been fascinated by Moore's anecdotes of Byron, later supplied him with two letters from Byron for his edition of Letters and Journals of Lord Byron (1830).
Source#1: Moore, T. Odes of Anacreon. 9th edn. London: Carpenter & Son, 1815
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Moore, Thomas, 1779-1852 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of James Justinian Morier by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Facsimile of a sketch of British diplomat and novelist James Justinian Morier (1780?-1849), with facsimile of signature. Walter Scott submitted a favourable review of Morier's comic novel The Adventures of Hajji Baba of Ispahan in England for the Quarterly Review of January 1829. In the introduction to the 'Magnum Opus' edition of The Talisman, Scott praised Morier for describing 'the manners and vices of the Eastern nations, not only with fidelity, but with the humour of Le Sage and the ludicrous power of Fielding himself'. This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p.90)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Morier, James Justinian, 1780?-1849 - Portraits

Title#1: James Douglas, Earl of Morton, Regent of Scotland
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of James Douglas, Earl of Morton, by G. B. Shaw after an unknown artist
Description#1: Engraved portrait of James Douglas, Earl of Morton (ca. 1516-1581). James Douglas, Earl of Morton, features in Walter Scott's novel The Abbot. He was a principal in the murder of Mary Queen of Scot's secretary David Rizzio and was later involved in the plot against Lord Darnley. He was chief advisor to Regent Murray, becoming Regent after his death, and defeated Mary's forces at Langside after her escape from Lochleven Castle. In The Abbot he is portrayed as 'deep and dark' (ch. 3), the implacable and ruthless enemy of Mary and the Catholic cause. His military and political career are also described in Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Abbot. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, 1877
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Morton, James Douglas, Earl of, d. 1581 - Portraits
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Title#1: Napoleon: From a Picture by F. Gerard in the Possession of the Publisher
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Napoleon Bonaparte by W. Holl after F. Gerard
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Napoleon I (1769-1821) in his coronation robes. Walter Scott published his nine-volume Life of Napoleon Bonaparte in 1827. In a letter to Lady Abercorn (April 21, 1824), he described Napoleon as 'a strange mingled phantom of grandeur and terror and a little meanness withal as ever bestrode the destinies of the world'. The original portrait by Baron FranÌ¤ois GÌ©rard was painted in 1805/06.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: France - Kings and rulers - Portraits Napoleon I, Emperor of the French, 1769-1821 - Portraits
Subject Person#1: Napoleon I, Emperor of the French

Title#1: William Pitt: From a Picture by Hoppner in the Possession of the Publisher
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of William Pitt the Younger by J. Posselwhite after J. Hoppner
Description#1: Engraved portrait of William Pitt the Younger (1759-1806) during his second term as Prime Minister. Walter Scott mourned the recently deceased Pitt the Younger in Marmion (1808): 'The mind that thought for Britain's weal,... | While faith and civil peace are dear, | Grace this cold marble with a tear,--- | He, who preserved them, Pitt, lies here!' (Introduction to Canto First, lines 61, 123-125). Pitt, for his part, was a great admirer of The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) and told Scott's childhood friend William Dundas that 'it would give him pleasure to advance the fortunes of such a writer'. When Scott was told of Pitt's admiration, he wrote that 'I can say without affectation that I would rather have the satisfaction of having been approved by him, though now dead, than by all the living statesmen and nobility in Europe' (letter to Lady Abercorn, 20 September 1806). The original portrait by John Hoppner was painted in 1804/05.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Statesmen - Great Britain - Portraits Pitt, William, 1759-1806 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Title#1: Pope: From the Picture by Hudson, in the Possession of His Grace the Duke of Buckingham
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Alexander Pope by J. Posselwhite after W. Hoare
Description#1: Engraved portrait of English poet and satirist, Alexander Pope (1688-1744). In his unfinished Autobiography (1808), Scott recalls that, as a child of five or six, his 'hours of leisure were usually spent in reading aloud to my mother Pope's translation of Homer, which, excepting a few traditionary ballads, and the songs in Allan Ramsay's Evergreen, was the first poetry which I perused'. According to Lockhart, Scott called Pope a 'true deacon of the craft' and long cherished a plan to publish a complete edition and biography of Pope as he had done for Swift. The original portrait, made c. 1739-84, is by William Hoare rather than Thomas Hudson.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Poets, English - Portraits Pope, Alexander, 1688-1744 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Title#1: Tom Purdie, Wood Forester at Abbotsford
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Tom Purdie by H. Haig after E. Landseer
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott's forester, Tom Purdie (d. 1829), sitting on a rock with a gun in his lap. Tom (or Tam) Purdie was first employed by Scott in 1804 as a shepherd but rose to become his forester, gamekeeper, all-round factotum, and faithful companion. In a Journal entry for 7 January 1826, Scott wrote: 'What a blessing is a man like Tom whom no familiarity can spoil, whom you may scold and praise and joke with, knowing the quality of the man is unalterable in his love and reverence for his master'. Scott was greatly shocked by his sudden death on 29 October 1829, feeling that he had 'lost feet and hands so ready was [Purdie] always to supply the want of either' (letter to Mary Ann Hughes, 1 December 1829). The original portrait by Edwin Landseer was probably made during the artist's stay at Abbotsford in October 1824.
Source#1: Lockhart, J. G. Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. Edinburgh: Adam & Charles Black. 1871.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Purdie, Thomas, 1767-1829 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraving by G. B. Shaw of a self-portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn
Description#1: Engraved self-portrait of Scottish artist, Sir Henry Raeburn (1756-1823). Raeburn, the most celebrated Scottish portraitist of his day, painted four likenesses of Sir Walter Scott: for Archibald Constable in 1808, for Scott himself in 1809, for Lord Montagu, and for Raeburn's own private gallery (both 1823). Scott disliked the first two portraits, lamenting that Raeburn had 'twice made a very chowderheaded [i.e. clumsy- or thick-headed] person of me' (letter to Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry, 15 April 1819). On Raeburn's death, Scott wrote that 'painting is deprived of a votary of genius, our city of an ornament, and society of a most excellent and most innocent member' (letter to Benjamin Robert Haydon, 8 July 1823). The original self-portrait by Henry Raeburn was painted in 1815.
Source#1: Chambers, R. (ed.) A Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen. Glasgow: Blackie, 1835
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Raeburn, Henry, Sir, 1756-1823 - Portraits

Title#1: Raleigh: From a Picture in the Collection of the Duchess of Dorset
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Raleigh by J. Posselwhite after an unknown artist
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Raleigh (ca. 1552-1618), taken from a larger work featuring Raleigh and his son. Raleigh proves himself a friend to the hero Edmund Tressilian in Sir Walter Scott's novel Kenilworth (1821). He is described as knowing 'better than almost any of the courtiers who surrounded her, how to mingle the devotion claimed by the Queen [Elizabeth I] with the gallantry due to her personal beauty'. The original portrait was painted by an unknown artist in 1590.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Raleigh, Walter, Sir, 1552?-1618 - Portraits

Title#1: Lord Rodney: From a Picture by Sir Joshua Reynolds in His Majesty's Collection at St. James's Palace
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Baron George Brydges Rodney by E. Scriven after J. Reynolds
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Admiral Lord Rodney (1718-1792) wearing the riband and star of the Order of the Bath. Sir Walter Scott's older brother Robert served as a midshipman under Lord Rodney in a number of naval engagements against the French in the West Indies. In his unfinished Autobiography (1808), Scott quotes from an elegy by Robert on the imagined loss of his ship written on the eve of Rodney's victory in the Battle of the Saintes (April 9-12, 1782). In a footnote to the Magnum Opus edition of The Pirate (1831), Scott reveals that Captain Cleveland's tales of the haunted isles of the Caribbean (ch. 22) derive from stories told by his brother. The original portrait by Sir Joshua Reynolds was painted in 1789.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Great Britain - Royal Navy - Officers - Portraits Rodney, George Brydges Rodney, Baron, 1719-1792 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Title#1: The Author of 'The Pleasures of Memory'
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of Samuel Rogers by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Facsimile of a sketch of English poet Samuel Rogers (1763-1855), seated in an armchair, with facsimile of signature. Sir Walter Scott met Rogers when visiting London in 1803. He frequently breakfasted with Rogers in subsequent visits to London and corresponded with him. Rogers supported and wrote for the Quarterly Review (the journal that Scott set up to rival the Whig Edinburgh Review) and contributed a lyric to Scott's English Minstrelsy (1810). In a letter to J. G. Lockhart, Scott describes Rogers as 'a man of honour and humanity when out of his poetical character in which he harbours a little too much irritability' (30 May 1826). This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 14)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Rogers, Samuel, 1763-1855 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait Sir John Leslie by J. G. Lockhart
Description#1: Engraved profile portrait of Scottish mathematician and physicist Sir John Leslie (1766-1832) at a podium. In 1808 Sir Walter Scott engaged Leslie, Professor of Mathematics at Edinburgh University, to contribute scientific articles to the Edinburgh Annual Register. Writing to George Ellis, Scott described Leslie as 'a great philosopher, and as abominable an animal as I ever saw', adding that 'he writes, however, with great eloquence, and is an enthusiast in mathematical, chemical, and mineralogical pursuits' (13 December 1808). The original artist is J. G. Lockhart using the pseudonym W. Wastle, a character in his Peter's Letters to his Kinfolk. Lockhart may also be the engraver.
Source#1: Lockhart, J. G. Peter's Letters to His Kinsfolk, vol. I. Edinburgh: William Blackwood, 1819 (facing p. 64)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Leslie, John, Sir, 1766-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Schiller: From a Print by Faustin Anderloni, after a Picture by G. von Kugelgen
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Friedrich Schiller by J. Posselwhite after F. Anderloni after G. von Kugelgen
Description#1: Engraved profile portrait of German author Friedrich Schiller (1759-1805). Beginning in 1792, Walter Scott enthusiastically read the works of Goethe and Schiller with a group of friends at Edinburgh University. Inspired by Alexander Fraser Tytler's translation of Schiller's drama Die RÌ_uber, Scott prepared his own version of Schiller's Die VerschwÌ¦rung des Fiesco zu Genoa. The manuscript is now lost but Scott recalled that he 'used to read it to sobbing and weeping audiences & no wonder, for whatever may be thought of the translation the original is sublime' (letter to Mary Anne Hughes, 13 December 1821). Scott also wrote a play The House of Aspen in imitation of Schiller, which he later dismissed as 'a sort of half-mad German tragedy which I wrote many years ago when my taste was very green and when like the rest of the world I was taken in with the bombast of Schiller' (letter to Lady Abercorn, 17 May 1811). Although he distanced himself from his early love of German theatre, it is widely thought to have exerted a profound influence on his conception of the historical novel. The original portrait by Gerhard von Kugelgen was probably painted in 1808 or 1809. Posselwhite's engraving is derived from an earlier engraving by Faustino Anderloni.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Dramatists, German - Portraits Schiller, Friedrich, 1759-1805 - Portraits

Title#1: Shakspere [sic]: From the Picture in the Possession of His Grace the Duke of Buckingham, at Stowe
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of William Shakespeare by E. Scriven after J. Taylor
Description#1: Engraved portrait of English playwright William Shakespeare (1564-1616). Scott steeped himself in Shakespeare's plays from his earliest youth, and his works abound in allusions to and quotations from them. Shakespeare appears as a character in chapter 17 of Kenilworth (perhaps, with Rokeby, Scott's most Shakespearian work) and is warmly praised by Queen Elizabeth I. A bust of Shakespeare occupies pride of place in Scott's library at Abbotsford. A long-cherished project to publish a popular edition of Shakespeare never came to fruition. The original portrait of William Shakespeare is attributed to John Taylor and is dated c. 1610.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Dramatists, English - Portraits Shakespeare, William, 1564-1616 - Portraits

Title#1: Chas. Kirkpatrick Sharpe, Born 1780. - Died 17 March 1851
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph portrait of Charles Kirkpatrick Sharpe by W.H. McFarlane after D.O. Hill
Description#1: Portrait of Scottish artist, poet, and antiquarian Charles Kirkpatrick Sharpe (1781-1851), seated at a table. Sharpe was a close friend of Sir Walter Scott. He contributed both traditional ballads and original verse to Scott's Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1803), and collaborated on the Annual Register and Quarterly Review. Scott proposed Sharpe for the position of King's Limner after the death of Sir Henry Raeburn in 1823, but it had already been given to David Wilkie. The lithograph by W.H. MacFarlane was taken from a photograph by David Octavius Hill, executed between 1843 and 1851.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Sharpe, Charles Kirkpatrick, 1781-1851 - Portraits

Title#1: Mrs. Siddons: After the Picture by Sir Joshua Reynolds
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sarah Siddons by W. Holl after J. Reynolds
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Welsh actress Sarah Siddons (1755-1831) as the Tragic Muse. Sarah Siddons (nÌ©e Kemble) was considered the finest tragedian and interpreter of Shakespeare of her age. Offstage, Scott found her 'a vain foolish woman spoild [sic] (and no wonder) by unbounded adulation to a degree that deserved praise tasted faint on her palate'. He doubted, however, that he would ever see another actress who came 'within a hundred degrees of what she was in her zenith' (letter to Joanna Baillie, 17 April 1819). He appealed to Mrs Siddons for support of the new patent for the Edinburgh Theatre that would put its management under the control of the Duke of Buccleuch, Walter Scott himself and Henry Mackenzie, among others. Her son Henry Siddons was subsequently appointed manager. The original portrait by Sir Joshua Reynolds was painted in 1784. The engraving by William Holl the Younger was first published in Knight's Portrait Gallery (1835).
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Actresses - England - Portraits Siddons, Sarah, 1755-1831 - Portraits

Title#1: One of the Authors of 'Rejected Addresses'
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of James Smith by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Facsimile of sketch of English comical writer James Smith (1775-1839) seated in a chair, with a facsimile of his signature. In 1812, the brothers James and Horace Smith published Rejected Addresses, or, The New Theatrum Poetarum, a collection of parodies of contemporary poets. Walter Scott was one of the collection's many admirers, declaring 'I have seldom been so much diverted with any thing this long while' (letter to Sarah Smith, 11 December 1812). This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 142)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Smith, James, 1775-1839 - Portraits

Title#1: Lord Chancellor Somers: From a Picture by Sir G. Kneller, in the Possession of the Royal Society
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Baron Somers by T. A. Dean after G. Kneller
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of John Somers, Lord Chancellor of England (1651-1716). Between 1809 and 1815, Sir Walter Scott prepared a revised edition of A Collection of Scarce and Valuable Tracts: On the Most Interesting and Entertaining Subjects: But Chiefly Such as Relate to the History and Constitution of these Kingdoms. Generally known as the Somers Tracts, this collection of historical pamphlets was largely drawn from the library of John Somers, Lord Chancellor of England, 1697-1700. Scott had found the original edition (published 1748-1751) particularly helpful when preparing his edition of the works of Dryden (1808). The original portrait of Baron Somers by Sir Godfrey Kneller was painted ca. 1715-1716.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Statesmen - England - Portraits Somers, John Somers, Baron, 1651-1716 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Collection of Scarce and Valuable Tracts, A

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Robert Southey by R. Page after H. Edridge
Description#1: Engraved portrait of English poet Robert Southey (1774-1843), with decorative border. Scott and Southey first met when Southey visited him at Ashestiel in August 1805. Later in the same month, Scott visited Southey at Keswick, and subsequently made further visits in 1813 and 1825. Southey contributed to a number of Scott's literary projects, including An Apology for Tales of Terror (1799), his English Minstrelsy (1810), the Quarterly Review, and the Edinburgh Annual Register. Scott made repeated attempts to secure a salary for the impecunious Southey. Finally when Scott was offered the position of Poet Laureate in 1813, he declined and instead recommended Southey. The original drawing of Robert Southey by Henry Edridge was made in 1804.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Southey, Robert, 1774-1843 - Portraits

Title#1: [Engraved portrait of Edmund Spenser by James Thomson after an unknown artist]
Description#1: Engraved portrait of a man commonly identified as English poet Edmund Spenser (ca. 1552-1599). As Scott recorded in his unfinished Autobiography (1808), Edmund Spenser's The Fairie Queene was a childhood favourite. There are frequent allusions to and quotations from Spenser's allegory in Scott's fiction, and it provided a model for his poems The Vision of Don Roderick (1811) and The Bridal of Triermain (1813).
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Poets, English - Portraits Spenser, Edmund, 1552?-1599 - Portraits

Title#1: Madame de StaÌÇl: From the Original Picture by F. GÌ©rard, in the Possession of M. de Broglie, at Paris
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Madame de StaÌÇl by E. Scriven after F. GÌ©rard
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of French-Swiss author Madame de StaÌÇl (1766-1817). When Madame de StaÌÇl was rumoured to be planning a visit to Edinburgh in 1814, Scott wrote that he would be 'both curious and pleased' to see a woman of her 'literary reputation' (letter to Sarah Smith, 8 January). Should, however, the visit be cancelled, he would not altogether regret it 'for as I tired of some of her works, I am afraid I should disgrace my taste by tiring of the authoress too' (letter to Joanna Baillie, 10 December 1813). Scott drew on Madame de StaÌÇl's Memoirs when preparing his Life of Napoleon Bonaparte (1827-1828). The original portrait by FranÌ¤ois GÌ©rard was painted in 1818.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries StaÌÇl, Madame de (Anne-Louise-Germaine), 1766-1817 - Portraits

Title#1: Swift: From the Picture, in the Bodleian Library, Oxford
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Jonathan Swift by B. Holl after C. Jervas
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Irish satirist Jonathan Swift (1667-1745). Walter Scott published his 19-volume edition of The Works of Jonathan Swift in 1814, incorporating a lengthy biography of the author. Scott quoted frequently from Swift's works and used his Drapier's Letters (1724) as a model for Letters of Malachi Malagrowther (1826). The original portrait of Swift by Charles Jervas was painted 1709-1710.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. II. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Authors, Irish - Portraits Swift, Jonathan, 1667-1745 - Portraits

Title#1: Tasso: From a Print by Raffaelle Morghen
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Torquato Tasso by R. Hart after R. Morghen after P. Ermini
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Italian poet Torquato Tasso (1544-1595) crowned with laurels. As described in his unfinished Autobiography (1808), Sir Walter Scott first discovered Tasso's Gerusalemme Liberata while at school in Kelso (1783). At Edinburgh University (1786-1790), Scott took evening lessons in Italian in order to read Tasso, Ariosto, and other poets in the original. Edward Waverley, hero of Scott's first novel, shares his creator's love of Italian Romance. Hart's engraving is based on an earlier engraving by Raphael Morghen, which was taken from the original portrait by Pietro Ermini (op. 1799-1820).
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. I. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Poets, Italian - Portraits Tasso, Torquato, 1544-1595 - Portraits

Title#1: James Watt: From a Picture by Sir W. Beechey in the Possession of J. Watt Esq. of Aston Hall
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of James Watt by C.E. Wagstaff after W. Beechey
Description#1: Engraved seated portrait of Scottish engineer James Watt (1736-1819). In the preface to The Monastery, Scott saluted Watt as 'the man whose genius discovered the means of multiplying our national resources to a degree perhaps even beyond his own stupendous powers of calculation and combination; bringing the treasures of the abyss to the summit of the earth--giving the feeble arm of man the momentum of an Afrite--commanding manufactures to arise, as the rod of the prophet produced water in the desert--affording the means of dispensing with that time and tide which wait for no man, and of sailing without that wind which defied the commands and threats of Xerxes himself'. He was, furthermore, 'one of the best and kindest of human beings'. Scott presided at a meeting, at the Waterloo Hotel, Edinburgh, to raise subscriptions for a monument to Watt on 9 July 1824. The original portrait of Watt by Sir William Beechey was painted in 1801.
Source#1: The Portrait Gallery of Distinguished Poets, vol. III. London: Wm. S. Orr & Co., 1853
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Watt, James, 1736-1819 - Portraits

Title#1: Wellington: Copied by Permission of Mr. Graves from an Engraving by Mr. F.C. Lewis of a Drawing by Sir Thomas Lawrence
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of the Duke of Wellington by H. Adlard after F.C. Lewis after T. Lawrence
Description#1: Engraved sketch portrait of the Duke of Wellington (1769-1852), with facsimile of signature. Sir Walter Scott was a great admirer of Wellington's generalship in the Peninsular War. In 1811 he declared Wellington 'the only man we had to trust to' (letter to John B.S. Morritt, 26 April).
