He was 'a man of genius and talent, not deterd [sic] by obstacles, not fettered by prejudices, not immured within the pedantries of his profession but playing the general and the heroe [sic] where most of our military commanders would have exhibited the drill Serjeant or at best the adjutant'. Scott celebrated Wellington's victories in The Vision of Don Roderick (1811) and The Field of Waterloo (1815). Scott met Wellington in Paris in 1815 and gave an account of their interview in Paul's Letters to His Kinsfolk, where the account of the Battle of Waterloo draws largely on Wellington's own account. Later, Wellington supplied notes on Napoleon's Russian campaign for Scott Life of Napoleon Bonaparte (1827-1828). Adlard's engraving is derived from an earlier print by Frederick Christian Lewis (1779-1856). The original drawing by Sir Thomas Lawrence was made c. 1820.
Source#1: Gleig, G.R. The Life of Arthur, First Duke of Wellington. London: Longman, Green, Longman, and Roberts. 1862.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Wellington, Arthur Wellesley, Duke of, 1769-1852 - Portraits

Title#1: John Wilson Esq., Professor of Moral Philosophy
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of John Wilson by J. Horsburgh after R. Lauder
Description#1: Engraved portrait of John Wilson (1785-1854), Scottish poet, essayist, and Professor of Moral Philosophy at Edinburgh University. Along with Scott's son-in-law and biographer J. G. Lockhart and James Hogg, John Wilson was the principal contributor to the satirical Blackwood's Magazine. Scott considered him 'very clever but somewhat whimsical' (letter to Mrs Clephane, 3 December 1818) and thought him a doubtful influence on J.G. Lockhart as he disputed 'with low adversaries' and indulged in biting, personal attacks (letter to Lady Louisa Stuart, 13 April 1826). Scott successfully canvassed for Wilson in his campaign to be elected Professor of Moral Philosophy at Edinburgh University (1820). Scott hoped that the position would give Wilson 'the consistence and steadiness which is all he wants to make him the first man of the age' (letter to J.G. Lockhart, 30 March 1820). The original portrait by Robert Scott Lauder was exhibited in 1832. The engraving was probably made before 1850 when John Horsburgh scaled down his professional activities.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Wilson, John, 1785-1854 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of John Wilson by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Facsimile of sketch of John Wilson (1785-1854), Scottish poet, essayist, and Professor of Moral Philosophy at Edinburgh University, with facsimile of his signature. Along with Scott's son-in-law and biographer J. G. Lockhart and James Hogg, John Wilson was the principal contributor to the satirical Blackwood's Magazine. Scott considered him 'very clever but somewhat whimsical' (letter to Mrs Clephane, 3 December 1818) and thought him a doubtful influence on J.G. Lockhart as he disputed 'with low adversaries' and indulged in biting, personal attacks (letter to Lady Louisa Stuart, 13 April 1826). Scott successfully canvassed for Wilson in his campaign to be elected Professor of Moral Philosophy at Edinburgh University (1820). Scott hoped that the position would give Wilson 'the consistence and steadiness which is all he wants to make him the first man of the age' (letter to J.G. Lockhart, 30 March 1820). This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 32)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Wilson, John, 1785-1854 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of John Wilson by J. Stewart after J.W. Gordon
Description#1: Engraved portrait of John Wilson (1785-1854), Scottish poet, essayist, and Professor of Moral Philosophy at Edinburgh University. Along with Scott's son-in-law and biographer J. G. Lockhart and James Hogg, John Wilson was the principal contributor to the satirical Blackwood's Magazine. Scott considered him 'very clever but somewhat whimsical' (letter to Mrs Clephane, 3 December 1818) and thought him a doubtful influence on J.G. Lockhart as he disputed 'with low adversaries' and indulged in biting, personal attacks (letter to Lady Louisa Stuart, 13 April 1826). Scott successfully canvassed for Wilson in his campaign to be elected Professor of Moral Philosophy at Edinburgh University (1820). Scott hoped that the position would give Wilson 'the consistence and steadiness which is all he wants to make him the first man of the age' (letter to J.G. Lockhart, 30 March 1820). The original artist is probably John Watson Gordon who assumed the name Gordon in 1826. He was a neighbour and close friend of John Wilson in Ann Street, Edinburgh.
Source#1: Lockhart, J. G. Peter's Letters to His Kinsfolk, vol. III. Edinburgh: William Blackwood, 1819. (facing p. 256)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Wilson, John, 1785-1854 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of William Wordsworth by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Facsimile of sketch of English poet William Wordsworth (1770-1850), with facsimile of signature. Sir Walter Scott was a friend and admirer of Wordsworth. They first met when Scott accompanied the poet and his sister on a tour of the Border Country in September 1803. Scott visited the Wordsworths at Grasmere in August 1805 and climbed Helvellyn with Wordsworth and Sir Humphry Davey. A further visit to Grasmere took place in August 1825. Finally, the Wordsworths visited Abbotsford in 1831, leading Wordsworth to compose 'On the Departure of Sir Walter Scott from Abbotsford, for Naples'. Writing of Wordsworth, Scott declared that he did not know 'a man more to be venerated for uprightness of heart and loftiness of genius' (letter to Allan Cunningham, 7 January 1821). His conversation 'as much distinguished by manly sense and candour as by talent and principle, was like a fountain in the desert' (letter to Sir George Beaumont, 28 August 1825). Scott, who particularly admired Wordsworth's sonnets, regretted that his poetry was not as popular as it deserved to be as it was 'too subtle and metaphysical in the idea, & too blunt in the expression' (letter to Allan Cunningham, 14 October 1828). This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 78)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Wordsworth, William, 1770-1850 - Portraits

Title#1: Author of 'Plymley's Letters on the Catholics'
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of Reverend Sydney Smith by Daniel Maclise
Description#1: Facsimile of sketch of English clergyman and wit Sydney Smith (1771-1845), with facsimile of signature. The English clergyman and wit Sydney Smith was the chief originator and first editor of the Edinburgh Review, to which Scott contributed reviews between 1803 and 1806 before withdrawing for political reasons. Smith's correspondence with Archibald Constable contains some of the most astute early criticism of the Waverley Novels. This facsimile reproduction is of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-1838, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.
Source#1: Maclise, D. The Maclise Portrait Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters, ed. W. Bates. London: Chatto and Windus, 1883 (facing p. 212)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Contemporaries Smith, Sydney, 1771-1845 - Portraits

Title#1: Abbotsford, the Seat of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.: To Whom This Plate is Most Respectfully Inscribed by Thos. H. Shepherd
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Abbotsford House by T. Barber after T.H. Shepherd
Description#1: Depicts a view of the front of Abbotsford House, Scottish Borders. When Scott bought the 110-acre Cartley Hole Farm in 1811 he renamed it Abbotsford. He bought up neighbouring properties until in 1825 the estate had expanded to ten times its original size. By 1821, the residence that he had built between 1812 and 1818 had become too small for the estate and for the constant stream of visitors that he received. A two-storey manor house (portrayed here) was built in its stead. Scott continued to live in Abbotsford following the financial disaster of 1825-26 as the estate had been settled upon his newly married son Walter. Abbotsford proved immensely influential on nineteenth-century building styles, sparking the Victorian revival of Scots-Baronial architecture. The architects were William Atkinson and Edward Blore, with assistance from Scott himself.
Source#1: Shepherd, T.H. Modern Athens!: Displayed in a Series of Views, or, Edinburgh in the Nineteenth Century. London: Jones & Co, 1829
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Abbotsford (Scotland)

Title#1: Abbotsford: The Seat of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Abbotsford House by W. H. Lizars after J. Ewbank
Description#1: Depicts a rear view of Abbotsford House, Scottish Borders, with the River Tweed in the foreground. When Scott bought the 110-acre Cartley Hole Farm in 1811 he renamed it Abbotsford. He bought up neighbouring properties until in 1825 the estate had expanded to ten times its original size. By 1821, the residence that he had built between 1812 and 1818 had become too small for the estate and for the constant stream of visitors that he received. A two-storey manor house (portrayed here) was built in its stead. Scott continued to live in Abbotsford following the financial disaster of 1825-26 as the estate had been settled upon his newly married son Walter. Abbotsford proved immensely influential on nineteenth-century building styles, sparking the Victorian revival of Scots-Baronial architecture. The architects were William Atkinson and Edward Blore, with assistance from Scott himself.
Source#1: Chambers, R. The Picture of Scotland, 2nd edn, vol. I. Edinburgh: William Tait, 1828
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Abbotsford (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Abbotsford House by J. Johnstone after J. Bower
Description#1: Depicts the north-east face of Abbotsford House, Scottish Borders, with surrounding countryside. When Scott bought the 110-acre Cartley Hole Farm in 1811 he renamed it Abbotsford. He bought up neighbouring properties until in 1825 the estate had expanded to ten times its original size. By 1821, the residence that he had built between 1812 and 1818 had become too small for the estate and for the constant stream of visitors that he received. A two-storey manor house (portrayed here) was built in its stead. Scott continued to live in Abbotsford following the financial disaster of 1825-26 as the estate had been settled upon his newly married son Walter. Abbotsford proved immensely influential on nineteenth-century building styles, sparking the Victorian revival of Scots-Baronial architecture. The architects were William Atkinson and Edward Blore, with assistance from Scott himself.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Abbotsford (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Ben Lomond by S. Lacey after T.H. Shepherd
Description#1: Depicts a view of Loch Lomond from Dumbarton, with Ben Lomond in the background. Ben Lomond and Loch Lomond form a dramatic part of the scenery in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rob Roy (1817) and The Lady of the Lake (1810), where Roderick Dhu is portrayed as 'the terror of Loch Lomond's side' (canto II, stanza XI, line 14). Scott visited the Loch with his wife in the summers of 1809, 1816, and 1817.
Source#1: Shepherd, T.H. Modern Athens!: Displayed in a Series of Views, or, Edinburgh in the Nineteenth Century. London: Jones & Co., 1829
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lomond, Ben (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Ben More by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
Description#1: Depicts Ben More (or Benmore), Stirling, and surrounding mountains with a cowherd and his cattle in the foreground. The 'proud crest of proud Benmore' is described in one of Scott's earliest poems, Glenfinlas, or Lord Ronald's Coronach (1800). There are further references in Waverley (1814), The Lord of the Isles (1815), and The Fair Maid of Perth (1828).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings More, Ben (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the Battle of Bothwell Bridge by G. Greatbach
Description#1: Depicts the opposing armies of the Government and the Covenanters clashing on Bothwell Bridge, South Lanarkshire. The Battle of Bothwell Bridge (22 June 1679) saw a government army under James, Duke of Monmouth, decisively defeat an army of Covenanters and effectively put an end to their rebellion. It is dramatized in ch. 31-32 of Scott's Old Mortality (1816). Scott also included the traditional 'Ballad of Bothwell Brig' in his Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1803), adding extensive historical notes, and gave a further account of the battle in the Second Series of his Tales of a Grandfather (1828).
Source#1: Wylie, J.A. The Scots Worthies: Their Lives and Testimonies. Edinburgh: William Mackenzie, [186-?]
Subject#1: Scotland - History - 1660-1688 Bothwell Bridge, Battle of, 1679
Related Work Title#3: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the ruins of Bothwell Castle by E. Walker after S. Prout
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of the South-East Tower of Bothwell Castle, South Lanarkshire. In ch. 37 of Scott's Old Mortality (1816), Henry Morton passes the 'romantic ruins of Bothwell Castle' as he revisits the scene of the Covenanters' defeat at the Battle of Bothwell Bridge (1679). Scott had first visited the castle, a 13th-century edifice located southeast of Glasgow, in 1799 when visiting Lord and Lady Douglas. He was inspired to write the unfinished ballad 'Bothwell Castle'. On a later visit he wrote the ballad of 'Young Lochinvar' which he published as part of Marmion (1808).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Bothwell Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Title#1: Charles Edouard, fils aÌ¨nÌ© de Jacques Stuard, nÌ© ÌÊ Rome, le 31. DÌ©cembre 1720
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Prince Charles Edward Stuart by J. DaullÌ© after D. DuprÌÊ
Translated Title#1: Charles Edward, oldest son of James Stuart, born in Rome on 31 December 1720
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Charles Edward Stuart ('Bonnie Prince Charlie') (1720-1788). Charles Edward Stuart features as a character in two of Sir Walter Scott's novels, Waverley (1814) which is set during the Jacobite Rebellion of 1745-1746, and Redgauntlet (1824) which portrays a fictional further Jacobite uprising in 1765. Scott also describes Charles's role in the 1745-1746 Rebellion in Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1829). The original portrait by Domenico DuprÌÊ was painted c.1741.

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Prince Charles Edward Stuart by E. Finden after L. TocquÌ©
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Charles Edward Stuart ('Bonnie Prince Charlie') (1720-1788). Charles Edward Stuart features as a character in two of Sir Walter Scott's novels, Waverley (1814) which is set during the Jacobite Rebellion of 1745-1746, and Redgauntlet (1824) which portrays a fictional further Jacobite uprising in 1765. Scott also describes Charles's role in the 1745-1746 Rebellion in Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1829). The original portrait by Louis TocquÌ© was painted in 1748. Its whereabouts is unknown, and the engraver Edward Francis Finden was probably working from an earlier engraving executed in 1748 by Georg Johann Wille.

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Crichton Castle by T. Picken after T. Creswick
Description#1: Depicts the River Tyne with Crichton Castle, Midlothian, on a hill in the background. In Sir Walter Scott's Marmion (1808), Lord Marmion and Lord Lindesay spend two days at Crichton Castle in Midlothian: 'Crichtoun! though now thy miry court | But pens the lazy steer and sheep, | Thy turrets rude, and totter'd Keep, | Have been the minstrel's loved resort' (canto IV, stanza XI, lines 1-4). The castle is described in detail in stanzas X-XI of the poem. Scott traces the history of the fourteenth-century castle in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Crichton Castle (Scotland)

Title#1: John Wilson Croker, Esqr., M.P., Secretary to the Admiralty: Engraved by T. Blood for the European Magazine From an Original Painting by S. Drummond A.R.A.
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of John Wilson Croker by T. Blood after S. Drummond
Description#1: Engraved portrait of British statesman John Wilson Croker (1780-1857) in a fur-collared coat. Croker was a close friend and political ally of Sir Walter Scott. In 1813 Scott wrote to Croker to suggest Robert Southey for the post of Poet Laureate (a post that Scott himself had declined). In 1818 Croker also assisted Scott in obtaining a warrant to search for the Regalia (Crown Jewels) of Scotland. In 1824 Croker persuaded Scott to join with Thomas Moore and others to found the Athenaeum Club. Their relations were momentarily strained in 1826 when Croker penned a caustic reply to Scott's Letters of Malachi Malagrowther. Scott would subsequently assist Croker with his new edition of Boswell's Life of Johnson (1831). Another work by Croker, Stories for Children from the History of England (1817), provided the model for Scott's Tales of a Grandfather (1828-1831). The original portrait by Samuel Drummond was probably commissioned by the European Magazine in 1812.
Source#1: European Magazine, and London Review. London: Fielding, Debrett, & Sewell, 1782-1826
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Croker, John Wilson, 1780-1857 - Portraits
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Title#1: The Right Honble. John Wilson Croker
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of John Wilson Croker by W. Finden after T. Lawrence
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of British statesman John Wilson Croker (1780-1857). Croker was a close friend and political ally of Sir Walter Scott. In 1813 Scott wrote to Croker to suggest Robert Southey for the post of Poet Laureate (a post that Scott himself had declined). In 1818 Croker also assisted Scott in obtaining a warrant to search for the Regalia (Crown Jewels) of Scotland. In 1824 Croker persuaded Scott to join with Thomas Moore and others to found the Athenaeum Club. Their relations were momentarily strained in 1826 when Croker penned a caustic reply to Scott's Letters of Malachi Malagrowther. Scott would subsequently assist Croker with his new edition of Boswell's Life of Johnson (1831). Another work by Croker, Stories for Children from the History of England (1817), provided the model for Scott's Tales of a Grandfather (1828-1831). The original portrait by Sir Thomas Lawrence was first exhibited in 1825. Finden's engraving was published in 1838 as an illustration to H.T. Ryall's Portraits of Eminent Conservatives and Statesmen.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Croker, John Wilson, 1780-1857 - Portraits

Title#1: Sir Humphrey Davy, Bart. P.R.S. : By Permission From the Large Print Published by Messrs. Agnew & Lanitti
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Humphry Davy by J. Jenkins after J. Lonsdale.
Description#1: Engraved portrait of British scientist Sir Humphry Davy (1778-1829), with facsimile of signature. Sir Walter Scott and Davy were fellow guests of William Wordsworth's at Dove Cottage, Grasemere, in August 1805. Scott 'liked him excessively' and was 'particularly delighted with the total absence of pedantry which has always appeared to me the test of true genius' (letter to Jane Kerr Apreece, 2 April 1811). Davy later made two visits to Scott at Abbotsford in 1820 and 1823. In 1812 Davy had become a member of Scott's extended family by marrying his widowed cousin Jane Kerr Apreece. As a favour to her Scott wrote a review of Davy's Salmoniana for the Quarterly Review in 1828.
Source#1: Taylor, W.C. The National Portrait Gallery of Illustrious and Eminent Personages, vol. I. London: Fisher, Son & Co., 1846
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Davy, Humphry, Sir, 1778-1829 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Doune Castle by T. Picken after J. Dobbin
Description#1: Depicts cattle on the banks of the Teith River with Doune Castle, Stirling, in the background. In ch. 38 of Sir Walter Scott's Waverley (1814), Edward Waverley is rescued by a party of Jacobite Highlanders and escorted to Doune Castle in the Menteith district, a 'gloomy yet picturesque structure'. There are further references to the Castle in other works by Scott, notably The Lady of the Lake, canto VI.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth. 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Doune Castle (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the Battle of Drumclog by G. Greatbach
Description#1: Depicts Covenanters and the King's forces clashing at the Battle of Drumclog. The Battle of Drumclog (1 June 1879), in which a Covenanting army defeated John Grahame of Claverhouse's Royalist forces, is portrayed in chapters 15-17 of Sir Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816). A further account of the battle is given in Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829). The plate is engraved by George Greatbach, probably from his own design.
Source#1: Wylie, J. A. The Scots Worthies: Their Lives and Testimonies. Edinburgh: William Mackenzie, [1875-76]
Subject#1: Scotland - History - 1660-1688 - Fiction Drumclog, Battle of, 1679
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey by T. Picken after J. Dobbin
Description#1: Depicts a man and a woman visiting Scott's Sir Walter Scott's tomb in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' (1808) that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Tomb Dryburgh Abbey (Dryburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Dunbar Castle by T. Picken after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts the harbour and ruined castle of Dunbar, East Lothian. Sir Walter Scott traced the history of Dunbar Castle in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). In his notes to 'Thomas the Rhymer' in Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802), Scott discusses prophetic verses attributed to Thomas of Ercildoune concerning the heroic defence of Dunbar Castle (1337) by the Countess of March ('Black Agnes'). A further account of the siege is given in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Dunbar Castle by E. Goodall after J. C. Schetky
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Dunbar Castle, East Lothian, with a group of people in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott traced the history of Dunbar Castle in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). In his notes to 'Thomas the Rhymer' in Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802), Scott discusses prophetic verses attributed to Thomas of Ercildoune concerning the heroic defence of Dunbar Castle (1337) by the Countess of March ('Black Agnes'). A further account of the siege is given in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828). The original oil painting by John Christian Schetky, probably made specifically for Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland, is displayed in Abbotsford.

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Dunfermline Abbey by T. Picken after D. O. Hill
Description#1: Depicts wooded parkland with Dunfermline Abbey, Fife, visible through the trees. In Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828), Sir Walter Scott describes how Robert the Bruce's heart was removed from his body in Dunfermline Abbey and taken to Melrose Abbey. He then describes how a skeleton, wrapped in rich cloth and with its heart removed, was discovered by workmen during restoration work on Dunfermline Abbey in 1819. Scott had a cast made from the skeleton's skull which he exhibited at Abbotsford. In 1822 the Magistrates of Dunfermline made a gift to Scott of panelling from a post-Reformation church built in the nave of Dunfermline Abbey.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Dunfermline Abbey (Dunfermline, Scotland) Dunfermline (Scotland) - Antiquities
Related Work Title#1: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Title#1: Edinburgh from the Frith of Forth
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the Firth of Forth and Edinburgh by T. Picken after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts ships in the Firth of Forth with a view of Edinburgh in the background. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the Regalia of Scotland by E. Goodall after A. Geddes
Description#1: Depicts, from left to right, the Sceptre of James V, the Scottish Crown, and the Sword of State, which together constitute the Regalia of Scotland. Following the Act of Union between England and Scotland in 1707, the ancient Regalia (or 'Honours') of Scotland were deposited in a locked oak chest in the Crown Room of Edinburgh Castle. Over the following decades, their whereabouts was forgotten, and it was rumoured that, counter to the terms of the Union, they had been carried away to England. Prompted by Sir Walter Scott, the Prince Regent set up a commission to search the Crown Room for the Regalia. On 4 February 1818, the Commissioners, including Scott, discovered the chest and found, wrapped in linen, the fourteenth-century Scottish Crown, the Sceptre of James V, and the Sword of State, a gift from Pope Julius II to James V. The Regalia were subsequently placed on permanent display in the Crown Room. Scott described the discovery in his Description of the Regalia of Scotland (1819). Andrew Geddes was asked to paint the Regalia for the frontispiece to the 9th Part of the Provincial Antiquities in 1824. The oil painting on which the engraving is based is held at Abbotsford.
Source#1: Scott, W. Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland, vol. I. London: J. and A. Arch. 1826 (facing p. iii)
Subject#1: Regalia (Insignia) - Scotland Crown Jewels - Scotland
Related Work Title#1: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland
Related Work Title#2: Description of the Regalia of Scotland

Title#1: Greyfriars' Churchyard: Signing of the Covenant
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the signing of the National Covenant by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts a crowd of people in Greyfriars Churchyard, Edinburgh, gathered to sign the National Covenant, with Edinburgh Castle in the background. In Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829), Sir Walter Scott describes the mass signing of the National Covenant in Greyfriars Kirkyard, Edinburgh, which began on 28 February 1638. The Covenant challenged the Divine Right of Kings, demanding a free Scottish Parliament, a free General Assembly of the Church of Scotland, the abolition of bishops, and establishment of Presbyterian church government. The ensuing 'Covenanting' wars feature in a number of Scott's works, most notably Old Mortality (1816). Greyfriars Kirkyard also had personal associations for Scott. His and sister were both buried there in the Scott family burial-plot. According to J. G. Lockhart, Scott also made the acquaintance of his first love Williamina Belsches in the Kirkyard.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: National Covenant (1638) Scotland - History - 17th century
Related Work Title#1: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph by T. Picken after G. Cattermole of the murder of Rizzio in Queen Mary's Bedchamber, Holyrood Palace
Description#1: Depicts the murder of David Rizzio (ca. 1533-1566) in Queen Mary's Bedchamber, Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh. The murderers of Mary Stuart's secretary David Rizzio dragged their victim from the Queen's presence into the royal bedchamber at the Palace of Holyroodhouse before dispatching him. This episode is described in Sir Walter Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).There are further references to the murder in The Abbot and Chronicles of the Canongate.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Palace of Holyroodhouse (Edinburgh, Scotland) Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567
Related Work Title#1: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Liberton's Wynd, Edinburgh by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts street life on Libberton's Wynd, Edinburgh, outside Burn's Tavern. From 1817 until the date of the last public execution, the head of Libberton's (or Liberton's) Wynd, Edinburgh, was the site of the gallows. Among other executions, Sir Walter Scott witnessed that of the body-snatcher and murderer William Burke, 28 January, 1829.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Edinburgh (Scotland) Execution sites - Scotland - Edinburgh

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Moray House, Edinburgh by T. Picken after J. Nash
Description#1: Depicts a fierce battle outside Moray House on Canongate, Edinburgh. In Sir Walter Scott's Chronicles of the Canongate (1827), Mrs Bethune Baliol recalls her mother's account of watching the last riding of the Scottish Parliament in 1707 from 'the balcony in front of Lord Moray's Lodging in the Canongate'. Moray House was built in the 1620s by Mary, Dowager Countess of Home. It served as Cromwell's Edinburgh lodgings in 1648 and 1650-1651, and was the scene of some of the negotiations which led to the Treaty of Union in 1707. The building is now part of Edinburgh University's Moray House School of Education.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Moray House College of Education

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the National Monument, Calton Hill, Edinburgh by T. Picken after J.D. Harding
Description#1: Depicts the National Monument on Calton Hill, Edinburgh. The National Monument was built between 1824 and 1829 in memory of those who had died in the Napoleonic Wars. It was modelled on the Parthenon in Athens, but only the faÌ¤ade was completed. It is generally believed that funding ran out, but surviving drawings by the architects C. R. Cockerell and William Playfair suggest that no building had been projected beyond the extant structure. Scott wrote approvingly of Playfair's plans in a letter to Robert Johnston, 19 September 1819. Scott described Calton Hill in Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826), but made no reference to the National Monument.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts National Monument (Edinburgh, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the Scott Monument, Edinburgh by J. Sutcliffe
Description#1: Depicts the Scott Monument on Princes Street, Edinburgh, with Edinburgh Castle in the background. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Monuments Scott Monument (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: Sir Walter Scott: From the Statue in the Monument at Edinburgh
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Sir J. Steell's statue of Sir Walter Scott by J. Sutcliffe
Description#1: Depicts a profile view of the statue of Walter Scott by Sir John Steell in the Scott Monument, Edinburgh. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Monuments Scott Monument (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of West Bow, Edinburgh, by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts a group of soldiers marching down West Bow, Edinburgh. In The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818), ch. 3, a group of people including Bartoline Saddletree and Reuben Butler discuss the reprieve of Captain Porteous while returning to their houses in the Lawnmarket via 'the steep declivity of the West Bow'. The West Bow was originally a steep winding road leading from the Grassmarket (site of the gallows) to Castle Hill, offering the only means of access to Edinburgh Castle from the South. It was largely demolished in the 1830s when Victoria Street and George IV Bridge were built to provide more convenient access. Only a small portion of the West Bow now survives at the foot of Victoria Street.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Edinburgh (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of West Bow, Edinburgh, by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts a crowded street scene at the foot of West Bow, Edinburgh. West Bow was originally a steep winding road leading from the Grassmarket to Castle Hill, offering the only means of access to Edinburgh Castle from the South. It was largely demolished in the 1830s when Victoria Street and George IV Bridge were built to provide more convenient access. Only a small portion of the West Bow now survives at the foot of Victoria Street.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Hand-coloured aquatint of a view of Eildon Hills by J. Merigot after J. Girten.
Description#1: Depicts the River Tweed with the Eildon Hills (Scottish Borders) in the background. In The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), Sir Walter Scott alludes to the legend that the peak of Eildon Hill was split into three by the wizard Michael Scott. The Monk of Melrose Abbey recalls meeting the wizard and tells Sir William of Deloraine: 'And, Warrior, I could say to thee | The words that cleft Eildon hills in three, | And bridled the Tweed with a curb of stone: | But to speak them were a deadly sin | And for having but thought them my heart within | A treble penance must be done' (canto II, stanza 13, lines 8-13). Scott's first aborted attempt to write a prose romance Thomas the Rhymer revolved around the legend that a cavern existed beneath the Eildon Hills, where King Arthur and his knights lay sleeping (see the General Introduction to the Waverley Novels (1829)). The Hills are mentioned in numerous other works by Scott, notably 'The Eve of St John' (1799). The prospect of the Eildon Hills from Bemersyde was a favourite of Scott's and is now known as 'Scott's view'.
Source#1: Stoddart J. Remarks on Local Scenery & Manners in Scotland During the Years 1799 and 1800. London: W. Miller, 1801
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Eildon Hills (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Falkland Palace by T. Picken after D. Roberts
Description#1: Depicts the entrance to Falkland Palace, Fife. In Sir Walter Scott's 'Fair Maid of Perth', the heroine Catharine Glover is tricked into taking refuge in Falkland Castle to escape the attentions of the Duke of Rothsay, the heir to the Scottish throne. A further stratagem brings the Duke to the Castle where he is murdered by his dismissed Master of the Horse, Sir John Ramorny. Scott's Journal for 27 June 1829 records a visit to the 'most interesting remains' of Falkland Palace. There are further references to the building throughout Scott's works, notably in Marmion (1808) and Tales of a Grandfather (1828-31).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Falkland Palace (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Melrose Abbey by T. Barber after T.H. Shepherd
Description#1: Depicts Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders, with figures in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott coordinated the restoration of Melrose Abbey in 1822. The Abbey features in many of Scott's works, most famously The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'If thou would'st view fair Melrose aright, | Go visit it by the pale moonlight [...] | Then view St. David's ruin'd pile; | And, home returning, soothly swear, | Was never scene so sad and fair!' (canto II, stanza I, lines 1-2, 16-18). The religious house of Kennaquhair in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) is also based on the Abbey, and is described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).
Source#1: Shepherd, T.H. Modern Athens!: Displayed in a Series of Views, or, Edinburgh in the Nineteenth Century. London: Jones & Co., 1829
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose Abbey
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Loch Leven Castle by S. Lacey after T.H. Shepherd
Description#1: Depicts Loch Leven Castle on Castle Island, Loch Leven, Fife. Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) centres around the imprisonment and escape from Loch Leven Castle of Mary, Queen of Scots. The thirteenth-century castle, built on the largest island in the Loch, also figures repeatedly in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).
Source#1: Shepherd, T.H. Modern Athens!: Displayed in a Series of Views, or, Edinburgh in the Nineteenth Century. London: Jones & Co., 1829
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Loch Leven Castle Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Pencil drawing tinted with watercolour of Flodden Field by P. Home
Description#1: Depicts Flodden Field, Northumberland, and surrounding countryside. Sir Walter Scott's poem Marmion culminates in one of the greatest disasters in Scottish history, the Battle of Flodden Field. It is described at length in Canto Sixth ('The Battle'). Scott visited the battlefield in August 1791.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Flodden, Battle of, England, 1513, in literature
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Fast Castle by T. Picken after H. Bright
Description#1: Depicts Fast Castle near St Abbs Head, Berwickshire. Fast Castle has been identified as an inspiration for Wolf's Crag, the home of the Master of Ravenswood in Sir Walter Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor (1819). In the Magnum Opus edition of the novel (1830), Scott claims that he cannot comment on the perceived resemblance between Wolf's Crag and Fast Castle as he has only seen the latter from the sea. He acknowledges, however, that the position of Fast Castle resembles that of Wolf's Crag. Scott also describes the castle in Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). Scott owned a painting of Fast Castle by the Rev. John Thomson (Letters, VIII, 459).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Fast Castle Site (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Glamis Castle by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts Glamis Castle, Angus. Scott visited Glamis (or Glammis) Castle, seat of the Earl of Strathmore in 1793. In his Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft (1830), he recalls experiencing 'that degree of superstitious awe that my countrymen call eerie' when spending the night at the notoriously haunted castle. He wrote: 'I must own, that as I heard door after door shut, after my conductor had retired, I began to consider myself too far from the living and somewhat too near the dead' (Letter X). Glenallan House in Scott's novel, The Antiquary (1816), is said to be based on Glamis Castle.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Haunted houses - Scotland Glamis Castle (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Glencoe by T. Picken after H. McCulloch
Description#1: Depicts the valley of Glencoe in the Scottish Highlands. Sir Walter Scott wrote the poem 'On the Massacre of Glencoe' in 1814. He also described the massacre at length in Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1828).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Coe, Glen (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Glen Falloch by T. Picken after G.F. Robson
Description#1: Depicts Glen Falloch with the River Falloch running into Loch Lomond. While researching Rob Roy (1817), Walter Scott visited Glen Falloch at the head of Loch Lomond. It is mentioned in ch. 29 of the novel as a sure place of refuge for Rob Roy Macgregor as it belongs to his wife's relatives. Glen Falloch has also been identified with the 'gloomy and desolate' spot, haunted by a spirit known as the 'Cloght-dearg', where the clergyman Mr Tyrie meets Elspat MacTavish Mhor in The Highland Widow (1827). The original drawing by G. F. Robson was probably taken expressly for Scotland Delineated.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Falloch, Glen (Scotland)

Title#1: 'Julia Mannering' from Sir Walter Scott's 'Guy Mannering'
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of painting of Julia Mannering by Sir J.D. Linton
Description#1: Profile portrait of Julia Mannering, heroine of Scott's novel Guy Mannering. Julia Mannering is the daughter of Guy Mannering in the novel of that name (1815). She marries Harry Bertram, the hero of the tale.
Source#1: Profeit, R.A. Under Lochnagar. Aberdeen: Taylor and Henderson, 1894 (p. 92)
Subject#1: Scotland - History - 18th century - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Jedburgh Abbey by R. Godfrey
Description#1: Depicts Jedburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, and kirkyard. Sir Walter Scott describes Jedburgh Abbey in his 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814), inaccurately praising its Anglo-Norman chapter-house as 'a very perfect specimen of Saxon architecture'. There are further references in The Black Dwarf and The Monastery. The Abbey was built by David I around 1138 but had fallen into ruin by the mid-sixteenth century. Scott was a frequent visitor to Jedburgh in his capacity as Sheriff Depute of Selkirkshire. He subscribed å£10 toward the repair-work on the Abbey's tower in 1824-1826. The engraving by Richard Godfrey was probably made for Francis Grose's The Antiquarian Repertory (1775-1784). It is likely to have been made from Godfrey's own design.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Jedburgh Abbey (Jedburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Kelso Abbey by T. Picken after D. Roberts
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Kelso Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott described Kelso in his unfinished Autobiography (1808) as 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Scott spent many summers in Kelso at his uncle Captain Robert Scott's house of Rosebank, which Scott inherited in 1804. In 1783, a convalescent Scott also attended Kelso Grammar School, where he made the acquaintance of his future business partner James Ballantyne. Kelso Abbey is one of four founded in the Borders by King David I. It is described in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Kelso Abbey (Kelso, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.

Title#1: The Back of old Leith Pier
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Leith Pier by T. Picken after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts Leith Pier, Edinburgh, with people gathered around a boat on the shore. According to his friend James Skene of Rubislaw, Scott frequently walked to Leith Pier, 'to which the freshness of the sea breeze offered a strong inducement to those accustomed to pass a few of the morning hours within the close and impure atmosphere of the Court of Session' (quoted in The Journal of Sir Walter Scott (Edinburgh: David Douglas, 1890), I, 210, n. 1). Scott gave a description and historical account of Leith harbour in Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). Leith Pier features in Waverley (1814), ch. 56, where Edward Waverley obtains permission for his prisoner Colonel Talbot to sail from there to England, and in Old Mortality (1816), ch. 36, where Henry Morton sails into European exile from Leith. Scott himself sailed from Leith on 29 July 1814 when he accompanied the Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Leith (Edinburgh, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Linlithgow Palace by T. Picken after D. Roberts
Description#1: Depicts Linlithgow Palace and Linlithgow Loch (West Lothian). Linlithgow Palace was built in the eleventh century and was a royal residence from the twelfth to the late sixteenth century. It was accidentally gutted by fire in 1746. In Marmion (1808), Sir Walter Scott describes Linlithgow as: 'Of all the palaces so fair, | Built for the royal dwelling, | In Scotland, far beyond compare | Linlithgow is excelling;' (canto IV, stanza XV, lines 1-4). The Palace is more fully described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and features in a number of his other works, notably Waverley (1814) and Tales of a Grandfather (1828-30). The entrance porch at Scott's home of Abbotsford was modelled after that of Linlithgow Palace.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Linlithgow Palace (Linlithgow, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Title#1: View of Loch Lomond from the South
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Loch Lomond by T. Picken after H. McCulloch
Description#1: Depicts Loch Lomond and surrounding mountains. Loch Lomond forms a dramatic part of the scenery in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rob Roy and The Lady of the Lake, where Roderick Dhu is portrayed as 'the terror of Loch Lomond's side' (canto II, stanza XI, line 14). Scott visited the Loch with his wife in the summers of 1809, 1816, and 1817.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lomond, Loch (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Watercolour painting of Melrose market-place by an unknown artist
Description#1: Depicts the Market Square of Melrose, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott's home of Abbotsford lay only a few miles west of the town of Melrose in the Scottish Borders. Melrose is set in the heart of the 'Scott Country', and is featured in many of his works, most notably The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) and, under the guise of 'Kennaquhair', in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820). Town and abbey are described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814). At a vital moment in The Monastery, ch. 37, the Earl of Murray meets the Abbot of Kennaqhair beneath the 'mercat cross' in the town's marketplace to demand that he hand over Sir Piercie Shafton.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Melrose market-place by J. Bower

Town and abbey are described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814). At a vital moment in The Monastery, ch. 37, the Earl of Murray meets the Abbot of Kennaqhair beneath the 'mercat cross' in the town's marketplace to demand that he hand over Sir Piercie Shafton. The engraving by John Bower was made from his own design.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Melrose Abbey by G.B. Smith after R.W. Billings
Description#1: Depicts a close view of the east side of the ruins of Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott coordinated the restoration of Melrose Abbey in 1822. The Abbey features in many of Scott's works, most famously The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'If thou would'st view fair Melrose aright, | Go visit it by the pale moonlight [...] | Then view St. David's ruin'd pile; | And, home returning, soothly swear, | Was never scene so sad and fair!' (canto II, stanza I, lines 1-2, 16-18). The religious house of Kennaquhair in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) is also based on the Abbey, and it is described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).
Source#1: Billings, R.W. The Baronial and Ecclesiastical Antiquities of Scotland, vol. IV. Edinburgh: William Blackwood, 1845-52 (plate 7)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose Abbey

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of a cloister of Melrose Abbey by J. Bower
Description#1: Depicts a sheltered cloister in Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott coordinated the restoration of Melrose Abbey in 1822. The Abbey features in many of Scott's works, most famously The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'If thou would'st view fair Melrose aright, | Go visit it by the pale moonlight [...] | Then view St. David's ruin'd pile; | And, home returning, soothly swear, | Was never scene so sad and fair!' (canto II, stanza I, lines 1-2, 16-18). The religious house of Kennaquhair in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) is also based on the Abbey, and it is described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814). The original drawing by John Bower was probably made in the 1830s.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose Abbey
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Minto Tower by W. Thomas after F. Grose
Description#1: Depicts Minto Tower (or Fatlips Castle), Scottish Borders. In The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), Sir William of Deloraine rides past the Minto Crags on his way to Melrose Abbey: 'On Minto-crags the moonbeams glint, | Where Barnhill hew'd his bed of flint; | Who flung his outlaw'd limbs to rest, | Where falcons hang their giddy nest, | Mid cliffs, from whence his eagle eye | For many a league his prey could spy; |Cliffs, doubling, on their echoes borne, | The terrors of the robber's horn' (canto I, stanza 27, lines 5-12). Minto Tower, more commonly known by the less poetical name of Fatlips Castle, is a 16th-century tower house, situated 4 miles west of Jedburgh. It was built by the Turnbulls of Barnhill, one of whom became a notorious Border freebooter. This view was probably drawn by Francis Grose in 1789 for his Antiquities of Scotland.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Fatlips Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of James Graham, Marquis of Montrose by W. Holl after G. van Honthorst
Description#1: Depicts James Graham, Marquis of Montrose (1612-1650) in armour. Initially a Covenanter, Montrose was won over to the Royalist cause and waged a successful campaign against the Covenanters in the Highlands in 1644-1645. Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819) is set against the backdrop of the 'Montrose wars'. Montrose's campaign, his subsequent betrayal by Charles II and execution by the Covenanters are also described in Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829). Scott, a great admirer of Montrose, came into possession of his sword which he displayed in his 'armory' at Abbotsford. The original portrait by Gerrit van Honthorst was painted in 1649.
Source#1: Wylie, J. A. The Scots Worthies: Their Lives and Testimonies. Edinburgh: William Mackenzie, [1875-76]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Montrose, James Graham, Marquis of, 1612-1650
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Newark Castle after T. Picken after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts Sir Walter Scott (seated) and William Wordsworth by the River Yarrow, Scottish Borders, with Newark Castle in the background. This image depicts a visit made by Scott and Wordsworth in September 1831 which inspired Wordsworth's poem 'Yarrow Revisited'. In Scott's The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), the minstrel receives hospitality from the Duchess of Buccleuch at Newark Castle and, in return, recites a tale about her ancestors.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits Newark Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The

Title#1: The Challenge: From the Painting in the Collection of W. Cuthbert Quilter, Esq.
Alternate Title#1: Engraving by J. Stephenson after a painting by W. Q. Orchardson depicting a scene from Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
Description#1: Depicts Sir Jasper Cranbourne presenting Geoffrey Peveril's challenge to Major Bridgenorth (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 9). Illustrates the following text: 'So saying, he [Cranbourne] took his sheathed rapier from his belt, and passing the point through the silk thread which secured the letter, he once more, and literally at sword point, gracefully tendered it to Major Bridgenorth who again waved it aside, though colouring deeply at the same time, as if he was putting a marked constraint upon himself' (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 9). The third figure in the engraving is the clergyman, Mr Solsgrace, who seeks to dissuade Major Bridgenorth from accepting the challenge. 'The Challenge', one of Orchardson's most celebrated paintings was completed in 1864.
Subject#1: Popish Plot, 1678 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Alternate Title#1: Drawing of Pinkie House by W. Geikie
Description#1: Depicts Pinkie House, Musselburgh, East Lothian. In Sir Walter Scott's novel Waverley (1814), ch. 49-50, Charles Edward Stuart ('Bonnie Prince Charlie') establishes his headquarters at Pinkie House near Musselburgh following his victory at the Battle of Prestonpans. Built as a tower house in the sixteenth century, Pinkie House was greatly expanded by Sir Alexander Seton, Chancellor of Scotland, in 1613.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Pinkie House (Musselburgh, Scotland)
Subject Person#1$1: Charles Edward, Prince grandson of James II, King of England

Title#1: [Covent Garden Theatre playbill for J.S. Knowles's production of The Vision of the Bard!]
Description#1: Playbill for The Vision of the Bard!, starring James Sheridan Knowles; also contains advertisements for Waverley, The Beaux Stratagem, and His First Campaign, among other productions. The Irish dramatist and actor James Sheridan Knowles (1784-1862) wrote and took the principal role in The Vision of the Bard! (1832), a masque in honour of the recently deceased Sir Walter Scott, which featured scenes from various of his novels. It was first performed at Covent Garden, London, on 29 October 1832.

Description#1: Playbill for The Wizard; or The Brown Man of the Moor, also includes advertisements for My Uncle and Batchelors' Wives, among other productions. The musical drama The Wizard, or, The Brown Man of the Moor was adapted from Sir Walter Scott's The Black Dwarf (1816), with words by Samuel James Arnold (1774-1852) and music by Charles Edward Horn (1786-1849). It was first performed at the Lyceum Theatre, London (then known as 'The English Opera House) on 26 July 1817.

Title#1: [Theatre Royal, Edinburgh playbill for Guy Mannering, or, The Gypsy's Prophecy, a musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's novel]
Description#1: Playbill for Guy Mannering, or The Gypsy's Prophecy; also advertises The Maid of the Mill. Guy Mannering, or, The Gypsy's Prophecy was a very successful musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's 1815 novel with words by Daniel Terry (1789-1829) and music by Sir Henry Bishop (1786-1855). Scott himself contributed to the libretto. It was first performed at the Covent Garden Theatre, London, on 12 March 1816.

Title#1: [Covent Garden Theatre playbill for The Maid of Judah, or, Knights Templars, based on Sir Walter Scott's novel, Ivanhoe]
Description#1: Playbill for The Maid of Judah, or, Knights Templars, also advertising Master's Rival, among other productions. The Maid of Judah is an adaptation by Michael Rophino Lacy (1795-1867) of Rossini's pasticcio IvanhoÌ©. IvanhoÌ© was first performed at the OdÌ©on, Paris, on 15 September 1826, with a libretto by Emile Deschamps and Gustave de Wailly. The music was selected from four Rossini operas, Semiramide, MosÌ¬, Tancredi, and La gazza ladra, and arranged by Antonio Pacini. Scott himself was in the audience for the 31 October performance and wrote in his Journal: 'It was superbly got up, the Norman soldiers wearing pointed helmets and what resembled much hauberks of mail, which looked very well. The number of the attendants, and the skill with which they were moved and grouped on the stage, were well worthy of notice. It was an opera, and of course the story greatly mangled, and the dialogue in a great part nonsense. Yet it was strange to hear anything like the words which I (then in an agony of pain with spasms in my stomach) dictated to William Laidlaw at Abbotsford, now recited in a foreign tongue, and for the amusement of a strange people.' Lacy's adaptation was first performed at Covent Garden on 7 March 1829.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Adaptations Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Musical Settings

Title#1: [Theatre Royal, Edinburgh playbill for Rossini's opera La Donna del Lago, based on Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake]
Description#1: Playbill for La Donna del Lago, or, The Lady of the Lake; also advertises Il Fanatico per la Musica, among other productions. La Donna del Lago was the first opera to be based on Sir Walter Scott's work and has proved one of the most successful. It was adapted from Scott's narrative poem The Lady of the Lake (1810) with music by Rossini and a libretto by Andrea Leone Tottola. The premiÌ¬re took place at the Teatro San Carlo, Naples, on 24 September 1819. The first British performance took place at the Theatre Royal, London, in February 1823.

Title#1: Mr. O Smith, as Christie of the Clint-hill, in the White Lady, Theatre Royal, Drury Lane
Alternate Title#1: Theatrical portrait of Mr O. Smith as Christie of Clint-hill in The White Lady
Description#1: Depicts actor O. Smith (1786-1855) in the role of Christie of the Clinthill for the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. Richard John Smith, better known as O. Smith, specialized in villainous parts. Here he is portrayed in the role of Christie of the Clinthill in The White Lady, or, La Dame Blanche, a comic opera combining motifs from Sir Walter Scott's Guy Mannering (1815) and The Monastery (1820). With music by FranÌ¤ois Adrien Boieldieu (1775-1834) and libretto by EugÌ¬ne Scribe (1791-1861), it was first performed at the OpÌ©ra comique, Paris, on 10 December 1825. The first British production took place at Drury Lane on 9 October 1826, with additional music by Thomas Cooke (1782-1848), and a libretto by Samuel Beazley (1786-1851),which deviated drastically from Scribe's original and which followed Scott more closely. The character of Christie of the Clinthill, absent from the Scribe version, was, in fact, introduced by Beazley from Scott's The Monastery.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Adaptations Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Title#1: [Theatre Royal, Edinburgh playbill for Rob Roy, a musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's novel]
Description#1: Playbill for Rob Roy; also advertises My Neighbour's Wife and The Twa Drovers, among other productions. The 'national opera' Rob Roy is probably a version of the musical drama Rob Roy Macgregor, or, Auld Lang Syne, written by Isaac Pocock (1783-1835) with music by Sir Henry Bishop (1786-1855) and John Davy (1763-1824). Adapted from Sir Walter Scott's 1817 novel, it was first performed at Covent Garden, London, on 12 March 1818 and went on to become one of the most popular and frequently revived dramas of the nineteenth century.

Title#1: View of the Clyde above Erskine Ferry
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the Clyde River by E. Walker after W. L. Leitch
Description#1: Depicts the Clyde river valley from Erskine Ferry. The Clyde River features in a number of works by Walter Scott, notably Rob Roy (1817), The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818), and Old Mortality (1816). In Rob Roy, Frank Osbaldistone travels through the Clyde valley on his way to Glasgow (ch. 19). In The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Jeanie Deans 'travelled through a thousand beautiful and changing views down the side of that noble stream' on her way to Inverary (ch. 40). Old Mortality, meanwhile, is set in Clydesdale, and much of the action takes place on the banks of the river.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Clyde River (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Painted engraving of Rosslyn Castle by F. Jukes after G. Walker
Description#1: Depicts Rosslyn Castle, Midlothian, and the River Esk. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Castle is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'O'er Roslin all that dreary night, | A wondrous blaze was seen to gleam; | 'Twas broader than the watch-fire's light, | And redder than the bright moon-beam' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 25-28). The castle, a ruined 14th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). This print is dated 1793 in Catalogue of Maps, Prints, Drawings, etc: Forming the Geographical and Topographical Collection Attached to the Library of His Late Majesty King George the Third (London: British Museum, 1829), vol. II, p. 279.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Rosslyn Castle (Roslin, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Rosslyn Chapel by T. Picken after D. Roberts
Description#1: Scotland Delineated title-page depicting a group of soldiers talking to a girl outside the entrance to Rosslyn Chapel, Midlothian. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Chapel is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'Seem'd all on fire that chapel proud, | Where Roslin's chiefs uncoffin'd lie... | Seem'd all on fire within, around, | Deep sacristy and altar's pale; | Shone every pillar foliage-bound, | And glimmer'd all the dead men's mail' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 33-40). The chapel, a 15th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and is thought to have provided the model for the convent of Engaddi in The Talisman (1825). Its architecture inspired the rich moulded ceiling of the library at Scott's home of Abbotsford.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth 1847-1854 (t.p.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Rosslyn Chapel (Roslin, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the interior of Rosslyn Chapel and the 'Prentice Pillar' by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
Description#1: Depicts some of the elaborate carvings of the interior of Rosslyn Chapel, Midlothian, including the 'Prentice Pillar'. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Chapel is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'Seem'd all on fire that chapel proud, | Where Roslin's chiefs uncoffin'd lie... | Seem'd all on fire within, around, | Deep sacristy and altar's pale; | Shone every pillar foliage-bound, | And glimmer'd all the dead men's mail' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 33-40). The chapel, a 15th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and is thought to have provided the model for the convent of Engaddi in The Talisman (1825). Its architecture inspired the rich moulded ceiling of the library at Scott's home of Abbotsford. According to tradition the 'Prentice Pillar' was carved by an apprentice while the master mason was studying in Rome. Upon his return, the master mason struck the apprentice dead with his mallet in a fit of jealousy.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Rosslyn Chapel (Roslin, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Lay of the Last Minstrel, The
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by an unknown artist, possibly after J. W. Gordon
Description#1: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-eight, with a book in his left hand. The head and shoulders of Sir Walter Scott in this engraving are very similar to those in the portrait that John Watson Gordon painted for Robert Cadell in 1830. However, in Gordon's portrait, Scott is shown with a walking cane and his dog Bran, whereas here he is portrayed with a book. According to Francis Russell in his Portraits of Sir Walter Scott: A Study of Romantic Portraiture (1987), p. 41, unsigned derivations of Watson Gordon's portrait were issued by J. Lofts, by Harwood, and by L. Tallis.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait by W. Holl from a bust of Sir Walter Scott by Sir F. Chantrey
Description#1: Engraved portrait depicting a side view of Chantrey's bust of Sir Walter Scott. Scott first sat for the original plaster bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. This engraving is from the marble replica (known as the 'Abbotsford Bust') that Chantrey made for Scott in 1821. It was first published in Knight's Gallery of Portraits, VII (1837). The engraver was probably William Holl the Younger (1807-71) but may have been his father William Holl the Elder (ca. 1771-1838).
Source#1: Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge. The Gallery of Portraits: With Memoirs. London: Charles Knight, 1833-37, vol. VII
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Pencil drawing by an unknown artist from a bust of Sir Walter Scott by Sir F. L. Chantrey]
Description#1: Pencil drawing of Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey's bust of Sir Walter Scott. Scott first sat for the original plaster bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. This drawing is of the marble replica (known as the 'Abbotsford Bust') that Chantrey made for Scott in 1821. A signature beginning with 'E' is visible to the bottom left of the sketch.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by J. Heath after J. Saxon
Description#1: Three-quarter length portrait of Sir Walter Scott, aged thirty-three, sitting with his dog, Camp. The original portrait by James Saxon was painted in 1805 for Sir Walter Scott's wife Charlotte and subsequently ceded to Scott's London publisher Longmans who wished to have it engraved. It now belongs to the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. The engraving by James Heath was published as the frontispiece to the second impression of Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Lady of the Lake. Edinburgh: John Ballantyne and Co., 1810 (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Sir Walter Scott in His Study (Castle Street, Edinburgh)
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott at his desk by R. C. Bell after J. Watson Gordon
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott seated at his desk at 39 North Castle Street, Edinburgh, with his cat Hinse of Hinsefeldt and dog Maida. The original portrait of Sir Walter Scott by John Watson Gordon is a posthumous likeness dating from the 1840s or 1850s. There are numerous inaccuracies and anachronisms. Scott's Castle Street study was lined with bookshelves and featured a portrait of John Graham of Claverhouse where Gordon has placed his own portrait of Scott's mother. The painting now belongs to the Scottish National Portrait Gallery.
Source#1: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott and Five Engravings in Illustration of The Pirate. Edinburgh: Royal Association for Promotion of the Fine Arts, 1871
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: View of the Coast of Sleat, Isle of Skye
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Sleat, Isle of Skye, by T. Picken after H. McCulloch
Description#1: Depicts part of the coastline of Sleat, the southern peninsula of the Isle of Skye. In Canto III of Sir Walter Scott's poem The Lord of the Isles (1815), Ronald, the Lord of the title, and his page Allan accompany Robert the Bruce to Skye. Scott had himself twice visited Skye, in July 1810 and again in the summer and autumn of 1814 when Scott joined a party of Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection around the coast of Scotland. In Waverley, ch. 22, Flora sings a Highland battle-song which calls on the 'proud chiefs of Clan Ranald, Glengarry, and Sleat' to 'combine like three streams from one mountain of snow, | And resistless in union rush down on the foe!' (lines 26-28).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Skye, Island of (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the Isle of Staffa by E. Walker after W. A. Nesfield
Description#1: Depicts the basalt cliffs and caves of the Isle of Staffa, Inner Hebrides. Sir Walter Scott visited the Isle of Staffa in 1810 and declared it 'one of the most extraordinary places I ever beheld' which 'exceeded in my mind every description I had heard of it' (Letter to Joanna Baillie, July 19, 1810). He was particularly struck by Fingal's Cave: 'the appearance of the cavern composed entirely of basaltic pillars as high as the roof of a cathedral and running deep into the rock, eternally swept by a deep and swelling sea, and paved as it were with ruddy marble baffles all description'. He subsequently described Fingal's Cave in The Lord of the Isles (1815), canto IV, stanza X: 'that wondrous dome, | Where, as to shame the temples deck'd | By skill of earthly architect, | Nature herself, it seem'd, would raise | A Minster to her Maker's p raise!' (lines 13-17). The island and its caves are further celebrated in 'Lines Addressed to Ranald Macdonald, Esq. of Staffa' (1814).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Staffa (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Lines Addressed to Ranald Macdonald, Esq. of Staffa

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Stirling Castle by T. Picken after G. F. Robson
Description#1: Depicts a regiment of soldiers patrolling the area around Stirling Castle. The concluding scenes of Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810) take place in 'the bulwark of the North, | Grey Stirling, with her towers and town' (canto V, stanza XVIII, lines 34-35). The castle features in a number of Scott's works, most notably Waverley, ch. 38, where the Jacobites guarding Edward Waverley exchange fire with the castle's garrison. The stained glass portraits of Scottish kings in the armoury window at Scott's home of Abbotsford are based on carvings in the presence chamber of Stirling Castle.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Stirling Castle (Stirling, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Tantallon Castle by T. Picken after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts Tantallon Castle, East Lothian, on the Firth of Forth. In Canto Fifth of Marmion (1808), James IV of Scotland sends Lord Marmion and Clara de Clare to Tantallon Castle: 'And, sudden, close before them showed | His towers Tantallon vast; | Broad, massive, high, and stretching far, | And held impregnable in war. | On a projecting rock they rose, | And round three sides the ocean flows' (stanza 23, lines 4-8). Tantallon Castle, built by the Earls of Douglas in the fourteenth century, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated in a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth. 1847-1854.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Tantallon Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Title#1: The Hon. Alexander Fraser Tytler, Lord Woodhouselee
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Alexander Fraser Tytler, Lord Woodhouselee, by C. Picart after J. Jackson after H. Raeburn
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of the Scottish historian Alexander Fraser Tytler, Lord Woodhouselee (1747-1813). Sir Walter Scott attended Alexander Fraser Tytler's courses in Universal History at Edinburgh University during the 1789-1790 session. Tytler's empiricism and his insistence on the determining influence of institutions, heredity, and environment had a profound impact on Scott's own vision of history. Scott was also greatly impressed by Tytler's translation of Schiller's Die Raíöuber (The Robbers) (1792) which inspired him to prepare his own translations of German drama and verse. Finally Tytler was sufficiently close a family friend to compose a Latin epitaph for Scott's dog Camp in 1809. The original portrait by Henry Raeburn was painted in 1804.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Woodhouselee, Alexander Fraser Tytler, Lord, 1747-1813 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Kenilworth Castle by J. Godfrey after H. Warren
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Kenilworth Castle, Warwickshire. Much of the decisive action of Sir Walter Scott's novel Kenilworth (1821) takes place in the Earl of Leicester's castle of that name. The now ruined castle was established by Geoffrey de Clinton, Chamberlain to Henry I, in about 1122.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Kenilworth Castle (Kenilworth, England)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Edinburgh and Craigmillar Castle by T. Picken after W. Simpson
Description#1: Depicts Craigmillar Castle with Edinburgh in the distance. Craigmillar Castle, built in the 15th century by the Preston family, was a favourite residence of Mary Queen of Scots. In ch. 17 of Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820), when Roland Graeme catches a first glimpse of Edinburgh, his companion Adam Woodcock points out Craigmillar Castle 'which I have known a merry place in my time'. The castle is also mentioned in Scott's account of Mary's reign in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828). It is also described in detail in his Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Craigmillar Castle (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History
Related Work Title#3: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Title#1: Sir Walter Scott, Bart., Born 1771: Died 1832
Alternate Title#1: Coloured lithograph of Sir Walter Scott by Riddle and Couchman
