Description#1: Colour lithograph half-length portrait of Sir Walter Scott. This lithograph produced by the established London firm of Riddle & Couchman appears to be freely based on the 1823 portrait of Scott painted by Sir Henry Raeburn for his own private gallery. Scott, however, appears markedly younger in the lithograph.
Source#1: The Penny Poets: Bryant, Spenser, Keats, Scott. London: Review of Reviews Office, 1895
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Prince Charles Edward Taking Leave of his Adherents = Le Prince Charles Edouard prenant congÌ© de ses adhÌ©rents
Alternate Title#1: Engraving by G. Presbury after a painting by F. W. Topham depicting a scene from Scott's novel Redgauntlet
Description#1: Depicts Charles Edward Stuart ('Bonnie Prince Charlie') taking leave of his followers on the beach of Lochnanach (Redgauntlet, ch. 23). Sir Walter Scott's Redgauntlet (1824) portrays a fictional third Jacobite uprising in 1765. At its conclusion Charles Edward Stuart is permitted to return to France, and his supporters are not pursued. This engraving shows his final farewell to his followers. The figure kneeling before the Prince is the Scottish laird, Redgauntlet, who follows the Prince into exile.
Source#1: Wright, G.N. Landscape-Historical Illustrations of Scotland, and the Waverley Novels, vol. II. London: Fisher, 1836-1838 (facing p. 61)
Subject#1: Jacobites - Fiction Charles Edward, Prince, grandson of James II, King of England, 1720-1788
Subject Person#1$1: Charles Edward, Prince grandson of James II, King of England

Title#1: The Field of Prestonpan: (Death of Colonel Gardiner)
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the Battle of Prestonpans by E. Walker after W. Allan
Description#1: Depicts the death of Colonel Gardiner at the Battle of Prestonpans (Waverley, ch. 18). The Battle of Prestonpans (September 21, 1745) saw Charles Edward Stuart's Jacobite army defeat Sir John Cope's Hanoverian troups. It is depicted in Sir Walter Scott's novel Waverley (1814), where the eponymous hero deserts Colonel Gardiner's Hanoverian dragoons to join the Jacobites. Scott thus describes the fall of Gardiner (a real-life figure): 'Waverley, as he cast his eyes towards this scene of smoke and slaughter, observed Colonel Gardiner, deserted by his own soldiers in spite of all his attempts to rally them, yet spurring his horse through the field to take the command of a small body of infantry... Waverley could perceive that he had already received many wounds, his clothes and saddle being marked with blood. To save this good and brave man, became the instant object of his most anxious exertions. But he could only witness his fall. Ere Edward could make his way among the Highlanders, who, furious and eager for spoil, now thronged upon each other, he saw his former commander brought from his horse by the blow of a scythe, and beheld him receive, while on the ground, more wounds than would have let out twenty lives.' The battle and Gardiner's death are also described in Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1829).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Jacobite Rebellion, 1745-1746 - Fiction Prestonpans (Scotland), Battle of, 1745
Related Work Title#2: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Title#1: [Front and back cover illustrations for an edition of The Pirate by Walter Scott]
Description#1: Front and back cover of an edition of Sir Walter Scott's The Pirate. Illustrator John Leighton FSA (1822-1912) also used the nom-de-plume 'Luke Limner'. The figures portrayed in alcoves on the front cover are probably Captain Cleveland, the pirate of the title, and his lover Minna Troil. The engraver is John Leighton's brother Henry. The scene on the back cover illustrates the parting interview of Cleveland and Minna, with Minna's sister Brenda in the background and John Bunce, Cleveland's lieutenant looking on (ch. 40). It was engraved by (W.T.?) Green, probably after Robert Scott Lauder.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Pirate. Edinburgh: A. & C. Black; London: Houlston & Stoneman, [18--?]
Subject#1: Shetland (Scotland) - History - 17th century - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Loch Katrine by T. Picken after H. McCulloch
Description#1: View of Loch Katrine, Stirling, with Ellen's Isle visible in the middle distance, and Ben Venue in the background. Loch Katrine provides the setting for Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810). Following the success of the poem, the Loch and the surrounding Trossachs region became major tourist attractions.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Katrine, Loch (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Edinburgh from Craigleith Quarry by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
Description#1: Depicts Craigleith Quarry with a view of Edinburgh city in the background. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). Craigleith Quarry provided much of the fine sandstone used in building Edinburgh's New Town in the 18th and 19th centuries. It was first worked to provide stone for Edinburgh Castle in the 17th century.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Edinburgh from Calton Hill by T. Picken after D. Roberts
Description#1: Depicts a view of Edinburgh city centre from Calton Hill as it was in the 1840s. In the middle ground may be seen the recently completed Scott Monument. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). In Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826), Sir Walter Scott describes the view from Calton Hill 'where every passenger, however much accustomed to the wonderful scene, is inclined to pause, and, with eyes unsatisfied with seeing, to gaze on the mingled and almost tumultuous scene which lies before and beneath him'.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Title#1: View of Edinburgh: From the Castle
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Edinburgh from the Castle by T. Picken after D. Roberts
Description#1: Presents a view of Edinburgh city centre from the Castle ramparts. To the left may be seen the recently completed Scott Monument. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). Edinburgh Castle is the city's most prominent landmark. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland)

Title#1: High Street: From Head of West Bow, Lawnmarket
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of High Street, Edinburgh by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
Description#1: Depicts the junction of West Bow and High Street, Edinburgh. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). Scott gives a description and historical account of the High Street in Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826), noting, not uncritically, the many innovations made during his own lifetime. The view of the High Street presented in this engraving was only made possible by the demolition of the Old Tolbooth and Luckenbooths in 1817. These buildings had previously stood between the Lawnmarket and the High Street proper. Scott still maintained that 'under all its mutilations, the High Street of Edinburgh is the most magnificent in Great Britain, excepting perhaps the High Street of Oxford'.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Edinburgh Castle from the Grassmarket by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
Description#1: Depicts the Grassmarket with Edinburgh Castle dominating the skyline. Edinburgh Castle is the most prominent landmark of Scott's hometown. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh Castle (Edinburgh, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Description of the Regalia of Scotland
Related Work Title#4: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the Assembly Hall, Edinburgh by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
Description#1: Depicts the Assembly Hall of the Church of Scotland, Edinburgh (now The Hub) and a crowded Castle Hill. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). The building portrayed here, Assembly Hall on Castle Hill, was built in 1842-44, a decade after Scott's death. Scott did, however, give a description and historical account of the High Street in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826), noting, not uncritically, the many innovations made during his own lifetime. These had effectively extended the street to Castle Hill.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Fleshmarket Close, Edinburgh by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
Description#1: Depicts Fleshmarket Close, Edinburgh. In the Magnum Opus edition of The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1830), Scott inserts a note containing a contemporary account of the inquiries made by Crown Counsel into the lynching of Captain Porteous in Edinburgh in 1737. This describes the unsuccessful attempt to arrest a suspect, Thomas Burns, a butcher, in an alehouse in Fleshmarket Close. Fleshmarket Close was intersected by Cockburn Street in 1859. Only the lower part of the historical Close now retains that name.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Edinburgh (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of the Palace of Holyroodhouse by T. Picken after J. D. Harding
Description#1: Depicts the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh, with Holyrood Park and Arthur's Seat in the background. The Royal Palace of Holyroodhouse appears in a number of Scott's works, most notably in Waverley (1814) where it is occupied by Prince Charles Edward Stuart and is the scene of a ball (chapter 43). The Palace is also described in Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and is repeatedly mentioned in Tales of a Grandfather, First to Third Series (1828-30).
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Palace of Holyroodhouse (Edinburgh, Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland
Related Work Title#3: Tales of a Grandfather; being Stories taken from Scottish History

Title#1: View From the Summit of Goatfell, Island of Arran
Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Goatfell on the Isle of Arran by T. Picken after J. D. Harding
Description#1: Presents a view from Goatfell across the Isle of Arran. In Canto IV of Sir Walter Scott's The Lord of the Isles (1815) Robert the Bruce sets sail for Arran where his forces are to assemble: 'Now launched once more, the inland sea | They furrow with fair augury, | And steer for Arran's isle; | The sun, ere yet he sunk behind | Ben-Ghoil, "the Mountain of the Wind," | Gave his grim peaks a greeting kind, | And bade Loch Ranza smile.' (stanza 12, lines 1-7). Ben Ghoil is the Gaelic name for Goatfell. Scott had himself visited Arran in September 1814 when he joined a party of Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection around the coast of Scotland. Arran is also described in chapter 41 of The Heart of Midlothian (1818) as abounding 'with the grandest and most romantic scenery'.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Arran, Island of (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of Glasgow Cathedral by T. Picken after D. Roberts
Description#1: Depicts crowds attempting to strip Glasgow Cathedral of Catholic symbols during the Reformation. Glasgow Cathedral is the scene of an important meeting between Frank Osbaldistone and Rob Roy in ch. 19 of Sir Walter Scott's novel Rob Roy (1817). Osbaldistone, the narrator, describes his first impression of the building in chapter 18: 'The pile is of a gloomy and massive, rather than of an elegant, style of Gothic architecture; but its peculiar character is so strongly preserved, and so well suited with the accompaniments that surround it, that the impression of the first view was awful and solemn in the extreme.' This engraving possibly depicts the (successful) efforts of the tradesmen of Glasgow to prevent the Cathedral from being demolished at the Reformation. This episode is recalled in Scott's novel by Osbaldistone's man-servant Andrew Fairservice.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Glasgow Cathedral (Glasgow, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Lithograph of a scene inside Glasgow Cathedral by T. Picken after J. Nash
Description#1: Depicts a confrontation inside Glasgow Cathedral at the time of the Reformation. Glasgow Cathedral is the scene of an important meeting between Frank Osbaldistone and Rob Roy in ch. 19 of Sir Walter Scott's novel Rob Roy (1817). Osbaldistone, the narrator, describes his first impression of the building in ch. 18: 'The pile is of a gloomy and massive, rather than of an elegant, style of Gothic architecture; but its peculiar character is so strongly preserved, and so well suited with the accompaniments that surround it, that the impression of the first view was awful and solemn in the extreme.' This engraving possibly depicts the (successful) efforts of the tradesmen of Glasgow to prevent the Cathedral from being demolished at the Reformation. This episode is recalled in Scott's novel by Osbaldistone's man-servant Andrew Fairservice.
Source#1: Lawson, J.P. Scotland Delineated: In a Series of Views by Clarkson Stanfield. London: J. Hogarth, 1847-1854
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Glasgow Cathedral (Glasgow, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Coloured engraving of Peel Castle by W. Daniell
Description#1: Depicts boats on the Irish Sea with Peel Castle (Isle of Man) and St. Patrick's Isle in the middle distance. Peel Castle, or Holm-Peel, Isle of Man, figures prominently in Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823) as the residence of the Countess of Derby. It is described in chapter 15 of the novel as 'one of those extraordinary monuments of antiquity with which this singular and interesting island abounds'. Scott did not personally visit the Isle of Man, but received information from his younger brother Thomas who served as an officer in the Manx Fencibles from 1808 to 1810. The image is both drawn and engraved by William Daniell.
Source#1: Ayton, R. A Voyage Round Great Britain. London: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown, 1814-25
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Peel Castle (Isle of Man)

Title#1: MacDonald of Glengarry: (The Fergus MacIvor of the Tale)
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Waverley
Description#1: Title page of Waverley, volume I in a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, featuring Colonel MacDonell in full Highland dress. Scott is thought to have based many of the traits of the Highland chieftain Fergus MacIvor in Waverley (1814) on his friend Alasdair (or Alexander) Ranaldson MacDonell, 15th Chief of Glengarry. Scott described him thus in his Journal (14 February 1826): 'This gentleman is a kind of Quixote in our age, having retained, in their full extent, the whole feelings of clanship and chieftainship, elsewhere so long abandoned. He seems to have lived a century too late, and to exist, in a state of complete law and order, like a Glengarry of old, whose will was law to his sept. Warmhearted, generous, friendly, he is beloved by those who know him, and his efforts are unceasing to show kindness to those of his clan who are disposed fully to admit his pretensions. To dispute them is to incur his resentment, which has sometimes broken out in acts of violence which have brought him into collision with the law. To me he is a treasure, as being full of information as to the history of his own clan, and the manners and customs of the Highlanders in general.' Glengarry gifted Scott the deerhounds Maida (1816) and Nimrod (1824). The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates MacDonell, Alasdair Ranaldson, 1773-1828 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Waverley
Description#1: Title page of Waverley, volume II in a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Edinburgh Castle. Approaching Edinburgh in Waverley (1814), ch. 39, Edward Waverly sees Edinburgh Castle besieged by a Jacobite army and is struck by the appearance of 'grandeur and gloom' that results from its partial concealment by gunsmoke. The Castle is also mentioned in other novels by Scott, notably The Heart of Midlothian (1818), and is described in his Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). It was also at Edinburgh Castle that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The original wood engraving, probably by John Greenaway, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Edinburgh Castle (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Guy Mannering
Description#1: Title page of Guy Mannering, volume III of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, featuring Caerlaverock Castle, Dumfries and Galloway. Ellangowan Castle, seat of the Bertrams in Sir Walter Scott's Guy Mannering (1815), is often thought to be based on Caerlaverock Castle in Dumfriesshire. Scott visited Caerlaverock Castle (built by the Maxwells in the 13th century) with Guthrie Wright in 1806. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-47).
Source#1: Scott, W. Guy Mannering. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Caerlaverock Castle (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Guy Mannering
Description#1: Title page of Guy Mannering, volume IV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Writer's Court, Edinburgh. In chapter 7 of Guy Mannering (1815), Mannering and Dandie Dinmont seek the lawyer Counsellor Pleydell in Clerihugh's Tavern, Edinburgh, and find him engaged in a game of 'High Jinks'. Clerihugh's Tavern was a real-life locale where the lawyers and magistrates of Edinburgh transacted much of their business in the 18th century. The original wood engraving, probably based on the work of Joseph Noel Paton, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-47).
Source#1: Scott, W. Guy Mannering. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Edinburgh (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Antiquary
Description#1: Title page of The Antiquary, volume V of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, featuring Arbroath Abbey, Angus. St Ruth's Priory, scene of a number of important episodes in Sir Walter Scott's The Antiquary (1816), is often thought to be based on the 12th-century Arbroath Abbey. Scott visited Arbroath in September 1796. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). The artist is Patrick Allan-Fraser who assumed his wife's surname of Fraser on his marriage in 1843.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Antiquary. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Arbroath Abbey

Title#1: Cabinet of Mr. Constable, (The Antiquary of the Tale)
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Antiquary
Description#1: Title page of The Antiquary, volume VI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Mr Constable's cabinet. Sir Walter Scott himself acknowledged that Jonathan Oldbuck, the titular character of The Antiquary (1816), was based partly on a family friend George Constable who first introduced Scott to Shakespeare. In his unfinished Autobiography (1808), Scott wrote: 'He used always to dine at my father's house of a Sunday, and was authorized to turn the conversation out of the austere and Calvinistic tone, which it usually maintained on that day, upon subjects of history or auldlangsyne. He rememberd the forty-five, and told many excellent stories, all with a strong dash of a peculiar caustic humour.' The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-47). The artist is Patrick Allan-Fraser who assumed his wife's surname of Fraser on his marriage in 1843.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Antiquary. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Constable, George, 1719-1803

Title#1: David Ritchie: (The Original of the Black Dwarf)
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Black Dwarf
Description#1: Title page of The Black Dwarf, volume IX of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting David Ritchie, real-life model for the dwarf of the title. As Sir Walter Scott himself acknowledged in his introduction to the 'Magnum Opus' edition of The Black Dwarf (1830), the character of Elshender the Recluse was based on a real-life hermit David Ritchie. Scott had visited Ritchie's cottage while staying with his friend Captain Adam Ferguson in Peeblesshire in 1797. The Gilbert portrait of David Ritchie was originally published in the Scot's Magazine 1817. The original wood engraving, probably by Thomas Gilks after John Gilbert, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Black Dwarf. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Ritchie, David, 1740-1811 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Old Mortality
Description#1: Title page of Old Mortality, volume X of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting James Sharp, Archbishop of St Andrews (1613-1679). In ch. 5-6 of Sir Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816), the hero Henry Morton shelters John Burley of Balfour who is wanted for his part in the assassination of James Sharp, Archbishop of St Andrews (3 May 1679). Sharp was detested by the Covenanters for betraying the Presbyterian cause and playing a major role in the reintroduction of Episcopacy and oppression of the Covenanting party. In Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829), Scott wrote of Sharp: 'He had some virtues, being learned, temperate, and living a life becoming his station; but his illiberal and intolerant principles, and the violences which he committed to enforce them, were the cause of great distress to Scotland, and of his own premature and bloody end.' The Dickes portrait of Archbishop Sharp is based on a 17th-century portrait by Sir Peter Lely. The wood engraving was originally made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Old Mortality. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Sharp, James, 1613-1679 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Old Mortality
Description#1: Title page of Old Mortality, volume XI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, featuring General Thomas Dalyell (1615-1685). Commander-in-Chief of the army in Scotland from 1661 to 1685, General Thomas Dalyell earned the epithet 'Bluidy Tam' after his suppression of the Covenanters at Rullion Green in 1666. In Old Mortality (1816) Scott describes him as 'as much feared for his cruelty and indifference to human life and human sufferings, as respected for his steady loyalty and undaunted valour'. The General also appears as a demonic ghost in 'Wandering Willie's Tale' in Redgauntlet (1824). The Dickes portrait appears to be based on an original portrait by David Paton (fl. 1660-1698). The wood engraving was originally made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Old Mortality. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Dalyell, Thomas, 1599?-1685 - Portraits

Title#1: John Duke of Argyle and Greenwich
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Heart of Midlothian
Description#1: Title page of The Heart of Midlothian, vol. XIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, featuring John Campbell, 2nd Duke of Argyll (1678-1743). In Sir Walter Scott's The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818), the Duke of Argyll assists Jeanie Deans in seeking the aid of Queen Caroline and ultimately provides a home on his estates for the heroine and her husband Reuben Butler. Scott wrote that 'few names deserve more honourable mention in the history of Scotland' than the Duke; he 'was alike free from the ordinary vices of statesmen, falsehood, namely, and dissimulation; and from those of warriors, inordinate and violent thirst after self-aggrandisement' (The Heart of Mid-Lothian, ch. 34). The original wood engraving, probably after William Lodge, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Heart of Midlothian. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Argyll, John Campbell, Duke of, 1680-1743 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor
Description#1: Title page of The Bride of Lammermoor, volume XIV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Queen Anne (1665-1714). Sir Walter Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor (1819) is set during the reign of Queen Anne in the years immediately preceding the Act of Union between England and Scotland (1707). The novel takes place at a time when the Jacobite party appears to be in the ascendant on both sides of the Border in the expectation that the Queen would be succeeded by her brother James (later known as the 'Old Pretender'). The Dickes portrait derives from a portrait by Sir Godfrey Kneller (ca. 1690) probably via the intermediary of earlier engravings. The wood engraving was originally made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Bride of Lammermoor. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Great Britains - Kings and rulers - Portraits Anne, Queen of Great Britain, 1665-1714 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's A Legend of Montrose
Description#1: Title page of A Legend of Montrose, volume XV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Archibald Campbell, 1st Marquis of Argyll (1607-1661). Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819) is set during the campaign of James Graham, Earl of Montrose, against the Covenanters in the Highlands in 1644-1645. The Marquis of Argyll met Montrose in a series of battles, finally defeating him at Philiphaugh in 1645. Scott describes Argyll as 'a man rather of political enterprise than personal courage, and better calculated to manage an intrigue of state, than to control the tribes of hostile mountaineers' (A Legend of Montrose, ch. 1). The Dickes portrait of the Marquis of Argyll is drawn from an 'old print', possibly a 1713 engraving by Michael Vandergucht after an unknown artist. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. A Legend of Montrose. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Argyll, Archibald Campbell, Marquis of, 1598-1661 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Ivanhoe
Description#1: Title page of Ivanhoe, volume XVI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, featuring Micklegate Bar, York. Sir Walter Scott's Ivanhoe (1819) is set in Yorkshire. The Jewish financier Isaac and his daughter Rebecca are both natives of the county-town York. Micklegate (or 'great street') was the principal thoroughfare of medieval York. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Ivanhoe. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings York (England)

Title#1: Crown of Thomas a Becket at Canterbury
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Ivanhoe
Description#1: Title page of Ivanhoe, volume XVII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting the Corona of Canterbury Cathedral, Kent. This image depicts the 'Corona' or the east end of Canterbury Cathedral, named after the severed crown of St Thomas Becket (St. Thomas the Martyr), who was assassinated in the cathedral in 1170. The Corona was built to contain a shrine to St Thomas, which was subsequently destroyed on the orders of Henry VIII in 1540. St Thomas' name is used in many oaths in Walter Scott's Ivanhoe (1819). Prince John also despairs about the loyalty of his men: "An unhappy prince am I. My father, King Henry, had faithful servants---He had but to say that he was plagued with a factious priest, and the blood of Thomas-a-Becket, saint though he was, stained the steps of his own altar" (ch. 11). The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). The engraving by Jewitt is presumably after his own design.
Source#1: Scott, W. Ivanhoe. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Becket, Thomas, Saint, 1118?-1170 - Shrines Canterbury Cathedral

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Monastery
Description#1: Title page of The Monastery, volume XVIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting King James V of Scotland (1512-1542). Sir Walter Scott's The Monastery (1820) in the years following the death of James V, when Lowland Scotland was devastated by Henry VIII of England's 'Rough Wooing'. That is the term that Scott coined to describe Henry's military campaign (1544-1551) to bring about the marriage of the infant Mary Queen of Scots and his own son Edward Prince of Wales. This portrait is taken from a 16th-century carving made for the King's Presence Chamber in Stirling Castle (one of the 'Stirling Heads'). The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Monastery. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction James V, King of Scotland, 1512-1542 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Monastery
Description#1: Title page of The Monastery, volume XIX of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Edward Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset (ca. 1500-1552). Somerset was Lord Protector of England from 1547 to 1549, ruling the country in the name of the boy king Edward VI. As Warden of the Scottish Marshes, he continued to prosecute the war of 'Rough Wooing', which was designed to bring about the marriage of Edward and the infant Mary Queen of Scots. The Scots suffered a particularly devastating defeat at his hands at the Battle of Pinkie Cleugh (1547). In Sir Walter Scott's The Monastery (1820), the father of Halbert and Edward Glendinning has been killed at the battle, and Somerset is depicted encamped at Roxburgh Castle demanding tribute from the Scots (ch. 2). The original wood engraving, probably by Charles Green, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Monastery. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction Somerset, Edward Seymour, Duke of, 1506?-1552 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Abbot
Description#1: Title page of The Abbot, volume XX of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting John Knox (ca. 1514-1572). Scott never portrayed John Knox directly in his fiction, but his 1820 novels The Monastery and The Abbot portray the triumph of the Knox-inspired Reformation in Scotland. Scott's preacher Henry Warden is presented as second only in power and eloquence to Knox. In The Abbot even the Catholic Mary Queen of Scots salutes Knox's power, describing him as 'the ablest and most powerful of heresiarchs' (ch. 25). Scott also described Knox's role in the Reformation in the historical Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828), where Knox is introduced as 'a man of great courage, zeal, and talents' and as the 'bold and inflexible father of the Scottish Reformation'. For each of these works, Knox's own Historie of the Reformation of the Church of Scotland was an important source. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847), where it was used to illustrate The Monastery. It was engraved by John Orrin Smith and William James Linton after a drawing by William Dickes. Dickes's drawing was based on one of several earlier prints all ultimately deriving from a portrait by Adrian Van Son (ca. 1580).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Abbot. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction Knox, John, c.1505-1572 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Abbot
Description#1: Title page of The Abbot, volume XXI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley (1545-1567) as a child. Following the murder of Lord Darnley, second husband of Mary Queen of Scots (1567), and Mary's subsequent remarriage to the Earl of Bothwell, the Scottish Lords confronted the Queen and imprisoned her in Loch Leven Castle. Her escape from captivity is the subject of Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820). In ch. 22 of the novel she proclaims herself innocent of involvement in the murder of Darnley, but acknowledge that by marrying the chief suspect she has laid herself open to suspicion. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847) by a member of the Dalziel family of engravers, possibly George (1815-1902). It derives ultimately from a late 16th- or early 17th-century engraving by Renold Elstrack.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Abbot. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scotland - History - Mary Stuart, 1542-1567 - Fiction Darnley, Henry Stewart, Lord, 1545-1567 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Kenilworth
Description#1: Title page of Kenilworth, volume XXIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Thomas Radcliffe, 3rd Earl of Sussex (ca. 1525-1583). Thomas Radcliffe was Earl of Sussex, not Essex as indicated here. Under Queen Elizabeth, he served as Lord Lieutenant of Ireland (1559-1564) and Lord Chamberlain (1572-1583). His court rivalry with Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester, forms the backdrop to Sir Walter Scott's Kenilworth (1821). Radcliffe wished Elizabeth to marry a non-English bridegroom and was thus hostile to Dudley's own ambitions to marry the Queen. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). It derives from a 16th-century painting by an unknown artist.
Source#1: Scott, W. Kenilworth. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Great Britain - History - Elizabeth, 1558-1603 - Fiction Sussex, Thomas Radcliffe, Earl of, 1526?-1583 - Portraits

Title#1: Aisle of St. Magnus' Cathedral, Kirkwall
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Pirate
Description#1: Title page of The Pirate, volume XXIV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting St. Magnus Cathedral, Kirkwall, Orkney. In Sir Walter Scott's The Pirate (1821), St. Magnus Cathedral in Kirkwall, Orkney, is the scene of decisive encounters between Captain Cleveland and Minna Troil (ch. 37) and between Mordaunt Mertoun and Ulla Troil (ch. 41). Scott, who had visited Orkney in 1814, described the Cathedral as 'of the heaviest order of Gothic architecture, but grand, solemn, and stately, the work of a distant age, and of a powerful hand' (The Pirate, ch. 31). The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). There the engraving itself gives the artist's name as Dickes and the engraver as Mary A. Williams, but the list of illustrations gives the artist's name as Elizabeth Leveson-Gower, Duchess-Countess of Sutherland.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Pirate. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings St. Magnus Cathedral (Kirkwell, Scotland)

Title#1: Headland of Culswick, Pictish Fort: Norna's Dwelling
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Pirate
Description#1: Title page of The Pirate, volume XXV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Fitful Head, Shetland. In Sir Walter Scott's The Pirate (1821), the self-style prophetess Ulla Troil inhabits a pictish fort or broch on Fitful Head, Shetland. No such structure exists on Fitful Head, and Scott is generally thought to have modelled her imaginary dwelling on the nearby brochs of Mousa and Culswick (the latter portrayed here). Scott visited Shetland in 1814 when he joined a party of Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection around the coast of Scotland. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Pirate. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Brochs - Scotland - Shetland

Title#1: Statue of George Heriot: (In the Hospital at Edinburgh)
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel
Description#1: Title page of The Fortunes of Nigel, volume XXVI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting a statue of George Heriot (1563-1624). George Heriot, Goldsmith and Jeweller to James VI, is portrayed as 'Jingling Geordie' in Sir Walter Scott's 1822 novel The Fortunes of Nigel. George Heriot's School, Edinburgh, formerly George Heriot's Hospital, was founded in 1628 as a result of a bequest from Heriot. The statue of Heriot in the school's Quadrangle was carved in 1693 by Robert Mylne (1633-1710) who based the likeness on a painting by Paul Van Somer. This engraving, obtained glyphographically be Edward Palmer, was originally made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Fortunes of Nigel. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Heriot, George, 1563-1624 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel
Description#1: Title page of The Fortunes of Nigel, volume XXVII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting the George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham (1592-1628). Buckingham appears as the omnipotent favourite of both King James VI and I and the Prince of Wales in Sir Walter Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel (1822). Scott describes him as 'more feared than beloved, and, if not absolutely of a tyrannical disposition [...] accounted haughty, violent, and vindictive' (ch. 6). The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). It derives, via earlier engravings, from a portrait by Michiel Jansz van Miereveld (1567-1641).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Fortunes of Nigel. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Buckingham, George Villiers, Duke of, 1592-1628 - Portraits

Title#1: Newgate: As Built by Sir Richard Whittington
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Peveril of the Peak
Description#1: Title page of Peveril of the Peak, volume XXVIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Newgate Prison, London. In Sir Walter Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak (1823), the hero Julian Peveril is imprisoned in Newgate following an affray with the Duke of Buckingham's men. His father Sir Geoffrey Peveril had earlier been imprisoned in the same gaol on suspicion of involvement in the Popish Plot (1678). The original wood engraving, probably by Ebenezzar Whymper, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Peveril of the Peak. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Newgate (Prison: London, England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Peveril of the Peak
Description#1: Title page of Peveril of the Peak, volume XXIX of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Margaret Cavendish, Duchess of Newcastle (1661-1717). In Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823), the Duchess of Newcastle is mentioned on several occasions as a friend of the Countess of Derby. She attracts the ridicule of the Earl of Derby and of King Charles II who describes her as 'an entire raree-show in her own person--a universal masquerade--indeed a sort of private Bedlam-hospital' (ch. 45). To this day, the Duchess divides opinion, some hailing her as a pioneering woman writer, others concurring with Pepys that she was 'mad, conceited and ridiculous'. Scott clearly inclined to the latter view. The original wood engraving, probably by John Thompson, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-47). It derives, probably via earlier engravings, from an original painting by Abraham Diepenbeeck.
Source#1: Scott, W. Peveril of the Peak. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Popish Plot, 1678 - Fiction Newcastle, Margaret Cavendish, Duchess of, 1624?-1674

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Peveril of the Peak
Description#1: Title page of Peveril of the Peak, volume XXX of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Haddon Hall with lit beacon. Martindale Castle, ancient seat of the Peverils in Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823), is generally thought to be modelled on Haddon Hall, Derbyshire, a fortified medieval manor house belonging to the Manners family. The original wood engraving, probably by Charles Green, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Peveril of the Peak. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Haddon Hall (England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Quentin Durward
Description#1: Title page of Quentin Durward, volume XXXI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting PÌ©ronne, Somme, France. In Sir Walter Scott's Quentin Durward (1823), Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy makes his camp at PÌ©ronne. He is unexpectedly visited there by his enemy Louis XI who, by feigning friendliness, hopes to allay suspicions that he has backed a revolt against Charles's brother-in-law, the Bishop of LiÌ¬ge. Charles sees through Louis's ploy and imprisons him. The King is finally, however, able to persuade Charles of his innocence and regain liberty. Scott himself passed through PÌ©ronne when travelling from Belgium to France in 1815. The original wood engraving, probably by Walter George Mason, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Quentin Durward. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings PÌ©ronne (Somme, France)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Quentin Durward
Description#1: Title page of Quentin Durward, volume XXXII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting St Joan of Valois (1464-1505). Joan (or Jeanne), Duchess of Berry was the second daughter of Louis XI by his second wife Charlotte of Savoy. For dynastic purposes, Louis compelled her to marry his second cousin Louis duc d'OrlÌ©ans, later Louis XII. Divorced by Louis XII on his ascent to the throne, she went on to found the religious order of the Annonciades and was canonized by Pius XII. In Sir Walter Scott's Quentin Durward (1823), the duc d'OrlÌ©ans's passion for Isabelle de Croye threatens to thwart Louis IX's plans to marry him to her daughter. Scott describes Joan as 'pale, thin, and sickly in her complexion; her shape visibly bent to one side, and her gait [...] so unequal that she might be called lame'. In terms of appearance, eyes 'expressive of melancholy, softness, and resignation' were her only 'redeeming points'. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Quentin Durward. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Jeanne, Queen, Consort of Louis XII, King of France, 1464-1505 - Portraits
Subject Person#1$1: Jeanne, Queen Consort of Louis XII, King of France

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Saint Ronan's Well
Description#1: Title page of St. Ronan's Well, volume XXXIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting the inn at Howgate, near Penicuik, Midlothian. The inn at Howgate has sometime been proposed as a model for the Auld Town Inn kept by Meg Dods in Sir Walter Scott's Saint Ronan's Well (1823). The original wood engraving, probably after Noel Paton, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Saint Ronan's Well. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Howgate (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's St Ronan's Well
Description#1: Title page of Saint Ronan's Well, volume XXXIV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, featuring Niel Gow (1727-1807). Niel (or Neil) Gow was the most celebrated Scottish fiddler of the 18th century. His son Nathaniel (1766-1831), a first-rate musician and composer in his own right, plays during the theatricals at Shaws-Castle in Sir Walter Scott's St Ronan's Well (1823). Touchwood comments: 'He is his father's own son [...]. It is many a long year since I listened to old Neil at Inver, and, to say truth, spent a night with him over pancakes and Athole brose; and I never expected to hear his match again in my lifetime' (ch. 20). The original wood engraving, probably by John Andrew, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Saint Ronan's Well. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Gow, Niel, 1727-1807 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Betrothed
Description#1: Title page of The Betrothed, volume XXXVII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting the Bishop's Palace, Gloucester. In ch. 18 of Sir Walter Scott's The Betrothed (1825), Hugo de Lacy meets Baldwin, Archbishop of Canterbury, in the Bishop's Palace at Gloucester. Scott is guilty here of an anachronism. There was no Diocese of Gloucester in the twelfth century, the period in which the novel is set. The fourteenth-century building portrayed here only became the Bishop's Palace in 1542 when Henry VIII created the Diocese. Previously it had been the residence of the Abbot of the Benedictine Abbey of St. Peter. The original wood engraving, probably by J. J. Field, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Betrothed. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Bishop's Palace (Gloucester, England)

Title#1: Interior of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, Jerusalem
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Talisman
Description#1: Title page of The Talisman, volume XXXVIII of a set the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, Jerusalem. Sir Walter Scott's The Talisman (1825) is set during the Third Crusade (1189-1192), when a combined European force attempted to reconquer the Holy Land from Saladin and to restore access to the most important Christian shrine, the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem. The original wood engraving, probably by Thomas Armstrong, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Talisman. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Church of the Holy Sepulchre (Jerusalem)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Woodstock
Description#1: Title page of Woodstock, volume XXXIX of a set the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting General George Monck (1608-1670). In ch. 38 of Sir Walter Scott's Woodstock (1826) news reaches the exiled Royal Court at Brussels that General Monck (or Monk) is marching South from Scotland, a move that would bring about the restoration of the Stewart dynasty. Having initially fought on the Royal side, Monck had become one of Cromwell's most trusted generals and his deputy in Scotland. On Cromwell's death, he pledged to support Cromwell's son and successor Richard. As the country descended into chaos, however, he acted to restore the monarchy. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-47). According to the contents page of the Abbotsford Edition, the illustration was engraved by 'Nugent' after 'Chapman'. However, the image is clearly signed 'W. Dickes' and was probably derived from one or more pre-existing engraved portraits.
Source#1: Scott, W. Woodstock. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Great Britain - History - Elizabeth, 1558-1603 - Fiction Albemarle, George Monck, Duke of, 1608-1670 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Woodstock
Description#1: Title page of Woodstock, volume XL of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, featuring Windsor Castle, Berkshire. In Sir Walter Scott's Woodstock (1826), Cromwell is stationed at Windsor while awaiting the capture of the fugitive King Charles. In chapter 8 of the novel Roger Wildrake is granted an audience at Windsor with Cromwell, during which he delivers a letter from Colonel Markham Everard. The original wood engraving, possibly after Edmund Evans, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Woodstock. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Windsor Castle (England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Highland Widow, etc.
Description#1: Title page of The Highland Widow, etc, volume XLI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting the Canongate Cross, Edinburgh. Sir Walter Scott's Chronicles of the Canongate were published in two Series (1827 and 1828) and purport to be narrated by Chrystal Croftangry, a resident in the Canongate, Edinburgh, who writes up the tales from the recollections of his friends and neighbours, Mrs Bethune Baliol and Miss Kate Fairscribe. The original wood engraving, probably by Owen Jones after William Douglas, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Highland Widow, etc. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Canongate (Edinburgh, Scotland)

Title#1: Gowrie Tower, the Tay, and Bridge, Perth
Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Fair Maid of Perth
Description#1: Title page of The Fair Maid of Perth, volume XLII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting the Perth Bridge. Describing Perth in ch. I of The Fair Maid of Perth (1828), Sir Walter Scott regrets the demolition in 1809 of Gowrie House or Tower, the scene of the alleged 'Gowrie Conspiracy' against James VI in 1600. The bridge portrayed here was built in 1771 and is therefore not the one featured in the novel which was destroyed by a flood in 1621. The original wood engraving, possibly by Edward Evans, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Fair Maid of Perth. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Perth (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Fair Maid of Perth
Description#1: Title page of The Fair Maid of Perth, volume XLIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Abernethy Round Tower, Perthshire. The Round Tower of Abernethy (near Perth) was built in the ninth century and is one of only two such towers in Scotland. Over 70 feet tall, it was built by monks from the nearby monastery and has served as a place of refuge, a belfry, and a burial chamber. Scott described the Tower in a letter to his son Walter on 14 November 1820 and in a review of Joseph Ritson's Annals of the Caledonians, Picts, and Scots for the Quarterly Review in July 1829. The original wood engraving, by William Dickes after Noel Paton, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Fair Maid of Perth. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Round towers - Scotland - Abernethy

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Anne of Geierstein
Description#1: Title page of Anne of Geierstein, volume XLV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting a monument to William Tell. The legend of William Tell is constantly invoked throughout Sir Walter Scott's Anne of Geierstein (1829). The caption to this engraving is a little misleading. The monument to Tell is not the tower but the statue overlooking the fountain. It was created in 1786 by Benedikt Curiger and removed in 1859 to make way for a new monument. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Anne of Geierstein. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Tell, Wilhelm - Monuments

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Count Robert of Paris
Description#1: Title page of Count Robert of Paris, volume XLVI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C Black, depicting the Column of Theodosius, Istanbul. Sir Walter Scott's Count Robert of Paris (1831) is set in Constantinople during the reign of the Byzantine Emperor Alexius Comnenus (1081-1118). It begins with a brief history of the city which mentions the additions and improvements made by the Emperor Theodosius I (378-395). It was Theodosius who brought to Constantinople the Egyptian obelisk of Pharaoh Thutmosi III now known as the Column of Theodosius. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Count Robert of Paris. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Istanbul (Turkey) - Antiquities, Byzantine

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Castle Dangerous
Description#1: Title page of Castle Dangerous, volume XLVII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting St Bride's Church, Douglas, South Lanarkshire. In Sir Walter Scott's Castle Dangerous (1831), the disguised heroine, Lady Augusta de Berkely, takes up residence in the Abbey of St. Bride in the village of Douglas. Originally the parish church, the thirteenth-century Kirk of St Bride's became a mausoleum for the 'Black' Douglas family. The original wood engraving, possibly by Owen Jones after Noel Paton, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Castle Dangerous. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings St. Bride's Church (Douglas, Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Surgeon's Daughter
Description#1: Title page of The Surgeon's Daughter, volume XLVIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. & C. Black, depicting Hyder Ali (ca. 1720-1782). In Sir Walter Scott's The Surgeon's Daughter (1827), Haidar (or Hyder Ali), Nawab of Mysore, assures the safety of the heroine, Menie Gray, and punishes her duplicitous fiance Richard Middlemass. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Surgeon's Daughter. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Haidar Ali, Nawab of Mysore, ca. 1722-1782 - Portraits

Title#1: [Engraving of the Vale of Gala Water by W. Forrest after C. Stanfield]
Description#1: Depicts the Vale of Gala Water from the woods of Abbotsford, Scottish Borders. The Gala Water, a tributary of the River Tweed, runs through the heart of the 'Scott Country'. In his Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. (1837-1838), Scott's son-in-law J. G. Lockhart describes the return of the dying Scott to Abbotsford on 11 July 1832 after a lengthy stay on the Continent. Scott begins to revive from a state of torpor as his carriage descends the Vale of Gala, and he murmurs, 'Gala Water, surely -- Buckholm --Torwoodlee'. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847), where it appeared as an illustration to The Monastery.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Monastery. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Gala Water (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Berwick-upon-Tweed by W. Miller after J.M.W. Turner
Description#1: Depicts Berwick-upon-Tweed, Northumberland, with the ruins of Berwick Castle in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott's drama Halidon Hill (1822) describes an event which took place during the Battle of Halidon Hill (1333), when a Scottish army under Sir Archibald Douglas sought to lift the siege of Berwick-upon-Tweed but were heavily defeated by English forces. This engraving was first published in vol. XII of the The Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. (Edinburgh: Cadell, 1834).
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Berwick-upon-Tweed (England)

Title#1: The Vale of Manor Water, Peebles-Shire
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Manor Valley by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts Manor Valley, Scottish Borders, with bridge and ruined tower. In the Introduction to Magnum Opus edition of The Black Dwarf (1830), Walter Scott recounts the tale of David Ritchie, the inspiration for the eponymous character: 'Tired at length of being the object of shouts, laughter, and derision, David Ritchie resolved, like a deer hunted from the herd, to retreat to some wilderness... He settled himself, with this view, upon a patch of wild moorland at the bottom of a bank on the farm of Woodhouse, in the sequestered vale of the small river Manor, in Peeblesshire.' Scott himself visited Ritchie's cottage while staying with his friend Captain Adam Ferguson in Peeblesshire in 1797. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Black Dwarf. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Manor Valley (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Craignethan Castle by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts Craignethan Castle, Lanarkshire. Craignethan Castle is generally held to be the inspiration for Tillietudlem Castle, seat of the Bellenden family in Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816). Scott had visited the ruins of the 16th-century castle in 1799 in the company of Lord and Lady Douglas. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Old Mortality. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Craignethan Castle (Scotland)

Title#1: [Engraving of a Highland Pass, near Gairloch, by W. Richardson after C. Stanfield]
Description#1: Depicts a deep canyon and two Highlanders by a fallen tree. In ch. 49 of Sir Walter Scott's The Heart of Midlothian (1818), Lady Staunton (the former Effie Deans) becomes trapped while visiting a waterfall in the vicinity of Gairloch (Ross and Cromarty). The artist has chosen a spot matching the description: 'A single shoot carried a considerable stream over the face of a black rock, which contrasted strongly in colour with the white foam of the cascade, and, at the depth of about twenty feet, another rock intercepted the view of the bottom of the fall. The water, wheeling out far beneath, swept round the crag, which thus bounded their view, and tumbled down the rocky glen in a torrent of foam.' The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Heart of Midlothian. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Wester Ross (Scotland)

Title#1: [Engraving of the Trossachs by W. Richardson after A. Nasmyth]
Description#1: Depicts a view of the Trossachs, Stirling. The Trossachs region of Scotland, now a National Park, was home to Rob Roy Macgregor and his clan. Sir Walter Scott celebrated its scenery in the novel Rob Roy (1817) and poem The Lady of the Lake (1810), spawning an enduring tourist industry. Scott visited the region with his wife in the summers of 1809, 1816, and 1817. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Rob Roy. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Trossachs (Scotland)

Title#1: [Engraving of Eyemouth and the coast of Berwickshire by W. Richardson after C. Stanfield]
Description#1: Depicts boats in the harbour at Eyemouth, Berwickshire. In Sir Walter Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor (1819), Wolf's Crag tower is 'situated on the bleak shores between Saint Abb's Head and the village of Eyemouth' (ch. 2). In ch. 35 of the novel Ravenswood perishes in quicksand on the Links of Wolf's Hope, which are based on Eyemouth Links. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Bride of Lammermoor. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Eyemouth (Scotland)

Title#1: [Engraving of Fast Castle by J. Horsburgh after J. Thomson]
Description#1: Depicts the ruins of Fast Castle on a promontory and a stretch of Berwickshire coastline. Fast Castle, near St Abbs Head, Berwickshire, has been identified as an inspiration for Wolf's Crag, the home of the Master of Ravenswood in Sir Walter Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor (1819). In the Magnum Opus edition of the novel (1830), Scott claims that he cannot comment on the perceived resemblance between Wolf's Crag and Fast Castle as he has only seen the latter from the sea. He acknowledges, however, that the position of Fast Castle resembles that of Wolf's Crag. Scott owned a painting of Fast Castle by the Rev. John Thomson (Letters, VIII, 459), quite possibly the one engraved here. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Bride of Lammermoor. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Fast Castle Site (Scotland)

Title#1: [Engraving of Inveraray by W. Forrest after W. L. Leitch]
Description#1: Depicts the town of Inveraray (Argyll and Bute) and Loch Fyne. In ch. 12 of Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819), Sir Duncan Campbell and Captain Dalgetty arrive in Inveraray (formerly Inverary), ancestral home of the Marquis of Argyle. The village is described as 'a rude assemblage of huts, with a very few stone mansions interspersed, stretching upwards from the banks of Loch Fine to the principal gate of the castle'. Extensively rebuilt in 1745, by Scott's age it had become 'a neat country town'. There are further references to Inverary as the seat of the Duke of Argyll in The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. A Legend of Montrose. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Inveraray (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of York Minster by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts York Minster in the moonlight. At the conclusion of Sir Walter Scott's novel Ivanhoe (1819), Wilfred of Ivanhoe marries Rowena 'in the most august of temples, the noble Minster of York' (ch. 44). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Ivanhoe. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings York Minster

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Temple Church by J. H. Le Keux after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts the interior of the Temple Church, London. In ch. 35 of Sir Walter Scott's Ivanhoe (1819), the Grand Master of the Knights Templar declares: 'Not one object in England hath met mine eye which it could rest upon with pleasure, save the tombs of our brethren, beneath the massive roof of our Temple Church in yonder proud capital.' The Temple Church was built by the Knights Templar in the 12th century as their English headquarters. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Ivanhoe. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Temple Church (London, England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Melrose Abbey by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts the town of Melrose, Scottish Borders, and the ruins of Melrose Abbey with a quarry in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott coordinated the restoration of Melrose Abbey in 1822. The Abbey features in many of Scott's works, most famously The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'If thou would'st view fair Melrose aright, | Go visit it by the pale moonlight [...] | Then view St. David's ruin'd pile; | And, home returning, soothly swear, | Was never scene so sad and fair!' (canto II, stanza I, lines 1-2, 16-18). The religious house of Kennaquhair in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) is also based on the Abbey, and it is described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Monastery. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Melrose Abbey

Title#1: Barnbugle Castle and Firth of Forth: From Laurieston Castle.
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the Barnbougle Castle and the Firth of Forth by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts the Firth of Forth from Lauriston Castle, Edinburgh, with cattle in the foreground. In Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820), the hero Roland Graeme 'admired the Gothic towers of Barnbougle, rising from the seabeaten rock, and overlooking one of the most glorious landscapes in Scotland' (ch. 20). The thirteenth-century tower house is the seat of the Earls of Roseberry. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Abbot. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Barnbougle Castle (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester by G. B. Shaw after W. Lodge
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester (1532 or 3-1588), in full court dress wearing the Order of the Garter. The murder of Amy Robsart, first wife of Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester, is the subject of Sir Walter Scott's Kenilworth (1821). Leicester was Elizabeth I's Master of the Horse and court favourite. He was suspected of arranging Amy Robsart's murder to free himself to marry the Queen. The original steel engraving, after a sixteenth-century portrait by Sir William Segar, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Kenilworth. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters Leicester, Robert Dudley, Earl of, 1532?-1588 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Warwick Castle by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts Warwick Castle in the moonlight, with the River Avon in the foreground. In Sir Walter Scott's Kenilworth (1821), Queen Elizabeth I stays at Warwick Castle while travelling to Kenilworth Castle. Scott describes it as 'that fairest monument of ancient and chivalrous splendour which yet remains uninjured by time' (ch. 25). Scott visited Warwick Castle in September 1815 when travelling home from France. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Kenilworth. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Warwick Castle (England)

Title#1: [Engraving of Thurso Bay and Orkney Islands by R. Brandard after W. Collins]
Description#1: Depicts Thurso Bay, Caithness, with a view across the sea to Orkney. Sir Walter Scott's The Pirate (1821) was inspired by the legend of the Orkney pirate, John Gow, and is set partly in Orkney, partly in Shetland. Scott visited both groups of islands in 1814 when he joined a party of Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection around the coast of Scotland. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Pirate. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Orkney (Scotland)

Title#1: View on the Coast of Zetland: The Morning after a Storm
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Shetland (Zetland) by W. Miller after W. Collins
Description#1: Depicts wreckage off the Shetland coast. In Sir Walter Scott's The Pirate (1822), Captain Cleveland is shipwrecked on the coast of Shetland, where most of the novel is set. Scott visited Shetland in 1814 when he joined a party of Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection around the coast of Scotland. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Pirate. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Shetland (Scotland)

Title#1: Royal Palace, Whitehall: As Designed by Inigo Jones
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the Royal Palace at Whitehall by J. Horsburgh after G.H. Dodgson
Description#1: Depicts the Palace of Whitehall, London, and the River Thames. In Walter Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel (1822), the hero Nigel Olifaunt, Lord Glenvarloch travels to the court of King James VI and I at Whitehall, in order to reclaim a sum of money lent to the King by his father. The palace was then undergoing a major modernization at the hands of Inigo Jones. Nigel thus finds the King 'amidst the rubbish of old buildings, and the various confusion attending the erection of the new pile, which formed at present a labyrinth not easily traversed' (ch. 5). A fire in the Palace on 4 January 1698 destroyed all except Inigo Jones's Banqueting Hall. The original steel engraving, from a drawing in the British Museum, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels. Abbotsford Edition, vol. VII. Edinburgh: R. Cadell, 1845, facing p. 293
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Whitehall Palace (London, England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of James I by G. B. Shaw after the original at the Palace of Holyroodhouse
Description#1: Engraved portrait of King James VI and I (1566-1625) in ermine fringed robes. In Walter Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel (1822), the hero Nigel Olifaunt, Lord Glenvarloch travels to the court of King James VI and I at Whitehall, in order to reclaim a sum of money lent to the King by his father. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). It derives from a portrait painted in 1618 by Paulus van Somer.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Fortunes of Nigel. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters James I, King of England, 1566-1625 - Portraits

Title#1: [Engraving of Haddon Hall by J. Horsburgh after W. L. Leitch]
Description#1: Depicts Haddon Hall and surrounding countryside. Martindale Castle, ancient seat of the Peverils in Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823), is generally thought to be modelled on Haddon Hall, a fortified medieval manor house belonging to the Manners family. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Peveril of the Peak. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Haddon Hall (England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Peveril Castle by W. Richardson after W. L. Leitch
Description#1: Depicts Peveril Castle overlooking the village of Castleton, Derbyshire. Peveril Castle is the principal seat of Sir Geoffrey Peveril in Sir Walter Scott's novel, Peveril of the Peak (1823). The stronghold, formerly known as Peak Castle, was built around 1080 by William Peveril who is thought to be the illegitimate son of William the Conqueror. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Peveril of the Peak. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Peveril Castle (Castleton, Derbyshire, England)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Castle Rushen by W. Miller after W. L. Leitch
Description#1: Depicts the harbour at Castleton, Isle of Man, with Castle Rushen in the background. At the beginning of Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823), the hero Julian Peveril is staying as a guest of the Countess of Derby in Castle Rushen (or Rushin). The Castle was built around 1200 and was the residence of the last Norse King of Man (d. 1266). Scott did not personally visit the Isle of Man, but received information from his younger brother Thomas who served as an officer in the Manx Fencibles from 1808 to 1810. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Peveril of the Peak. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Castle Rushen (Isle of Man)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of PÌ©ronne by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts four soldiers outside the castle of PÌ©ronne, Somme, France. In Sir Walter Scott's Quentin Durward (1823), Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy makes his camp at PÌ©ronne. He is unexpectedly visited there by his enemy Louis XI who, by feigning friendliness, hopes to allay suspicions that he has backed a revolt against Charles's brother-in-law, the Bishop of LiÌ¬ge. Charles sees through Louis's ploy and imprisons him. The King is finally, however, able to persuade Charles of his innocence and regain liberty. Scott himself passed through PÌ©ronne when travelling from Belgium to France in 1815. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Quentin Durward. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings PÌ©ronne (Somme, France)
