Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Cologne by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts the waterfront of Cologne, Germany, with, to the right, a view of the Cathedral. In Sir Walter Scott's Quentin Durward (1823), the eponymous hero journeys to LiÌ¬ge with Isabelle de Croye under the pretence of being pilgrims on their way to visit the Shrine of the Three Kings in Cologne Cathedral. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Quentin Durward. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Cologne (Germany)

Title#1: Peebles and the Tweed: From Neidpath Castle
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Neidpath Castle by W. Miller after P. Paton
Description#1: Depicts the Peebles countryside and the River Tweed from the battlements of Neidpath Castle (Scottish Borders). Neidpath Castle, near Peebles, has been suggested as the model for Saint Ronan's Castle as described in chapter I of Saint Ronan's Well (1823). Neidpath is a 14th-century castle converted into a 17th-century tower house. At the turn of the 19th century, it was home to Scott's close friend Adam Ferguson. It also features in Scott's poem 'The Maid of Neidpath', which was published in William Whyte's A Collection of Scottish Airs (1806-07): 'Disease had been in Mary's bower | And slow decay from mourning, | Though now she sits on Neidpath's tower | To watch her Love's returning' (lines 5-8). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Saint Ronan's Well. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Neidpath Castle (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Dumfries, Scotland by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts the River Nith and the town of Dumfries. The first part of Sir Walter Scott's Redgauntlet (1824) consists of a series of letters between Darsie Latimer and Alan Fairford. Darsie's first letter is sent from Dumfries which he has made his base while rambling through the countryside of Dumfries and Galloway. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Redgauntlet. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Dumfries (Scotland)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Llanberis Pass by W. Miller after R. K. Penson
Description#1: Depicts a traveller making his way through the Llanberis Pass, Wales, with Dolbadern Castle in the background. Sir Walter Scott's The Betrothed (1824) is a tale of Anglo-Welsh Border conflict set in the Welsh Marches. In ch. 9 an Anglo-Norman force lifts the siege of the castle of Garde Douleureuse. The defeated Welsh army are seen fleeing through the pass protected by the Castle: 'The single pass by which they could cross to the other side was soon completely choked by fugitives, on whose rear raged the swords of the victorious Normans. Many threw themselves into the river, upon the precarious chance of gaining the farther side, and, except a few, who were uncommonly strong, skilful, and active, perished among the rocks and in the currents'. To illustrate this scene, R. K. Penson has chosen to portray Dolbadern Castle and the Llanberis Pass, although neither is geographically close to the Welsh Marches. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Betrothed. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Llanberis (Wales)

Title#1: Convent of St. Saba, Wilderness of Engadi, Holy Land
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the Convent of St Saba by J. Horsburgh after D. Roberts
Description#1: Depicts the monastery of Mar Saba overlooking the Kidron Valley (West Bank). In chapter 6 of Sir Walter Scott's The Talisman (1825), King Richard of England is informed that his wife Queen Berengaria has set out on a pilgrimage to the 'Convent of Engadi', i.e. the Greek-Orthodox Monastery Mar Saba. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Talisman. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Mar Saba (Monastery)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Worcester by W. Miller after T. Creswick
Description#1: Depicts the River Severn and city of Worcester. The plot of Sir Walter Scott's novel Woodstock (1826) revolves around the escape of King Charles II following his decisive defeat by Cromwell at the Battle of Worcester (3 September 1651). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Woodstock. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Worcester (England)

Title#1: [Engraving of Windsor Castle by J. Horsburgh after T. Creswick]
Description#1: Depicts Windsor Castle, Berkshire, by moonlight. In Sir Walter Scott's Woodstock (1826), Cromwell is stationed at Windsor while awaiting the capture of the fugitive King Charles II. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Woodstock. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Windsor Castle (England)

Title#1: [Engraving of Kilchurn Castle and Loch Awe by W. Miller after H. McCulloch]
Description#1: Depicts Loch Awe and Kilchurn Castle (Argyl and Bute, Scotland). In Sir Walter Scott's The Highland Widow (1827), the narrator Mrs. Bethune Baliol meets Elspat MacTavish, the widow of the title, while on a Highland tour. On the morning before their meeting, Mrs Baliol's party takes a boat-trip across Loch Awe, and their guide tells 'a hundred legends of the stern chiefs of Loch Awe, Duncan with the thrum bonnet, and the other lords of the now mouldering towers of Kilchurn'. The Castle, seat of the Lairds of Glenurquhay, was built around 1440. The original painting by Horatio McCulloch was made in 1844. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Highland Widow, etc. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Kilchurn Castle (Scotland)

Title#1: Ben Lawers, From the South Shore of Loch Tay
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Ben Lawers by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts the south face of Ben Lawers as seen from Loch Tay, Perthshire. In ch. 27 of Sir Walter Scott's The Fair Maid of Perth (1828), the mountains seen from the north bank of Loch Tay are likened to a 'clan of Titans [...] commanded by their appropriate chieftains -- the frowning mountain of Ben Lawers, and the still more lofty eminence of Ben Mohr'. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Fair Maid of Perth. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lawers, Ben (Scotland)

Title#1: St. Omer and the Cathedral, Strasbourg
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Strasbourg by W. Richardson after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts Strasbourg Cathedral, Alsace, France, with, in the foreground, the Protestant Ìäglise Saint-Thomas (incorrectly identified as St. Omer). In Sir Walter Scott's Anne of Geierstein (1829), two exiled Lancastrians, John de Vere, Earl of Oxford, and his son, Arthur, travel to Strasbourg on a mission to convert Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy, to the Lancastrian cause. In Strasbourg Cathedral, Arthur meets Margaret of Anjou, widow of the Lancastrian King Henry VI (ch. 24). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Anne of Geierstein. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Strasbourg (France)

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Mount Pilatus by J. Cousen after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Presents a view of the Swiss Alps from Mount Pilatus. In Sir Walter Scott's Anne of Geierstein (1829), the exiled Lancastrians John de Vere, Earl of Oxford, and his son, Arthur, travel incognito through Switzerland on a mission to convert Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy, to the Lancastrian cause. As they stand beneath the 'dark and shadowy eminence' of Mount Pilatus, they are told the local legend that Pontius Pilate committed suicide by throwing himself into the lake at its summit and that his ghost still haunts the peak. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Anne of Geierstein. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Pilatus (Switzerland)

Title#1: The Walls of Constantinople and Distant View of the Sea of Marmara
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the Walls of Constantinople by W. Forrest after T. Allom
Description#1: Depicts the city walls of Istanbul, Turkey. Sir Walter Scott's Count Robert of Paris is set in Constantinople during the reign of the Byzantine Emperor Alexius Comnenus (1081-1118).The opening scene takes place outside the Golden Gate before 'the massive, and seemingly impregnable walls with which Constantine surrounded the city' and which 'were greatly improved and added to by Theodosius' (ch. 2). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Count Robert of Paris. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Istanbul (Turkey) - Antiquities

Title#1: [Engraving of the Rumeli Fortress and the Bosporus by W. Richardson after T. Allom]
Description#1: Depicts the Rumeli Hisar±, Istanbul, Turkey and the River Bosporus. Sir Walter Scott's Count Robert of Paris is set in Constantinople during the reign of the Byzantine Emperor Alexius Comnenus (1081-1118). The fortress of Rumeli Hisar± portrayed here was built in 1451 or 1452, some three-and-a-half centuries later than the setting of the novel. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Count Robert of Paris. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Bosporus (Turkey)

Title#1: [Engraving of the Palace of Holyroodhouse by W. Miller after C. Stanfield]
Description#1: Depicts the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh, with the Salisbury Crags and the Firth of Forth in the background. In Sir Walter Scott's Waverley (1814), the Royal Palace of Holyroodhouse is occupied by Prince Charles Edward Stuart and is the scene of a ball (ch. 43). The Palace is also described in Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Palace of Holyroodhouse (Edinburgh, Scotland)
Subject Person#1$1: Charles Edward, Prince grandson of James II, King of England

Title#1: Highland Hills, From the Teith Below Callander
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of the Highland Hills, near Callander by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts a view from the River Teith, Perthshire. In ch. 38 of Sir Walter Scott's Waverley (1814), Edward Waverley is rescued by a party of Jacobite Highlanders and escorted through the Menteith district and over the River Teith to Doune Castle. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Teith, River (Scotland)

Title#1: [Engraving of boats on Lake Windermere by E. Goodall after C. Stanfield]
Description#1: Depicts a ferry crossing Lake Windermere, Cumbria. This engraving illustrates a passage in ch. 16 of Sir Walter Scott's Guy Mannering (1815), where Julia Mannering is serenaded by Henry Bertram on an (unnamed) Westmorland lake. Scott met his wife Charlotte when holidaying in the Lake District in 1797. He made further visits to the region in 1805, 1813, and 1825. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Guy Mannering. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Windermere, Lake (England)

Title#1: Skiddaw and Saddleback: From Bolton Moor.
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Skiddaw and Saddleback by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts Bolton Moor, Cumbria, with Skiddaw and Saddleback mountains in the background. In ch. 22 of Guy Mannering (1815), Sir Walter Scott describes the hero Henry Bertram setting out on foot from Cumbria to Scotland: 'Let the reader conceive to himself a clear frosty November morning, the scene an open heath,--having for the background that huge chain of mountains in which Skiddaw and Saddleback are pre-eminent.' Scott met his wife Charlotte when holidaying in the Lake District in 1797. He made further visits to the region in 1805, 1813, and 1825. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Guy Mannering. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Skiddaw (Cumbria)

Title#1: Dundee in the Time of the Antiquary
Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Dundee by E. Goodall after C. Stanfield
Description#1: Depicts the River Tay and the waterfront of Dundee. Sir Walter Scott himself acknowledged that Jonathan Oldbuck, the titular character of The Antiquary (1816), was based partly on a family friend George Constable who first introduced Scott to Shakespeare. Constable was a native of Dundee, and Oldbuck's house of Monkbarns is sometimes thought to be based on Constable's estate of Craigie Wallace. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Antiquary. Edinburgh: Adam and Charles Black, [185-?]
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Dundee (Scotland)

Title#1: From the Original Picture in the Possession of Mr. Murray: Painted 1824
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by W. Finden after G. S. Newton
Description#1: Three-quarter portrait of Walter Scott at the age of fifty-three. Sir Walter Scott sat for Gilbert Stuart Newton in August 1824. The portrait was commissioned by the publisher John Murray and is held by his heirs. The engraving was first published by John Murray in 1833. It includes a facsimile of Scott's handwriting with the words: 'Very truly yours, Walter Scott. Abbotsford 3 Sept. 1824'.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: The Portrait Engraved by Woolnoth and the Emblematical Design by Hawksworth
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by T. Woolnoth after A. Geddes, with ornamental frieze by J. Hawkesworth
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott (aged forty-seven or forty-eight), surrounded by a Gothic border with vignettes taken from his poems. The original portrait by Andrew Geddes began life as a study for his The Discovery of the Regalia of Scotland (1821). The sitting took place some time between 4 February 1818, the date of the discovery of the Regalia, and the beginning of 1819 when Scott fell seriously ill. The portrait suggests that Scott's health is already deteriorating. Originally purchased by the collector Sir James Stuart, 7th Baronet of Allanbank, the picture now hangs in the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. Woolnoth's engraving is after a drawing by Geddes himself, or possibly after an earlier engraving by F.C. Lewis (1824). The ornamental frieze by Hawkesworth features scenes from Scott's poems, some based on illustrations by Richard Westall. Scott had not yet publicly acknowledged authorship of the Waverley Novels (he would do so in 1827).
Source#1: The Spirit of the Public Journals for the Year M.DCCC.XXV. London: Sherwood, Gilbert, and Piper, 1826 (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Sir Walter Scott, and His Favorite Maida: From an Original Sketch
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by R.J Hamerton
Description#1: Engraved portrait of a seated Walter Scott with his dog Maida. This engraved portrait by Robert Jacob Hamerton (fl. 1831-1858) was published by J. M. M'Cormack, London, in 1832. The 'original sketch' has not been identified. The face bears a close resemblance to that in Charles Robert Leslie's 1824 portrait of Scott, especially as engraved by M. I. Danforth in 1829.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Etched portrait of Walter Scott by William Nicholson]
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott aged forty-six, with his dog Maida. William Nicholson made at least three watercolour portraits of Sir Walter Scott in 1816. One formed the basis for this etching executed in 1817 by Nicholson himself. The only significant difference between the watercolour and the etching is that Scott's dog Maida has been moved somewhat to the right, leaving more of Scott's waistcoat visible.
Source#1: Nicholson, W. Portraits of Distinguished Living Characters of Scotland. London: Rodwell and Martin, 1818
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Walter Scott]: Etched by W. Mayor after a Sketch by Edwin Landseer
Alternate Title#1: Facsimile of etched portrait of Walter Scott by W. Mayor after E. Landseer
Description#1: Facsimile of etched profile portrait of Walter Scott. The etching by W. Mayor was taken from a portrait now in the collection of the Dower House Gallery, Boughton House. According to Algernon Graves, the portrait was painted in 1831 (Catalogue of the Works of the Late Sir Edwin Landseer, no. 163). There is no record of Scott sitting for Landseer in that year, but Scott appears markedly older than in sketches made by Landseer in 1824. Francis Russell agrees that it is 'not unreasonable' to suggest that Landseer may have seen Scott in 1831, but argues that Landseer nonetheless referred to his earlier sketches of Scott (Portraits of Sir Walter Scott, no. 113). The etching by Mayor was published in 1832.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Facsimile of silhouette of Sir Walter Scott by A. Edouart]
Description#1: Profile full-length silhouette of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-nine (with slight water damage). The original silhouette of Sir Walter Scott was cut by Augustin Edouart in Edinburgh in 1831. It is now held by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery.
Source#1: The Connoisseur, 90 (Sept. 1932), p.169
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: [Facsimile of silhouette of Walter Scott at his desk by A. Edouart]
Description#1: Newspaper clipping of silhouette of Sir Walter Scott, aged fifty-nine, writing at his desk. The original silhouette of Sir Walter Scott was cut by Augustin Edouart in Edinburgh in 1831. It is now held by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery.
Source#1: The Scotsman, 27 October 1928
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Sir Walter Scott: From a Sketch by Sir Edwin Landseer
Alternate Title#1: Pencil drawing of Sir Walter Scott after E. Landseer
Description#1: Pencil sketch of three-quarter portrait of Sir Walter Scott, with, below, a further profile of Scott. The original sketch by Sir Edwin Landseer was probably made during his visit to Abbotsford in 1824. It is now held by the Victoria and Albert Museum. This pencil drawing was probably made by James Clarkson Corson, copied from a reprint of the original sketch in Richard Garnett and Edmund Gosse's English Literature (1903).
Source#1: Gosse, E. English Literature: An Illustrated Record, vol. IV. London: W. Heinemann. 1903
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by W.T. Fry after T. Phillips
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of Walter Scott, aged forty-four, with a plaid of Stuart tartan over his shoulders. The dating of the half-length portrait of Scott made by Thomas Phillips for the publisher John Murray remains uncertain. In his Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. (2nd edn, 1839), J.G. Lockhart dates it to 1818, relying on information provided by Phillips himself. In his Portraits of Sir Walter Scott, however, Francis Russell argues that 1815 is more probable (no. 157). Scott did not, in fact, visit London in 1818 but spent ten weeks there in 1815, spending a good deal of time at John Murray's where he met Byron. The engraving by Fry was first published by Boys, 1 November 1820.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Walter Scott, Esq.: Engraved For the New Monthly Magazine, by Hy. Meyer
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by H. Meyer after H. Raeburn
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott at the age of thirty-six. The original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn was commissioned by Scott's publisher Archibald Constable in 1808. It is now part of the collection at Bowhill, seat of the Duke of Buccleuch. Meyer's engraving was published in the November 1818 issue of the New Monthly Magazine. It is based on an earlier engraving by Charles Picart (1811) made from a drawing by William Evans. Evans substituted the outdoor backdrop of Raeburn's portrait for an interior suggestive of the writer's study.
Source#1: New Monthly Magazine, 1 November, 1818
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Sir Walter Scott: From the Original in Possession of the Publishers
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by H. Robinson after J. W. Gordon
Description#1: Engraved three-quarter portrait of Walter Scott, seated in a study. The original portrait by John Watson Gordon was probably painted to be engraved by Samuel Freeman for Robert Chambers's Lives of Eminent Scotsmen, vol. 4 (Glasgow: Blackie & Son, 1835). It derives from an earlier unfinished portrait by Gordon, painted in spring 1830 and now held by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. The engraving by Robinson was first published by Blackie & Son in 1837. It adds a chair, bookshelves, curtains, and the Byron urn to the Gordon/Freeman original.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Walter Scott with family and friends by J. Smith after D. Willkie
Description#1: Depicts Walter Scott with family and friends in south-country peasant dress. Sir David Wilkie was commissioned to paint 'The Abbotsford Family' by Scott's friend Sir Adam Ferguson in 1817. The sittings took place at Abbotsford in October of that year. Portrayed from left are: Lady Scott; Ann Scott (Scott's younger daughter); Sophia Scott (Scott's older daughter, later Mrs. John Gibson Lockhart); Sir Walter Scott (seated); Thomas Scott (shepherd); Charles Scott (Scott's younger son); Sir Adam Ferguson; Walter Scott (Scott's oldest son). The dogs are Maida (left) and Ourisk (right). The painting is now held by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. The engraving by John Smith was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels, vol. XII. Abbotsford Edition. Edinburgh: Cadell, 1847) (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by E. Smith after D. Wilkie
Description#1: Engraved three-quarter portrait of Walter Scott (aged fifty-three) in fur-trimmed cloak. The portrait by David Wilkie originated in 1824 as a sketch for The Entrance of King George the Fourth at Holyrood, where Scott was to figure among the King's attendants. It was subsequently worked up as an independent painting for Sir William Knighton in 1828. It was engraved by Edward Smith for Robert Cadell, Edinburgh, and Moon, Graves, & Boys, London, in 1829. In 1830, it was published as the frontispiece to vol. I of The Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott.
Source#1: Scott, W. The Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott, vol. I. Edinburgh: Cadell, 1830 (front.)
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by W.H. Lizars after W. Wilkie
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott at the age of sixty. The original portrait by Captain William Wilkie was painted in 1831. The undated engraving by Lizars was published by George Tait, Haddington, and Alexander Hill, Edinburgh. George Tait died in 1844.
Subject#1: Authors, Scottish - Portraits Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Henry Mackenzie: From the Original in Possession of the Publishers
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Henry Mackenzie by S. Freeman after J. Watson Gordon
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Scottish novelist Henry Mackenzie (1745-1831). Scott read Henry Mackenzie's novels in his youth and became his friend and colleague in adulthood.Mackenzie contributed to Walter Scott's Edinburgh Annual Register and both men were trustees of the Edinburgh Theatre. In 1823, Scott edited Mackenzie's fiction for Ballantyne's Novelists Library, and provided a biographical sketch of the author which was subsequently reprinted as one of his Lives of the Novelists. The original portrait by Watson Gordon was probably expressly painted to be engraved by Freeman for Chambers's Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen (1835). It may have derived from an earlier portrait by Watson Gordon painted during Mackenzie's lifetime.
Source#1: Chambers, R. (ed.) A Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen, vol. III. Glasgow: Blackie, 1835
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Mackenzie, Henry, 1745-1831 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait by G. Parker after S.A. Hart of the heroine of Scott's novel The Talisman
Description#1: Depicts Edith Plantagenet, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's novel The Talisman (1825), dressed as a Carmelite votaress with a chaplet of red and white roses. This portrait of Edith Plantagenet was inspired by a passage in ch. 4 of The Talisman in which Edith appears as a Carmelite novice: 'Six, who from their black scapularies, and black veils over their white garments, appeared to be professed nuns of the order of Mount Carmel; and as many whose veils, being white, argued them to be novices, or occasional inhabitants in the cloister, who were not as yet bound to it by vows. The former held in their hands large rosaries, while the younger and lighter figures who followed carried each a chaplet of red and white roses... one of the white-stoled maidens, as she glided by him, detached from the chaplet which she carried a rosebud, which dropped from her fingers, perhaps unconsciously, on the foot of Sir Kenneth.'
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt. 1834
Subject#1: Crusades - Third, 1189-1192 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Dugald Stewart by S. Freeman after H. Raeburn
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of Scottish philosopher Dugald Stewart (1753-1828). Sir Walter Scott studied Moral Philosophy under Dugald Stewart at Edinburgh University in 1789-90. An exponent of the Scottish 'Common Sense' School of philosophy, Stewart greatly influenced Scott's views on history, human nature, and political ethics. At one stage good friends, the two men fell out following Scott's vehement support of Henry Dundas, Viscount Melville when he was impeached in 1806 for misappropriation of public money. The original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn was painted ca. 1810.
Source#1: Chambers, R. (ed.) A Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen. Vol. IV. Glasgow: Blackie. 1835.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Stewart, Dugald, 1753-1828 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait by H.T. Ryall after W. Mulready of the heroine of Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of Alice Bridgenorth, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak (1823). This portrait of Alice Bridgenorth was inspired by the following lines in ch. 13 of the novel: 'The sad-coloured gown--the pinched and plaited cap, which carefully obscured the profusion of long dark-brown hair--the small ruff, and the long sleeves, would have appeared to great disadvantage on a shape less graceful than Alice Bridgenorth's.'
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt, 1834
Subject#1: Popish Plot, 1678 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait by W.H. Egleston after J.W. Wright of the heroine of Scott's novel Castle Dangerous
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of Lady Augusta de Berkely, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's Castle Dangerous (1831), disguised as a male pilgrim. The portrait illustrates the line: 'In a moment, I think, of madness, I resolved to set out in this masculine disguise' (ch. 11). Lady Augusta, an English heiress, has promised to marry Sir John de Walton if he can defend the strategically vital Castle Douglas against the forces of Robert the Bruce and Sir James Douglas (the 'Black Douglas') for a year and a day. Increasingly alarmed, though, by the danger he is running, she travels to Douglasdale in masculine disguise. The scallop shell was the universally recognized badge of a pilgrim.
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt, 1834
Subject#1: Scotland - History - War of Independence, 1285-1371 Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait by C.E. Wagstaff after J. Inskipp of the heroine of Scott's novel The Betrothed
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of Eveline Berenger, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's novel The Betrothed (1825). This portrait of Eveline Berenger, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's The Betrothed (1825), was inspired by the following line in ch. 8: 'The morning light was scarce fully spread abroad, when Eveline Berenger, in compliance with her confessor's advice, commenced her progress around the walls and battlements of the beleaguered castle.' Eveline's father, the Anglo-Norman Raymond Berenger, has refused her hand to the Welsh prince Gwenwyn, and the incensed Gwenwyn has laid siege to the Berengers' castle of Garde Douloureuse.
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt, 1834
Subject#1: Wales - History - 1063-1284 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Lochmaben Castle by J.T. Willmore after J.M.W. Turner
Description#1: Engraved title page for The Poetical Works of Walter Scott, vol. III, with vignette depicting the ruins of Lochmaben Castle, Dumfries and Galloway. Lochmaben Castle near Dumfries was the seat of the Bruce family in their capacity as Lords of Annandale and has been proposed by some historians as the birthplace of Robert the Bruce, hero of Sir Walter Scott's The Lord of the Isles (1815). Built in the 13th century, the castle lay in ruins by Scott's time. There are further references to Lochmaben Castle and the Bruces in Scott's The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) and in the traditional ballad 'The Lochmaben Harper' which Scott included in his Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1803).
Source#1: Scott, W. The Poetical Works of Walter Scott, Bart., vol. III. Edinburgh: Robert Cadell, 1833 (t.p.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Lochmaben Castle (Lochmaben, Scotland)

Title#1: Alexander Adam, L.L.D.: From the Original Painting in the Royal High School Edinburgh
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Alexander Adam by S. Freeman after H. Raeburn
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of Scottish educationalist Alexander Adam (1741-1809). Alexander Adam was Rector of the High School of Edinburgh where Sir Walter Scott was educated from 1779 to 1783. One of the most innovative educators of his age, he sought to instil in his pupils not only a grasp of grammar but a sensitivity to literary language. With Adam's encouragement, the young Scott translated Horace and Virgil into English verse and made his first attempts at original composition. The original portrait was painted by Raeburn ca. 1808.
Source#1: Chambers, R. (ed.) A Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen, vol. I. Glasgow: Blackie, 1835
Subject#1: Educators - Scotland - Portraits Adam, Alexander, 1741-1809 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of Edinburgh Castle by Heath
Description#1: Depicts the north-west face of Edinburgh Castle. Edinburgh Castle is the most prominent landmark of Scott's hometown. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities & Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). The engraving is by James Heath, possibly after his own design.
Source#1: Thomson, W. A Tour in England and Scotland, in 1785. London: G.G.J. and J. Robinson.,1788 (facing p. 257)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Homes and haunts Edinburgh Castle (Edinburgh, Scotland)
Related Work Title#1: Description of the Regalia of Scotland
Related Work Title#4: Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland

Alternate Title#1: Engraving of a cave at Staffa by E. Goodall after J.W.M. Turner
Description#1: Engraved title page for The Poetical Works of Walter Scott, vol. X, with image of Staffa, Inner Hebrides. Sir Walter Scott visited the Isle of Staffa in 1810 and declared it 'one of the most extraordinary places I ever beheld' which 'exceeded in my mind every description I had heard of it' (Letter to Joanna Baillie, July 19, 1810). He was particularly struck by Fingal's Cave: 'the appearance of the cavern composed entirely of basaltic pillars as high as the roof of a cathedral and running deep into the rock, eternally swept by a deep and swelling sea, and paved as it were with ruddy marble baffles all description'. He subsequently described Fingal's Cave in The Lord of the Isles (1815), canto IV, stanza X: 'that wondrous dome, | Where, as to shame the temples deck'd | By skill of earthly architect, | Nature herself, it seem'd, would raise | A Minster to her Maker's p raise!' (lines 13-17). The island and its caves are further celebrated in 'Lines Addressed to Ranald Macdonald, Esq. of Staffa' (1814).
Source#1: The Poetical Works of Walter Scott, Bart., vol. X. Edinburgh: Robert Cadell, 1833 (t.p.)
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Settings Staffa (Scotland)
Related Work Title#2: Lines Addressed to Ranald Macdonald, Esq. of Staffa

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait by H. Meyer after J.S. Stump of a character from Scott's novel Kenilworth
Description#1: Engraved portrait depicting Janet Foster, lady-in-waiting to Amy Robsart in Sir Walter Scott's Kenilworth (1821). This portrait of Janet Foster is inspired by a passage in ch. 5 of the novel. Janet admires a string of pearls sent as a gift to Amy by her husband the Earl of Leicester: '"Surely, lady," said Janet, gazing with admiration at the neck-string of pearls, "the daughters of Tyre wore no fairer neck-jewels than these. And then the posy, 'For a neck that is fairer'--each pearl is worth a freehold.'
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt, 1834
Subject#1: Great Britain - History - Elizabeth, 1558-1603 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait by H. Cook after H. Howard of a character from Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Fenella, confidante of the Countess of Derby in Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823). This portrait is inspired by a passage in ch. 5 of the novel. Fenella, who has assumed the role of a deaf mute, attempts to warn Julian Peveril against keeping a rendezvous with Alice Bridgenorth: 'She proceeded to put him to the question by a series of gestures, which we will endeavour to describe. She commenced by extending her hand slightly, accompanied with the sharp inquisitive look which served her as a note of interrogation... Fenella looked grave, shook her head, and pointed to the Countess's window, which was visible from the spot where they stood.'
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt, 1834
Subject#1: Popish Plot, 1678 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Title#1: Francis Jeffrey: One of the Lords of Session
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Francis Jeffrey by G. Stodart after G. Hayter
Description#1: Engraved profile portrait of the Scottish lawyer and critic Francis Jeffrey, Lord Jeffrey (1773-1850). Francis Jeffrey was one of the founders of the Edinburgh Review and responsible for asking his fellow advocate Walter Scott to contribute. The Review flourished with Jeffrey as editor, and he became a powerful and influential critic. Jeffrey reviewed a number of Scott's own works making few concessions to personal friendship. Scott was particularly hurt by his critique of Marmion (1808), feeling that it might have been couched 'in language rather more civil to a personal friend'. While entertaining the highest regard for Jeffrey's talents, Scott felt he lacked 'the taste for poetry which is essentially necessary to enjoy and of course to criticize it with justice', and specifically 'that enthusiastic feeling which like sun-shine upon a landscape lights up every beauty and palliates if it cannot hide ever defect' (letter to Joanna Baillie, 31 October 1808).
Source#1: Chambers, R. (ed.) A Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen, vol. V. Glasgow: Blackie, 1835
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Jeffrey, Francis Jeffrey, Lord, 1773-1850 - Portraits
Related Work Title#1: Marmion; a Tale of Flodden Field

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait by W.H. Mote after E.T. Parris of a character from Scott's novel Anne of Geierstein
Description#1: Engraved portrait of Hermione, a character in Scott's Anne of Geierstein (1829). This portrait of Hermione, a learned Persian woman who acts as tutor to the Baron of Arnheim in Anne of Geierstein, was inspired by the following passage in ch. 11 of the novel: 'The silver lamp was extinguished, or removed from its pedestal, where stood in place of it a most beautiful female figure in the Persian costume, in which the color of pink predominated. But she wore no turban or head-dress of any kind, saving a blue ribbon drawn through her auburn hair, and secured by a gold clasp, the outer side of which was ornamented by a superb opal [...]. The little lady's countenance was of a lively and expressive character, in which spirit and wit seemed to predominate; and the quick dark eye, with its beautifully formed eyebrow, seemed to presage the arch remark, to which the rosy and half smiling lip appeared ready to give utterance.'
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt, 1834
Subject#1: Great Britain - History - James I, 1603-1625 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait by H. Robinson after S.J. Rochard of the heroine of Scott's novel Quentin Durward
Description#1: Engraved profile portrait of Countess Isabelle de Croye, heroine of Scott's Quentin Durward (1823). This portrait of Isabelle de Croye is inspired by the eponymous hero's first glimpse of her: 'He speedily made the discovery that a quantity of long black tresses, which, in the maiden fashion of his own country, were unadorned by any ornament, except a single chaplet lightly woven out of ivy leaves, formed a veil around a countenance which, in its regular features, dark eyes, and pensive expression, resembled that of Melpomene, though there was a faint glow on the cheek, and an intelligence on the lips and in the eye, which made it seem that gaiety was not foreign to a countenance so expressive, although it might not be its most habitual expression.' (ch. 4)
Source#1: Portraits of the Principal Female Characters in the Waverley Novels. London: Charles Tilt, 1834
Subject#1: France - History - Louis XI, 1461-1483 - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters - Heroines

Title#1: Sir John Leslie: Professor of Natural Philosophy in the University of Edinburgh
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir John Leslie by J. Johnstone after B.W. Crombie
Description#1: Engraved profile portrait of Scottish mathematician, scientist, and prolific inventor Sir John Leslie (1766åÐ1832). In 1808 Sir Walter Scott engaged Sir John Leslie, Professor of Mathematics at Edinburgh University, to contribute scientific articles to the Edinburgh Annual Register. Writing to George Ellis, Scott described Leslie as 'a great philosopher, and as abominable an animal as I ever saw', adding that 'he writes, however, with great eloquence, and is an enthusiast in mathematical, chemical, and mineralogical pursuits' (13 December 1808). The original portrait by Benjamin W. Crosbie was probably made for his Modern Athenians (1831), a collection of caricature etchings of prominent Edinburgh citizens.
Source#1: Chambers, R. (ed.) A Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen, vol. V. Glasgow: Blackie, 1835
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Leslie, John, Sir, 1766-1832 - Portraits

Title#1: Major Gen. David Stewart, of Garth
Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Major General David Stewart by J.B. Shaw after J.W. Gordon
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of Major-General David Stewart (1772-1829) in military uniform. David Stewart of Garth worked with Sir Walter Scott on the committee which organized the visit of King George IV to Edinburgh in August 1822. A hero of the Napoleonic Wars, Stewart is now best-known as the author of Sketches of the Character, Manners and Present State of the Highlanders of Scotland (1822). In 1828 he was appointed Governor of St Lucia. In a letter to J. G. Lockhart of 14 July 1828, Scott expresses his pleasure in the appointment, praising Stewart as a 'highlander of the old stamp'.
Source#1: Chambers, R. (ed.) A Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen, vol. IV. Glasgow: Blackie, 1835
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Stewart, David, 1772-1829 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of Sir David Wilkie by W. Holl after A. Geddes
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of Scottish painter Sir David Wilkie (1785-1841). Sir David Wilkie painted Scott on three occasions: in the group compositions 'The Abbotsford Family' (1817) and 'The Entrance of King George IV at Holyrood' (1829) and in an individual portrait (1824). He also left a sketch of 'Sir Walter Scott Coursing' (1817 or 1824). Besides painting a number of pictures inspired by the Waverley Novels, Wilkie contributed illustrations to the Magnum Opus edition of the Waverley Novels. Scott was a great admirer of Wilkie's work. In chapter 10 of The Antiquary (1816), he describes Steenie Mucklebackit's mourning family as presenting 'a scene which our Wilkie alone could have painted, with that exquisite feeling of nature that characterises his enchanting productions'. The original portrait of Wilkie by Andrew Geddes was painted in 1821.
Source#1: Chambers, R. (ed.) A Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen, vol. V. Glasgow: Blackie, 1835
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Wilkie, David, Sir, 1785-1841 - Portraits

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page for Redgauntlet by J. Horsburgh after W. Kidd
Description#1: Engraved title page for Redgauntlet, vol. XXXVI of the Magnum Opus edition of the Waverley Novels. The portrait depicts Peter Peebles, the novel's obsessive litigant, standing before Parliament House, seat of Scotland's Court of Session. As a newly qualified advocate, the novel's hero Alan Fairford takes up Peebles's case. The inscription reads: 'The identical Peter wears a huge great coat, threadbare and patched. His hair, half grey, half black, escaped in elflocks around a huge wig made of tow, above which he plants an immense cocked hat.' This is an abbreviated description of Peter Peebles taken from Letter XIII: Alan Fairford to Darsie Latimer.
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels, vol. XXXVI. Edinburgh: Cadell & Co., 1832
Subject#1: Jacobites - Fiction Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Characters

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page for The Talisman by S. Sangster after J.W. Gordon
Description#1: Engraved title page for The Talisman, vol. XXXVIII in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration portrays the meeting between the novel's hero, Sir Kenneth and Saladin. The inscription reads: 'Christian and Saracen, sat down together on the turf, and produced each the small allowance of store which they carried for their own refreshment.' (ch. 2)
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels, vol. XXXVIII. Edinburgh: Cadell & Co., 1832

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page for Anne of Geierstein by J. Rolls after J.W. Wright
Description#1: Engraved title page for Anne of Geierstein, vol. XLV in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the heroine's attendant Annette announcing to her the arrival of Arthur de Vere at Castle Arnheim. The inscription reads: 'Annette sped up a narrow turnpike stair to a closet or dressing-room, where her young mistress was seated, and exclaimed with open mouth -- Anne of Gei -- I mean my Lady Baroness, they are come, they are come !' (ch. 21)
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels, vol. XLV. Edinburgh: Cadell & Co., 1833

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page for The Pirate by Freebairn after A. Cooper
Description#1: Engraved title page for The Pirate, vol. XXV in the Magnum Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the heroine Minna Troil riding to Ull Troil's tower. The inscription reads: 'She could not help looking back to see how Minna should pass the point of peril, which she herself had just rounded: Minna, with an eager look dropped the bridle, and stretched forward her arms, and even her body, over the precipice in the attitude of a wild swan, when balancing itself.' (ch. 27)
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels, vol. XXV. Edinburgh: Cadell & Co, 1831

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page for The Abbot by W.H. Watt after E. Landseer
Description#1: Engraved title page for The Abbot, vol. XX in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the rescue of the hero Roland Graeme by Lady Avenel's stag-hound Wolf. The inscription reads: 'Wolf marked the object of her anxiety, he swam straight to the spot where his assistance was so much wanted, and, seizing the childs under dress in his mouth, he not only kept him afloat, but towed him towards the causeway.' (ch. 1)
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels, vol. XX. Edinburgh: Cadell & Co., 1831

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page for Old Mortality by C. Fox after J. Burnet
Description#1: Engraved title page for Old Mortality, vol. IX in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the arrival of Henry Morton at Cuddie Headrigg's cottage upon his return from exile. The child is Cuddie' daughter. The inscription reads: 'The child set down its water-pitcher, hardly understanding what was said to her, put her fair flaxen hair apart on her brows, and opened her round blue eyes with the wondering "what's yere wull?"' (ch. 37)
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels, vol. IX. Edinburgh: Cadell & Co., 1830

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page for A Legend of Montrose by F. Bacon after W. Boxall
Description#1: Engraved title page for A Legend of Montrose, vol. XV in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the Earl of Menteith and Allan M'Aulay rescuing the heroine Annot Lyle from the Children of the Mist. The inscription reads: 'One little maiden alone, who smiled upon Allan's drawn dirk, escaped his vengeance upon my earnest entreaty. She was brought to the castle and here bred up under the name of Annot Lyle.' (ch. 5)
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels, vol XV. Edinburgh: Cadell & Co., 1830

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page for Peveril of the Peak by F. Bacon after J. Webster
Description#1: Engraved title page for Peveril of the Peak, vol. XXVIII in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the young Julian Peveril preparing to protect Alice Bridgenorth from an intruder (who will shortly be revealed as the Countess of Derby). The inscription reads: 'Yet naturally bold and high-spirited, the little champion placed himself beside his defenceless sister, continuing to brandish his weapon in her defence, as boldly as he had himself been an Abencerrage of Grenada.' (ch. 5) 'Sister' is used here in the sense of 'comrade' or 'companion'.
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels, vol. XXVIII. Edinburgh: Cadell & Co., 1831

Alternate Title#1: Engraved title page for The Fortunes of Nigel by A. Fox after W. Boxall
Description#1: Engraved title page for The Fortunes of Nigel, vol. XXVI in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the visit of Vincent Jenkins, or 'Vin Jin' to Dame Ursley Suddlechop. Vin Jin, apprentice to George Heriot, has contracted gambling debts in an effort to gain a fortune sufficient to win Margaret Ramsay for a bride. He has come to upbraid Dame Ursley for offering him bad advice and to demand her aid in extricating himself from his predicament. The inscription reads: '[as] Jin Vin, threw himself into the great leathern chair, in which Dame Ursley was wont to solace herself of an evening, he declared "himself the most miserable dog within the sound of Bow-bell."' (ch. 21)
Source#1: Scott, W. Waverley Novels, vol. XXVI. Edinburgh: Cadell & Co., 1831

Alternate Title#1: Engraved portrait of John Home by J. Rogers after H. Raeburn
Description#1: Engraved half-length portrait of Scottish dramatist John Home (1722-1808). The Scottish dramatist John Home befriended the infant Sir Walter Scott and his aunt Jenny when they were taking the waters in Bath in 1775-1776. Scott subsequently became a frequent visitor to Home's villa at Kilduff outside Edinburgh. Scott reviewed Henry Mackenzie's edition of Home's Works (1822) in the Quarterly Review for June 1827, providing a detailed account of Home's life. The original portrait by Raeburn was painted ca. 1795-1800.
Source#1: Chambers, R. (ed.) A Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen, vol. III. Glasgow: Blackie, 1835.
Subject#1: Scott, Walter, Sir, 1771-1832 - Friends and associates Home, John, 1722-1808 - Portraits
